<div id="contentSub"></div>
<div id="contentSub2"></div>
<div id="jump-to-nav"></div>

<div class="mw-body-content mw-content-ltr" dir="ltr" id="mw-content-text" lang="en"><div class="mw-parser-output"><div class="shortdescription nomobile noexcerpt noprint searchaux" style="display:none">Country in Western Asia</div>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1033289096">.mw-parser-output .hatnote{font-style:italic}.mw-parser-output div.hatnote{padding-left:1.6em;margin-bottom:0.5em}.mw-parser-output .hatnote i{font-style:normal}.mw-parser-output .hatnote+link+.hatnote{margin-top:-0.5em}</style><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">For other uses, see <a class="mw-disambig" href="/wiki/Iran_(disambiguation)" title="Iran (disambiguation)">Iran (disambiguation)</a>.</div>
<p class="mw-empty-elt">
</p>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">"Persia" redirects here. Not to be confused with <a href="/wiki/Persis" title="Persis">Persis</a>. For other uses, see <a class="mw-disambig" href="/wiki/Persia_(disambiguation)" title="Persia (disambiguation)">Persia (disambiguation)</a>.</div>

4217">IRR</a>)</td></tr><tr class="mergedtoprow"><th class="infobox-label" scope="row">Time zone</th><td class="infobox-data"><span class="nowrap"><a href="/wiki/Coordinated_Universal_Time" title="Coordinated Universal Time">UTC</a>+3:30</span> (<a href="/wiki/Iran_Standard_Time" title="Iran Standard Time">IRST</a>)</td></tr><tr class="mergedbottomrow"><th class="infobox-label" scope="row"><div class="ib-country-fake-li">â¢Â SummerÂ (<a href="/wiki/Daylight_saving_time" title="Daylight saving time">DST</a>)</div></th><td class="infobox-data"><span class="nowrap"><a href="/wiki/Coordinated_Universal_Time" title="Coordinated Universal Time">UTC</a>+4:30</span> (IRDT)</td></tr><tr><th class="infobox-label" scope="row">Date format</th><td class="infobox-data"><span dir="rtl"><a href="/wiki/Date_and_time_notation_in_Iran" title="Date and time notation in Iran">yyyy/mm/dd</a></span> (<a href="/wiki/Solar_Hijri_calendar" title="Solar Hijri calendar">SH</a>)</td></tr><tr><th class="infobox-label" scope="row"><a href="/wiki/Left-_and_right-hand_traffic" title="Left- and right-hand traffic">Driving side</a></th><td class="infobox-data">right</td></tr><tr><th class="infobox-label" scope="row"><a href="/wiki/Telephone_numbers_in_Iran" title="Telephone numbers in Iran">Calling code</a></th><td class="infobox-data"><a href="/wiki/Telephone_numbers_in_Iran" title="Telephone numbers in Iran">+98</a></td></tr><tr><th class="infobox-label" scope="row"><a href="/wiki/ISO_3166" title="ISO 3166">ISO 3166 code</a></th><td class="infobox-data"><a href="/wiki/ISO_3166-2:IR" title="ISO 3166-2:IR">IR</a></td></tr><tr><th class="infobox-label" scope="row"><a href="/wiki/Country_code_top-level_domain" title="Country code top-level domain">Internet TLD</a></th><td class="infobox-data"><div class="plainlist"><ul><li><a href="/wiki/.ir" title=".ir">.ir</a></li><li><a href="/wiki/.ir" title=".ir">Ø§ÛØ±Ø§Ù.</a></li></ul></div></td></tr></tbody></table><style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1097025294">.mw-parser-output .side-box{margin:4px 0;box-sizing:border-box;border:1px solid #aaa;font-size:88%;line-height:1.25em;background-color:#f9f9f9}.mw-parser-output .side-box-abovebelow,.mw-parser-output .side-box-text{padding:0.25em 0.9em}.mw-parser-output .side-box-image{padding:2px 0 2px 0.9em;text-align:center}.mw-parser-output .side-box-imageright{padding:2px 0.9em 2px 0;text-align:center}@media(min-width:500px){.mw-parser-output .side-box-flex{display:flex;align-items:center}.mw-parser-output .side-box-text{flex:1}}@media(min-width:720px){.mw-parser-output .side-box{width:238px}.mw-parser-output .side-box-right{clear:right;float:right;margin-left:1em}.mw-parser-output .side-box-left{margin-right:1em}}</style><style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1092331828">@media(min-width:720px){.mw-parser-output .contains-special-characters{width:22em}}</style><div class="side-box metadata side-box-right contains-special-characters noprint selfref" style="width: 290px;">
<div class="side-box-flex">
<div class="side-box-image"><img alt="" data-file-height="384" data-file-width="512" decoding="async" height="30" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a2/Farsi.svg/40px-Farsi.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a2/Farsi.svg/60px-Farsi.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a2/Farsi.svg/80px-Farsi.svg.png 2x" width="40"/></div>
<div class="side-box-text plainlist">You may need <a href="/wiki/Help:Arabic" title="Help:Arabic">rendering support</a> to display the <a href="/wiki/Persian_alphabet" title="Persian alphabet">Persian text</a> in this article correctly.</div></div>
</div>
<p><b>Iran</b> (<span class="rt-commentedText nowrap"><small>English: </small><span class="IPA nopopups noexcerpt" lang="en-fonipa"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/English" title="Help:IPA/English">/<span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="/Éª/: 'i' in 'kit'">Éª</span><span title="/Ë/: primary stress follows">Ë</span><span title="'r' in 'rye'">r</span><span title="/ÉË/: 'a' in 'father'">ÉË</span><span title="'n' in 'nigh'">n</span></span>,<span class="wrap"> </span>-<span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="'r' in 'rye'">r</span><span title="/Ã¦/: 'a' in 'bad'">Ã¦</span><span title="'n' in 'nigh'">n</span></span>,<span class="wrap"> </span><span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="/aÉª/: 'i' in 'tide'">aÉª</span></span>-/</a></span></span>;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MW_12-0"><a href="#cite_note-MW-12">[12]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Persian_language" title="Persian language">Persian</a>: <span dir="rtl" lang="fa">Ø§ÛØ±Ø§Ù</span> <span title="Persian-language romanization"><i lang="fa-Latn">IrÃ¢n</i></span> <small></small><span class="IPA" lang="fa-Latn-fonipa" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/Persian" title="Help:IPA/Persian">[ÊiËËÉ¾ÉËn]</a></span> <span class="nowrap" style="font-size:85%">(<span class="unicode haudio"><span class="fn"><span style="white-space:nowrap;margin-right:.25em;"><a href="/wiki/File:Iran-Pronunciation.ogg" title="About this sound"><img alt="" data-file-height="20" data-file-width="20" decoding="async" height="11" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/11px-Loudspeaker.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/17px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/22px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 2x" width="11"/></a></span><a class="internal" href="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/1/17/Iran-Pronunciation.ogg" title="Iran-Pronunciation.ogg">listen</a></span></span>)</span>), officially the <b>Islamic Republic of Iran</b><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-13"><a href="#cite_note-13">[a]</a></sup> and also called <b>Persia</b><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Fishman_14-0"><a href="#cite_note-Fishman-14">[13]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Lewis1984_15-0"><a href="#cite_note-Lewis1984-15">[14]</a></sup> (<span class="rt-commentedText nowrap"><span class="IPA nopopups noexcerpt" lang="en-fonipa"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/English" title="Help:IPA/English">/<span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="/Ë/: primary stress follows">Ë</span><span title="'p' in 'pie'">p</span><span title="/ÉËr/: 'ur' in 'fur'">ÉËr</span><span title="/Ê/: 's' in 'pleasure'">Ê</span><span title="/É/: 'a' in 'about'">É</span></span>/</a></span></span><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MW_12-1"><a href="#cite_note-MW-12">[12]</a></sup>), is a country in <a href="/wiki/Western_Asia" title="Western Asia">Western Asia</a>. It is bordered by <a href="/wiki/Iraq" title="Iraq">Iraq</a> and <a href="/wiki/Turkey" title="Turkey">Turkey</a> to the west, by <a href="/wiki/Azerbaijan" title="Azerbaijan">Azerbaijan</a> and <a href="/wiki/Armenia" title="Armenia">Armenia</a> to the northwest, by the <a href="/wiki/Caspian_Sea" title="Caspian Sea">Caspian Sea</a> and <a href="/wiki/Turkmenistan" title="Turkmenistan">Turkmenistan</a> to the north, by <a href="/wiki/Afghanistan" title="Afghanistan">Afghanistan</a> and <a href="/wiki/Pakistan" title="Pakistan">Pakistan</a> to the east, and by the <a href="/wiki/Gulf_of_Oman" title="Gulf of Oman">Gulf of Oman</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Persian_Gulf" title="Persian Gulf">Persian Gulf</a> to the south. It covers an area of 1,648,195Â km<sup>2</sup> (636,372Â sqÂ mi), making it the <a href="/wiki/List_of_Asian_countries_by_area" title="List of Asian countries by area">fourth-largest country entirely in Asia</a> and the second-largest country in Western Asia behind <a href="/wiki/Saudi_Arabia" title="Saudi Arabia">Saudi Arabia</a>. Iran has a population of 85 million, making it the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_and_dependencies_by_population" title="List of countries and dependencies by population">17th-most populous country</a> in the world, and the second-largest in the <a href="/wiki/Middle_East" title="Middle East">Middle East</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-16"><a href="#cite_note-16">[15]</a></sup> Its largest cities, in descending order, are the capital <a href="/wiki/Tehran" title="Tehran">Tehran</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mashhad" title="Mashhad">Mashhad</a>, <a href="/wiki/Isfahan" title="Isfahan">Isfahan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Karaj" title="Karaj">Karaj</a>, <a href="/wiki/Shiraz" title="Shiraz">Shiraz</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Tabriz" title="Tabriz">Tabriz</a>.
</p><p>The country is home to one of the world's oldest civilizations,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-17"><a href="#cite_note-17">[16]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-18"><a href="#cite_note-18">[17]</a></sup> beginning with the formation of the <a href="/wiki/Elam" title="Elam">Elamite</a> kingdoms in the fourth millennium BC. It was first unified by the <a href="/wiki/Medes" title="Medes">Medes</a>, an <a href="/wiki/List_of_ancient_Iranian_peoples" title="List of ancient Iranian peoples">ancient Iranian people</a>, in the seventh century BC,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EncyclopÃ¦dia_Britannica_Encyclopedia_Article:_Media_ancient_region,_Iran_19-0"><a href="#cite_note-EncyclopÃ¦dia_Britannica_Encyclopedia_Article:_Media_ancient_region,_Iran-19">[18]</a></sup> and reached its territorial height in the sixth century BC, when <a href="/wiki/Cyrus_the_Great" title="Cyrus the Great">Cyrus the Great</a> founded the <a href="/wiki/Achaemenid_Empire" title="Achaemenid Empire">Achaemenid Persian Empire</a>, which became <a href="/wiki/List_of_largest_empires" title="List of largest empires">one of the largest empires in history</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-book_20-0"><a href="#cite_note-book-20">[19]</a></sup> The Achaemenid Empire fell to <a href="/wiki/Alexander_the_Great" title="Alexander the Great">Alexander the Great</a> in the fourth century BC and was subsequently divided into several <a href="/wiki/Hellenistic_period" title="Hellenistic period">Hellenistic states</a>. An Iranian rebellion established the <a href="/wiki/Parthian_Empire" title="Parthian Empire">Parthian Empire</a> in the third century BC, which was succeeded in the third century AD by the <a href="/wiki/Sasanian_Empire" title="Sasanian Empire">Sassanid Empire</a>, a major world power for the next four centuries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Norman_A._Stillman_p._22_21-0"><a href="#cite_note-Norman_A._Stillman_p._22-21">[20]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Byzantine_Studies_2006,_p._29_22-0"><a href="#cite_note-Byzantine_Studies_2006,_p._29-22">[21]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Muslim_conquest_of_Persia" title="Muslim conquest of Persia">Arab Muslims conquered the empire</a> in the seventh century AD, which led to the <a href="/wiki/Islamization_of_Iran" title="Islamization of Iran">Islamization of Iran</a>. It subsequently became a major center of <a href="/wiki/Islamic_culture" title="Islamic culture">Islamic culture</a> and learning, with <a href="/wiki/Persian_art" title="Persian art">its art</a>, <a href="/wiki/Iranian_literature" title="Iranian literature">literature</a>, <a href="/wiki/Iranian_philosophy" title="Iranian philosophy">philosophy</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Iranian_architecture" title="Iranian architecture">architecture</a> spreading across the <a href="/wiki/Muslim_world" title="Muslim world">Muslim world</a> and beyond during the <a href="/wiki/Islamic_Golden_Age" title="Islamic Golden Age">Islamic Golden Age</a>. Over the next two centuries, a series of <a href="/wiki/Iranian_Intermezzo" title="Iranian Intermezzo">native Iranian Muslim dynasties</a> emerged before the <a href="/wiki/Seljuk_dynasty" title="Seljuk dynasty">Seljuk Turks</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Ilkhanate" title="Ilkhanate">Mongols</a> conquered the region. In the 15th century, the native <a href="/wiki/Safavid_dynasty" title="Safavid dynasty">Safavids</a> re-established a unified Iranian state and national identity,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Sarkhosh_4-1"><a href="#cite_note-Sarkhosh-4">[4]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Safavid_conversion_of_Iran_to_Shia_Islam" title="Safavid conversion of Iran to Shia Islam">converted the country to Shia Islam</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Andrew_J._Newman_2006_5-1"><a href="#cite_note-Andrew_J._Newman_2006-5">[5]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-savoryeiref_23-0"><a href="#cite_note-savoryeiref-23">[22]</a></sup> Under the reign of <a href="/wiki/Nader_Shah" title="Nader Shah">Nader Shah</a> in the 18th century, Iran once again became a major world power,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-books.google.nl_24-0"><a href="#cite_note-books.google.nl-24">[23]</a></sup> though by the 19th century, a <a href="/wiki/Russo-Persian_Wars" title="Russo-Persian Wars">series of conflicts</a> with the <a href="/wiki/Russian_Empire" title="Russian Empire">Russian Empire</a> led to significant territorial losses.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFisherAveryHamblyMelville1991329â330_25-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFisherAveryHamblyMelville1991329â330-25">[24]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Timothy_C._Dowling_pp._728-730_26-0"><a href="#cite_note-Timothy_C._Dowling_pp._728-730-26">[25]</a></sup> The early 20th century saw the <a href="/wiki/Persian_Constitutional_Revolution" title="Persian Constitutional Revolution">Persian Constitutional Revolution</a>. Efforts to nationalize <a href="/wiki/Petroleum_industry_in_Iran" title="Petroleum industry in Iran">its fossil fuel supply</a> from <a href="/wiki/Western_world" title="Western world">Western</a> companies led to an <a href="/wiki/1953_Iranian_coup_d%27%C3%A9tat" title="1953 Iranian coup d'Ã©tat">Anglo-American coup in 1953</a>, which resulted in greater autocratic rule under <a href="/wiki/Mohammad_Reza_Pahlavi" title="Mohammad Reza Pahlavi">Mohammad Reza Pahlavi</a> and growing <a href="/wiki/Western_Bloc" title="Western Bloc">Western political influence</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Anthony_H._Cordesman_p_22_27-0"><a href="#cite_note-Anthony_H._Cordesman_p_22-27">[26]</a></sup> He went on to launch <a href="/wiki/White_Revolution" title="White Revolution">a far-reaching series of reforms</a> in 1963.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-28"><a href="#cite_note-28">[27]</a></sup> After the <a href="/wiki/Iranian_Revolution" title="Iranian Revolution">Iranian Revolution</a>, the current <a href="/wiki/Islamic_republic" title="Islamic republic">Islamic Republic</a> was established in 1979<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-britannica1_29-0"><a href="#cite_note-britannica1-29">[28]</a></sup> by <a href="/wiki/Ruhollah_Khomeini" title="Ruhollah Khomeini">Ruhollah Khomeini</a>, who became the country's first <a href="/wiki/Supreme_Leader_of_Iran" title="Supreme Leader of Iran">Supreme Leader</a>.
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Government_of_the_Islamic_Republic_of_Iran" title="Government of the Islamic Republic of Iran">government of Iran</a> is an <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Islamic_theocracy" title="Islamic theocracy">Islamic theocracy</a> that includes some elements of a <a href="/wiki/Presidential_system" title="Presidential system">presidential system</a>, with the ultimate authority vested in an autocratic "Supreme Leader";<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-politicalsystem_30-0"><a href="#cite_note-politicalsystem-30">[29]</a></sup> a position held by <a href="/wiki/Ali_Khamenei" title="Ali Khamenei">Ali Khamenei</a> since Khomeini's death in 1989. The Iranian government is <a href="/wiki/Authoritarianism" title="Authoritarianism">authoritarian</a>, and has attracted widespread criticism for its significant constraints and abuses against <a href="/wiki/Human_rights_in_the_Islamic_Republic_of_Iran" title="Human rights in the Islamic Republic of Iran">human rights</a> and civil liberties,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-31"><a href="#cite_note-31">[30]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-32"><a href="#cite_note-32">[31]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-33"><a href="#cite_note-33">[32]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-34"><a href="#cite_note-34">[33]</a></sup> including several violent suppressions of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/2016%E2%80%932021_Iranian_protests" title="2016â2021 Iranian protests">mass protests</a>, <a href="/wiki/Elections_in_Iran" title="Elections in Iran">unfair elections</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Women%27s_rights_in_Iran" title="Women's rights in Iran">limited rights for women</a> and <a href="/wiki/The_Rights_of_the_Child_in_Iran" title="The Rights of the Child in Iran">for children</a>. It is also a focal point for <a href="/wiki/Shia_Islam" title="Shia Islam">Shia Islam</a> within the Middle East, countering the long-existing <a href="/wiki/Arabs" title="Arabs">Arab</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sunni_Islam" title="Sunni Islam">Sunni</a> hegemony within the region. Since the Iranian Revolution, the country is widely considered to be the <a href="/wiki/Iran%E2%80%93Israel_proxy_conflict" title="IranâIsrael proxy conflict">largest adversary of Israel</a> and <a href="/wiki/Iran%E2%80%93Saudi_Arabia_proxy_conflict" title="IranâSaudi Arabia proxy conflict">also of Saudi Arabia</a>. Iran is also considered to be one of the biggest players within Middle Eastern affairs, with its government being involved both directly and indirectly in the majority of <a href="/wiki/List_of_modern_conflicts_in_the_Middle_East" title="List of modern conflicts in the Middle East">modern Middle Eastern conflicts</a>.
</p><p>Iran is a <a href="/wiki/Regional_power" title="Regional power">regional</a> and <a href="/wiki/Middle_power" title="Middle power">middle power</a>, with a geopolitically strategic location in the <a href="/wiki/Asia" title="Asia">Asian continent</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-35"><a href="#cite_note-35">[34]</a></sup> It is a founding member of the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations" title="United Nations">United Nations</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Economic_Cooperation_Organization" title="Economic Cooperation Organization">ECO</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Organisation_of_Islamic_Cooperation" title="Organisation of Islamic Cooperation">OIC</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/OPEC" title="OPEC">OPEC</a>. It has large reserves of <a href="/wiki/Fossil_fuel" title="Fossil fuel">fossil fuels</a>âincluding the second-largest <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Natural_gas_reserves_in_Iran" title="Natural gas reserves in Iran">natural gas supply</a> and the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_proven_oil_reserves" title="List of countries by proven oil reserves">fourth-largest proven oil reserves</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-36"><a href="#cite_note-36">[35]</a></sup> The country's rich cultural legacy is reflected in part by its 26 <a href="/wiki/List_of_World_Heritage_Sites_in_Iran" title="List of World Heritage Sites in Iran">UNESCO World Heritage Sites</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-37"><a href="#cite_note-37">[36]</a></sup> Historically a multi-ethnic country, Iran remains a pluralistic society comprising <a href="/wiki/Demographics_of_Iran" title="Demographics of Iran">numerous ethnic, linguistic, and religious groups</a>, with the largest of these being <a href="/wiki/Persians" title="Persians">Persians</a>, <a href="/wiki/Azerbaijanis" title="Azerbaijanis">Azeris</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kurds" title="Kurds">Kurds</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mazanderani_people" title="Mazanderani people">Mazandaranis</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Lurs" title="Lurs">Lurs</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CIA_3-2"><a href="#cite_note-CIA-3">[3]</a></sup>
</p>

<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-19"><a href="#Government_and_politics"><span class="tocnumber">4</span> <span class="toctext">Government and politics</span></a>
<ul>
<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-20"><a href="#Supreme_Leader"><span class="tocnumber">4.1</span> <span class="toctext">Supreme Leader</span></a></li>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Name">Name</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Name_of_Iran" title="Name of Iran">Name of Iran</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Bas_relief_nagsh-e-rostam_couronnement.jpg"><img alt="Inscription of Ardeshir Babakan (ruling 224â242) in Naqsh-e Rostam" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1704" data-file-width="2272" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fb/Bas_relief_nagsh-e-rostam_couronnement.jpg/220px-Bas_relief_nagsh-e-rostam_couronnement.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fb/Bas_relief_nagsh-e-rostam_couronnement.jpg/330px-Bas_relief_nagsh-e-rostam_couronnement.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fb/Bas_relief_nagsh-e-rostam_couronnement.jpg/440px-Bas_relief_nagsh-e-rostam_couronnement.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Bas_relief_nagsh-e-rostam_couronnement.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Inscription of <a href="/wiki/Ardashir_I" title="Ardashir I">Ardeshir Babakan</a> (r. 224â242) in <a href="/wiki/Ahura_Mazda_and_Ardashir_I" title="Ahura Mazda and Ardashir I">Naqsh-e Rostam</a>: "This is the figure of Mazdaworshiper, the lord Ardashir, Shahanshah of <b>Iran</b>..."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-38"><a href="#cite_note-38">[37]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Coin_of_Nader_Shah,_minted_in_Shiraz.jpg"><img alt="An Ashrafi Coin of Nader Shah" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="394" data-file-width="800" decoding="async" height="108" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/08/Coin_of_Nader_Shah%2C_minted_in_Shiraz.jpg/220px-Coin_of_Nader_Shah%2C_minted_in_Shiraz.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/08/Coin_of_Nader_Shah%2C_minted_in_Shiraz.jpg/330px-Coin_of_Nader_Shah%2C_minted_in_Shiraz.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/08/Coin_of_Nader_Shah%2C_minted_in_Shiraz.jpg/440px-Coin_of_Nader_Shah%2C_minted_in_Shiraz.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Coin_of_Nader_Shah,_minted_in_Shiraz.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>An <a href="/wiki/Ashrafi" title="Ashrafi">Ashrafi</a> Coin of <a href="/wiki/Nader_Shah" title="Nader Shah">Nader Shah</a> (r. 1736â1747), reverse:"Coined on gold the word of kingdom in the world, Nader of <a href="/wiki/Greater_Iran" title="Greater Iran">Greater Iran</a> and the world-conquerer king."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-39"><a href="#cite_note-39">[38]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>The term <i><a href="/wiki/Iran_(word)" title="Iran (word)">Iran</a></i> derives directly from <a href="/wiki/Middle_Persian" title="Middle Persian">Middle Persian</a> <span title="Middle Persian-language romanization"><i lang="pal-Latn">ÄrÄn</i></span>, first attested in a third-century inscription at <a href="/wiki/Naqsh-e_Rostam" title="Naqsh-e Rostam">Naqsh-e Rostam</a>, with the accompanying <a href="/wiki/Parthian_language" title="Parthian language">Parthian</a> inscription using the term <span title="Parthian-language romanization"><i lang="xpr-Latn">AryÄn</i></span>, in reference to the <a href="/wiki/Iranian_peoples" title="Iranian peoples">Iranians</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MacKenzie_40-0"><a href="#cite_note-MacKenzie-40">[39]</a></sup> The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Middle_Iranian_language" title="Middle Iranian language">Middle Iranian</a> <i>ÄrÄn</i> and <i>aryÄn</i> are oblique plural forms of <a href="/wiki/Demonym" title="Demonym">gentilic</a> nouns <i>Är-</i> (Middle Persian) and <i>ary-</i> (Parthian), both deriving from <a href="/wiki/Proto-Iranian_language" title="Proto-Iranian language">Proto-Iranian language</a> <i>*arya-</i> (meaning "<a href="/wiki/Aryan" title="Aryan">Aryan</a>", i.e. "of the Iranians"),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MacKenzie_40-1"><a href="#cite_note-MacKenzie-40">[39]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Schmitt_Aryans1_41-0"><a href="#cite_note-Schmitt_Aryans1-41">[40]</a></sup> recognized as a derivative of <a href="/wiki/Proto-Indo-European_language" title="Proto-Indo-European language">Proto-Indo-European language</a> <i><span class="Unicode" style="white-space:nowrap;" title="Proto-Indo-European language"><span lang="ine">*ar-yo-</span></span></i>, meaning "one who assembles (skilfully)".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-42"><a href="#cite_note-42">[41]</a></sup> In the <a href="/wiki/Iranian_languages" title="Iranian languages">Iranian languages</a>, the gentilic is attested as a self-identifier, included in ancient inscriptions and the literature of the <a href="/wiki/Avesta" title="Avesta">Avesta</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bailey_Arya_43-0"><a href="#cite_note-Bailey_Arya-43">[42]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-44"><a href="#cite_note-44">[b]</a></sup> and remains also in other Iranian ethnic names <i><a href="/wiki/Alans" title="Alans">Alan</a></i> (<a href="/wiki/Ossetian_language" title="Ossetian language">Ossetian</a>: <span lang="os">ÐÑ</span> <span title="Ossetian-language romanization"><i lang="os-Latn">Ir</i></span>) and <i><a href="/wiki/Iron_people" title="Iron people">Iron</a></i> (<span title="Ossetian-language text"><span lang="os">ÐÑÐ¾Ð½</span></span>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Schmitt_Aryans1_41-1"><a href="#cite_note-Schmitt_Aryans1-41">[40]</a></sup> According to the Iranian mythology, the country's name comes from the name of <a href="/wiki/Iraj" title="Iraj">Iraj</a>, a legendary prince and shah who was killed by his brothers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Iranica_45-0"><a href="#cite_note-Iranica-45">[43]</a></sup>
Historically, Iran has been referred to as <i>Persia</i> by <a href="/wiki/Western_world" title="Western world">the West</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Fishman_14-1"><a href="#cite_note-Fishman-14">[13]</a></sup> due mainly to the writings of <a href="/wiki/Greeks" title="Greeks">Greek</a> historians who referred to all of Iran as <span title="Ancient Greek (to 1453)-language romanization"><i lang="grc-Latn">PersÃ­s</i></span> (<a href="/wiki/Ancient_Greek" title="Ancient Greek">Ancient Greek</a>: Î ÎµÏÏÎ¯Ï; from <a href="/wiki/Old_Persian" title="Old Persian">Old Persian</a> <span title="Old Persian (ca. 600-400 B.C.)-language text"><span lang="peo">ð±ð ð¼ð¿</span></span> <span title="Old Persian (ca. 600-400 B.C.)-language romanization"><i lang="peo-Latn">PÃ¢rsa</i></span>),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-46"><a href="#cite_note-46">[44]</a></sup> meaning "land of the <a href="/wiki/Persians" title="Persians">Persians</a>", while <a href="/wiki/Persis" title="Persis">Persis</a> itself was one of the provinces of ancient Iran that is today known as <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fars_Province" title="Fars Province">Fars</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Arnold_Wilson_47-0"><a href="#cite_note-Arnold_Wilson-47">[45]</a></sup> As the most extensive interaction the <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Greece" title="Ancient Greece">ancient Greeks</a> had with any outsider was with the Persians, the term persisted, even long after the <a href="/wiki/Greco-Persian_Wars" title="Greco-Persian Wars">Greco-Persian Wars</a> (499â449 BC).
</p><p>In 1935, <a href="/wiki/Reza_Shah" title="Reza Shah">Reza Shah</a> requested the international community to refer to the country by its native name, <i>Iran</i>, on <a href="/wiki/Nowruz" title="Nowruz">Nowruz</a>, falling on 21 March 1935 (Esfand 30, 1313), 4:43 pm Tehran time; effective 22 March (the Iranian New Year on Farvardin 1, 1314) that year.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-48"><a href="#cite_note-48">[46]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-49"><a href="#cite_note-49">[47]</a></sup> Opposition to the name change led to the reversal of the decision in 1959, and Professor <a href="/wiki/Ehsan_Yarshater" title="Ehsan Yarshater">Ehsan Yarshater</a>, editor of <i><a href="/wiki/Encyclop%C3%A6dia_Iranica" title="EncyclopÃ¦dia Iranica">EncyclopÃ¦dia Iranica</a></i>, propagated a move to use <i>Persia</i> and <i>Iran</i> interchangeably.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-50"><a href="#cite_note-50">[48]</a></sup> Today, both <i>Iran</i> and <i>Persia</i> are used in cultural contexts, while <i>Iran</i> remains mandatory in official state contexts.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-artarena_51-0"><a href="#cite_note-artarena-51">[49]</a></sup>
</p><p>Historical and cultural usage of the word <i>Iran</i> is not restricted to the modern state proper.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-52"><a href="#cite_note-52">[50]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-53"><a href="#cite_note-53">[51]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-54"><a href="#cite_note-54">[52]</a></sup> "<a href="/wiki/Greater_Iran" title="Greater Iran">Greater Iran</a>" (<i>IrÄnzamÄ«n</i> or <i>IrÄn e Bozorg</i>)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-55"><a href="#cite_note-55">[53]</a></sup> refers to territories of the Iranian cultural and linguistic zones. In addition to modern Iran, it includes portions of the <a href="/wiki/Caucasus" title="Caucasus">Caucasus</a>, <a href="/wiki/Anatolia" title="Anatolia">Anatolia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mesopotamia" title="Mesopotamia">Mesopotamia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Afghanistan" title="Afghanistan">Afghanistan</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Central_Asia" title="Central Asia">Central Asia</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-56"><a href="#cite_note-56">[54]</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources" title="Wikipedia:Citing sources"><span title="This citation requires a reference to the specific page or range of pages in which the material appears. (November 2020)">pageÂ needed</span></a></i>]</sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Pronunciation">Pronunciation</span></h3>
<p>The Persian pronunciation of <i>Iran</i> is <small></small><span class="IPA" lang="fa-Latn-fonipa" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/Persian" title="Help:IPA/Persian">[ÊiËËÉ¾ÉËn]</a></span>. Common <a href="/wiki/English_in_the_Commonwealth_of_Nations" title="English in the Commonwealth of Nations">Commonwealth English</a> pronunciations of <i>Iran</i> are listed in the <i><a href="/wiki/Oxford_English_Dictionary" title="Oxford English Dictionary">Oxford English Dictionary</a></i> as <span class="rt-commentedText nowrap"><span class="IPA nopopups noexcerpt" lang="en-fonipa"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/English" title="Help:IPA/English">/<span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="/Éª/: 'i' in 'kit'">Éª</span><span title="/Ë/: primary stress follows">Ë</span><span title="'r' in 'rye'">r</span><span title="/ÉË/: 'a' in 'father'">ÉË</span><span title="'n' in 'nigh'">n</span></span>/</a></span></span> and <span class="rt-commentedText nowrap"><span class="IPA nopopups noexcerpt" lang="en-fonipa"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/English" title="Help:IPA/English">/<span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="/Éª/: 'i' in 'kit'">Éª</span><span title="/Ë/: primary stress follows">Ë</span><span title="'r' in 'rye'">r</span><span title="/Ã¦/: 'a' in 'bad'">Ã¦</span><span title="'n' in 'nigh'">n</span></span>/</a></span></span>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Oxford_Iran_57-0"><a href="#cite_note-Oxford_Iran-57">[55]</a></sup> while <a href="/wiki/American_English" title="American English">American English</a> dictionaries such as <a href="/wiki/Merriam-Webster" title="Merriam-Webster">Merriam-Webster</a>'s provide pronunciations which map to <span class="rt-commentedText nowrap"><span class="IPA nopopups noexcerpt" lang="en-fonipa"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/English" title="Help:IPA/English">/<span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="/Éª/: 'i' in 'kit'">Éª</span><span title="/Ë/: primary stress follows">Ë</span><span title="'r' in 'rye'">r</span><span title="/ÉË/: 'a' in 'father'">ÉË</span><span title="'n' in 'nigh'">n</span></span>,<span class="wrap"> </span>-<span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="/Ë/: primary stress follows">Ë</span><span title="'r' in 'rye'">r</span><span title="/Ã¦/: 'a' in 'bad'">Ã¦</span><span title="'n' in 'nigh'">n</span></span>,<span class="wrap"> </span><span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="/aÉª/: 'i' in 'tide'">aÉª</span><span title="/Ë/: primary stress follows">Ë</span><span title="'r' in 'rye'">r</span><span title="/Ã¦/: 'a' in 'bad'">Ã¦</span><span title="'n' in 'nigh'">n</span></span>/</a></span></span>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MW_Iran_58-0"><a href="#cite_note-MW_Iran-58">[56]</a></sup> or likewise in <i><a href="/wiki/Random_House_Webster%27s_Unabridged_Dictionary" title="Random House Webster's Unabridged Dictionary">Random House Webster's Unabridged Dictionary</a></i> as <span class="rt-commentedText nowrap"><span class="IPA nopopups noexcerpt" lang="en-fonipa"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/English" title="Help:IPA/English">/<span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="/Éª/: 'i' in 'kit'">Éª</span><span title="/Ë/: primary stress follows">Ë</span><span title="'r' in 'rye'">r</span><span title="/Ã¦/: 'a' in 'bad'">Ã¦</span><span title="'n' in 'nigh'">n</span></span>,<span class="wrap"> </span><span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="/Éª/: 'i' in 'kit'">Éª</span><span title="/Ë/: primary stress follows">Ë</span><span title="'r' in 'rye'">r</span><span title="/ÉË/: 'a' in 'father'">ÉË</span><span title="'n' in 'nigh'">n</span></span>,<span class="wrap"> </span><span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="/aÉª/: 'i' in 'tide'">aÉª</span><span title="/Ë/: primary stress follows">Ë</span><span title="'r' in 'rye'">r</span><span title="/Ã¦/: 'a' in 'bad'">Ã¦</span><span title="'n' in 'nigh'">n</span></span>/</a></span></span>. The <i><a href="/wiki/Cambridge_Advanced_Learner%27s_Dictionary" title="Cambridge Advanced Learner's Dictionary">Cambridge Dictionary</a></i> lists <span class="rt-commentedText nowrap"><span class="IPA nopopups noexcerpt" lang="en-fonipa"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/English" title="Help:IPA/English">/<span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="/Éª/: 'i' in 'kit'">Éª</span><span title="/Ë/: primary stress follows">Ë</span><span title="'r' in 'rye'">r</span><span title="/ÉË/: 'a' in 'father'">ÉË</span><span title="'n' in 'nigh'">n</span></span>/</a></span></span> as the British pronunciation and <span class="rt-commentedText nowrap"><span class="IPA nopopups noexcerpt" lang="en-fonipa"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/English" title="Help:IPA/English">/<span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="/Éª/: 'i' in 'kit'">Éª</span><span title="/Ë/: primary stress follows">Ë</span><span title="'r' in 'rye'">r</span><span title="/Ã¦/: 'a' in 'bad'">Ã¦</span><span title="'n' in 'nigh'">n</span></span>/</a></span></span> as the American pronunciation. Similarly, Glasgow-based <i><a href="/wiki/Collins_English_Dictionary" title="Collins English Dictionary">Collins English Dictionary</a></i> provides both <a href="/wiki/English_language_in_England" title="English language in England">English English</a> and American English pronunciations. The pronunciation guide from <a href="/wiki/Voice_of_America" title="Voice of America">Voice of America</a> also provides <span class="rt-commentedText nowrap"><span class="IPA nopopups noexcerpt" lang="en-fonipa"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/English" title="Help:IPA/English">/<span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="/Éª/: 'i' in 'kit'">Éª</span><span title="/Ë/: primary stress follows">Ë</span><span title="'r' in 'rye'">r</span><span title="/ÉË/: 'a' in 'father'">ÉË</span><span title="'n' in 'nigh'">n</span></span>/</a></span></span>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-59"><a href="#cite_note-59">[57]</a></sup>
</p><p>The American English pronunciation <span class="rt-commentedText nowrap"><span class="IPA nopopups noexcerpt" lang="en-fonipa"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/English" title="Help:IPA/English">/<span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="/aÉª/: 'i' in 'tide'">aÉª</span><span title="/Ë/: primary stress follows">Ë</span><span title="'r' in 'rye'">r</span><span title="/Ã¦/: 'a' in 'bad'">Ã¦</span><span title="'n' in 'nigh'">n</span></span>/</a></span></span> may be heard in U.S. media. Max Fisher in <i><a href="/wiki/The_Washington_Post" title="The Washington Post">The Washington Post</a></i><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-60"><a href="#cite_note-60">[58]</a></sup> prescribed <span class="rt-commentedText nowrap"><span class="IPA nopopups noexcerpt" lang="en-fonipa"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/English" title="Help:IPA/English">/<span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="/iË/: 'ee' in 'fleece'">iË</span><span title="/Ë/: primary stress follows">Ë</span><span title="'r' in 'rye'">r</span><span title="/ÉË/: 'a' in 'father'">ÉË</span><span title="'n' in 'nigh'">n</span></span>/</a></span></span> for <i>Iran</i>, while proscribing <span class="rt-commentedText nowrap"><span class="IPA nopopups noexcerpt" lang="en-fonipa"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/English" title="Help:IPA/English">/<span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="/aÉª/: 'i' in 'tide'">aÉª</span><span title="/Ë/: primary stress follows">Ë</span><span title="'r' in 'rye'">r</span><span title="/Ã¦/: 'a' in 'bad'">Ã¦</span><span title="'n' in 'nigh'">n</span></span>/</a></span></span>. <i><a href="/wiki/The_American_Heritage_Dictionary_of_the_English_Language" title="The American Heritage Dictionary of the English Language">The American Heritage Dictionary of the English Language</a></i>, in the dictionary's 2014 Usage Ballot, addressed the topic of the pronunciations of Iran and Iraq.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-61"><a href="#cite_note-61">[59]</a></sup> According to this survey, the pronunciations <span class="rt-commentedText nowrap"><span class="IPA nopopups noexcerpt" lang="en-fonipa"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/English" title="Help:IPA/English">/<span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="/Éª/: 'i' in 'kit'">Éª</span><span title="/Ë/: primary stress follows">Ë</span><span title="'r' in 'rye'">r</span><span title="/ÉË/: 'a' in 'father'">ÉË</span><span title="'n' in 'nigh'">n</span></span>/</a></span></span> and <span class="rt-commentedText nowrap"><span class="IPA nopopups noexcerpt" lang="en-fonipa"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/English" title="Help:IPA/English">/<span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="/Éª/: 'i' in 'kit'">Éª</span><span title="/Ë/: primary stress follows">Ë</span><span title="'r' in 'rye'">r</span><span title="/Ã¦/: 'a' in 'bad'">Ã¦</span><span title="'n' in 'nigh'">n</span></span>/</a></span></span> were deemed almost equally acceptable, while <span class="rt-commentedText nowrap"><span class="IPA nopopups noexcerpt" lang="en-fonipa"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/English" title="Help:IPA/English">/<span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="/Éª/: 'i' in 'kit'">Éª</span><span title="/Ë/: primary stress follows">Ë</span><span title="'r' in 'rye'">r</span><span title="/ÉË/: 'a' in 'father'">ÉË</span><span title="'n' in 'nigh'">n</span></span>/</a></span></span> was preferred by most panelists participating in the ballot. With regard to the <span class="rt-commentedText nowrap"><span class="IPA nopopups noexcerpt" lang="en-fonipa"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/English" title="Help:IPA/English">/<span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="/aÉª/: 'i' in 'tide'">aÉª</span><span title="/Ë/: primary stress follows">Ë</span><span title="'r' in 'rye'">r</span><span title="/Ã¦/: 'a' in 'bad'">Ã¦</span><span title="'n' in 'nigh'">n</span></span>/</a></span></span> pronunciation, more than 70% of the panelists deemed it unacceptable. Among the reasons given by those panelists were that <span class="rt-commentedText nowrap"><span class="IPA nopopups noexcerpt" lang="en-fonipa"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/English" title="Help:IPA/English">/<span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="/aÉª/: 'i' in 'tide'">aÉª</span><span title="/Ë/: primary stress follows">Ë</span><span title="'r' in 'rye'">r</span><span title="/Ã¦/: 'a' in 'bad'">Ã¦</span><span title="'n' in 'nigh'">n</span></span>/</a></span></span> has "hawkish connotations" and sounds "angrier", "xenophobic", "ignorant", and "not<span class="nowrap">Â </span>... cosmopolitan". The <span class="rt-commentedText nowrap"><span class="IPA nopopups noexcerpt" lang="en-fonipa"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/English" title="Help:IPA/English">/<span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="/aÉª/: 'i' in 'tide'">aÉª</span><span title="/Ë/: primary stress follows">Ë</span><span title="'r' in 'rye'">r</span><span title="/Ã¦/: 'a' in 'bad'">Ã¦</span><span title="'n' in 'nigh'">n</span></span>/</a></span></span> pronunciation remains standard and acceptable, reflected in the entry for <i>Iran</i> in the American Heritage Dictionary itself, as well as in each of the other major dictionaries of American English.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/History_of_Iran" title="History of Iran">History of Iran</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">For a chronological guide, see <a href="/wiki/Timeline_of_Iranian_history" title="Timeline of Iranian history">Timeline of Iranian history</a>.</div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Prehistory">Prehistory</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Prehistory_of_Iran" title="Prehistory of Iran">Prehistory of Iran</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Archaeological_sites_in_Iran" title="Archaeological sites in Iran">Archaeological sites in Iran</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Cave_painting_in_Doushe_cave,_Lorstan,_Iran,_8th_millennium_BC.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="330" data-file-width="486" decoding="async" height="149" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4a/Cave_painting_in_Doushe_cave%2C_Lorstan%2C_Iran%2C_8th_millennium_BC.JPG/220px-Cave_painting_in_Doushe_cave%2C_Lorstan%2C_Iran%2C_8th_millennium_BC.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4a/Cave_painting_in_Doushe_cave%2C_Lorstan%2C_Iran%2C_8th_millennium_BC.JPG/330px-Cave_painting_in_Doushe_cave%2C_Lorstan%2C_Iran%2C_8th_millennium_BC.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4a/Cave_painting_in_Doushe_cave%2C_Lorstan%2C_Iran%2C_8th_millennium_BC.JPG/440px-Cave_painting_in_Doushe_cave%2C_Lorstan%2C_Iran%2C_8th_millennium_BC.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Cave_painting_in_Doushe_cave,_Lorstan,_Iran,_8th_millennium_BC.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A <a href="/wiki/Cave_painting" title="Cave painting">cave painting</a> in Doushe cave, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Lorestan_Province" title="Lorestan Province">Lorestan</a>, from the eighth millennium BC<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-62"><a href="#cite_note-62">[60]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>The earliest attested archaeological artifacts in Iran, like those excavated at <a href="/wiki/Kashafrud" title="Kashafrud">Kashafrud</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ganj_Par" title="Ganj Par">Ganj Par</a> in northern Iran, confirm a human presence in Iran since the <a href="/wiki/Lower_Paleolithic" title="Lower Paleolithic">Lower Paleolithic</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-63"><a href="#cite_note-63">[61]</a></sup> Iran's <a href="/wiki/Neanderthal" title="Neanderthal">Neanderthal</a> artifacts from the <a href="/wiki/Middle_Paleolithic" title="Middle Paleolithic">Middle Paleolithic</a> have been found mainly in the <a href="/wiki/Zagros_Mountains" title="Zagros Mountains">Zagros</a> region, at sites such as <a href="/wiki/Warwasi" title="Warwasi">Warwasi</a> and <a href="/wiki/Yafteh" title="Yafteh">Yafteh</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Museum_64-0"><a href="#cite_note-Museum-64">[62]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-65"><a href="#cite_note-65">[63]</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources" title="Wikipedia:Citing sources"><span title="This citation requires a reference to the specific page or range of pages in which the material appears. (July 2013)">pageÂ needed</span></a></i>]</sup> From the tenth to the seventh millennium BC, early agricultural communities began to flourish in and around the Zagros region in western Iran, including <a href="/wiki/Chogha_Golan" title="Chogha Golan">Chogha Golan</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-66"><a href="#cite_note-66">[64]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-67"><a href="#cite_note-67">[65]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Chogha_Bonut" title="Chogha Bonut">Chogha Bonut</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-68"><a href="#cite_note-68">[66]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-69"><a href="#cite_note-69">[67]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Chogha_Mish" title="Chogha Mish">Chogha Mish</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-70"><a href="#cite_note-70">[68]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-71"><a href="#cite_note-71">[69]</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources" title="Wikipedia:Citing sources"><span title="This citation requires a reference to the specific page or range of pages in which the material appears. (July 2013)">pageÂ needed</span></a></i>]</sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-xinhuaciv_72-0"><a href="#cite_note-xinhuaciv-72">[70]</a></sup>
</p><p>The occupation of grouped hamlets in the area of <a href="/wiki/Susa" title="Susa">Susa</a>, as determined by <a href="/wiki/Radiocarbon_dating" title="Radiocarbon dating">radiocarbon dating</a>, ranges from 4395â3955 to 3680â3490 BC.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-73"><a href="#cite_note-73">[71]</a></sup> There are dozens of prehistoric sites across the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Iranian_Plateau" title="Iranian Plateau">Iranian Plateau</a>, pointing to the existence of ancient cultures and urban settlements in the fourth millennium BC.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-xinhuaciv_72-1"><a href="#cite_note-xinhuaciv-72">[70]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-iran-daily_74-0"><a href="#cite_note-iran-daily-74">[72]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-iranian.ws_75-0"><a href="#cite_note-iranian.ws-75">[73]</a></sup> During the <a href="/wiki/Bronze_Age" title="Bronze Age">Bronze Age</a>, the territory of present-day Iran was home to several civilizations, including <a href="/wiki/Elam" title="Elam">Elam</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jiroft_culture" title="Jiroft culture">Jiroft</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Zayandeh_River_Culture" title="Zayandeh River Culture">Zayanderud</a>. Elam, the most prominent of these civilizations, developed in the southwest alongside those in <a href="/wiki/Mesopotamia" title="Mesopotamia">Mesopotamia</a>, and continued its existence until the emergence of the Iranian empires. The advent of writing in Elam was paralleled to <a href="/wiki/Sumerian_language#Writing_system" title="Sumerian language">Sumer</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Elamite_cuneiform" title="Elamite cuneiform">Elamite cuneiform</a> was developed since the third millennium BC.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-76"><a href="#cite_note-76">[74]</a></sup>
</p><p>From the 34th to the 20th century BC, northwestern Iran was part of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kura-Araxes_culture" title="Kura-Araxes culture">Kura-Araxes culture</a>, which stretched into the neighboring <a href="/wiki/Caucasus" title="Caucasus">Caucasus</a> and <a href="/wiki/Anatolia" title="Anatolia">Anatolia</a>. Since the earliest second millennium BC, <a href="/wiki/Assyria" title="Assyria">Assyrians</a> settled in swaths of western Iran and incorporated the region into their territories.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Classical_antiquity">Classical antiquity</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Medes" title="Medes">Median Empire</a>, <a href="/wiki/Achaemenid_Empire" title="Achaemenid Empire">Achaemenid Empire</a>, <a href="/wiki/Seleucid_Empire" title="Seleucid Empire">Seleucid Empire</a>, <a href="/wiki/Parthian_Empire" title="Parthian Empire">Parthian Empire</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Sasanian_Empire" title="Sasanian Empire">Sasanian Empire</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Indo-European_migrations" title="Indo-European migrations">Indo-European migrations</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Medes_and_Persians_at_eastern_stairs_of_the_Apadana,_Persepolis.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3072" data-file-width="4608" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/09/Medes_and_Persians_at_eastern_stairs_of_the_Apadana%2C_Persepolis.JPG/220px-Medes_and_Persians_at_eastern_stairs_of_the_Apadana%2C_Persepolis.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/09/Medes_and_Persians_at_eastern_stairs_of_the_Apadana%2C_Persepolis.JPG/330px-Medes_and_Persians_at_eastern_stairs_of_the_Apadana%2C_Persepolis.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/09/Medes_and_Persians_at_eastern_stairs_of_the_Apadana%2C_Persepolis.JPG/440px-Medes_and_Persians_at_eastern_stairs_of_the_Apadana%2C_Persepolis.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Medes_and_Persians_at_eastern_stairs_of_the_Apadana,_Persepolis.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A <a href="/wiki/Relief#Bas-relief_or_low_relief" title="Relief">bas-relief</a> at <a href="/wiki/Persepolis" title="Persepolis">Persepolis</a>, depicting the united <a href="/wiki/Medes" title="Medes">Medes</a> and <a href="/wiki/Persians" title="Persians">Persians</a></div></div></div>
<p>By the second millennium BC, the <a href="/wiki/List_of_ancient_Iranian_peoples" title="List of ancient Iranian peoples">ancient Iranian peoples</a> arrived in what is now Iran from the <a href="/wiki/Eurasian_Steppe" title="Eurasian Steppe">Eurasian Steppe</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-77"><a href="#cite_note-77">[75]</a></sup> rivaling the native settlers of the region.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Panshin_78-0"><a href="#cite_note-Panshin-78">[76]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-79"><a href="#cite_note-79">[77]</a></sup> As the <a href="/wiki/Iranian_peoples" title="Iranian peoples">Iranians</a> dispersed into the wider area of <a href="/wiki/Greater_Iran" title="Greater Iran">Greater Iran</a> and beyond, the boundaries of modern-day Iran were dominated by <a href="/wiki/Medes" title="Medes">Median</a>, <a href="/wiki/Persians" title="Persians">Persian</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Parthia" title="Parthia">Parthian</a> tribes.
</p><p>From the late tenth to the late seventh century BC, the Iranian peoples, together with the "pre-Iranian" kingdoms, fell under the domination of the <a href="/wiki/Assyria" title="Assyria">Assyrian</a> Empire, based in northern <a href="/wiki/Mesopotamia" title="Mesopotamia">Mesopotamia</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Georges_Roux_â_Ancient_Iraq_80-0"><a href="#cite_note-Georges_Roux_â_Ancient_Iraq-80">[78]</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources" title="Wikipedia:Citing sources"><span title="This citation requires a reference to the specific page or range of pages in which the material appears. (November 2020)">pageÂ needed</span></a></i>]</sup> Under king <a href="/wiki/Cyaxares" title="Cyaxares">Cyaxares</a>, the Medes and Persians entered into an alliance with <a href="/wiki/Babylonia" title="Babylonia">Babylonian</a> ruler <a href="/wiki/Nabopolassar" title="Nabopolassar">Nabopolassar</a>, as well as the fellow Iranian <a href="/wiki/Scythians" title="Scythians">Scythians</a> and <a href="/wiki/Cimmerians" title="Cimmerians">Cimmerians</a>, and together they attacked the Assyrian Empire. The civil war ravaged the Assyrian Empire between 616 and 605Â BC, thus freeing their respective peoples from three centuries of Assyrian rule.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Georges_Roux_â_Ancient_Iraq_80-1"><a href="#cite_note-Georges_Roux_â_Ancient_Iraq-80">[78]</a></sup> The unification of the Median tribes under king <a href="/wiki/Deioces" title="Deioces">Deioces</a> in 728Â BC led to the foundation of the Median Empire which, by 612Â BC, controlled almost the entire territory of present-day Iran and eastern <a href="/wiki/Anatolia" title="Anatolia">Anatolia</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-81"><a href="#cite_note-81">[79]</a></sup> This marked the end of the Kingdom of <a href="/wiki/Urartu" title="Urartu">Urartu</a> as well, which was subsequently conquered and dissolved.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Sagona2006_82-0"><a href="#cite_note-Sagona2006-82">[80]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-83"><a href="#cite_note-83">[81]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Pasargad_Tomb_Cyrus3.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="4000" data-file-width="5996" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/51/Pasargad_Tomb_Cyrus3.jpg/220px-Pasargad_Tomb_Cyrus3.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/51/Pasargad_Tomb_Cyrus3.jpg/330px-Pasargad_Tomb_Cyrus3.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/51/Pasargad_Tomb_Cyrus3.jpg/440px-Pasargad_Tomb_Cyrus3.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Pasargad_Tomb_Cyrus3.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Tomb_of_Cyrus" title="Tomb of Cyrus">Tomb of Cyrus</a> the Great, founder of the <a href="/wiki/Achaemenid_Empire" title="Achaemenid Empire">Achaemenid Empire</a>, in <a href="/wiki/Pasargadae" title="Pasargadae">Pasargadae</a></div></div></div>
<p>In 550Â BC, <a href="/wiki/Cyrus_the_Great" title="Cyrus the Great">Cyrus the Great</a>, the son of <a href="/wiki/Mandane_of_Media" title="Mandane of Media">Mandane</a> and <a href="/wiki/Cambyses_I" title="Cambyses I">Cambyses I</a>, took over the Median Empire, and founded the <a href="/wiki/Achaemenid_Empire" title="Achaemenid Empire">Achaemenid Empire</a> by unifying other city-states. The conquest of Media was a result of what is called the <i><a href="/wiki/Persian_Revolt" title="Persian Revolt">Persian Revolt</a></i>. The <a href="/wiki/Brouhaha" title="Brouhaha">brouhaha</a> was initially triggered by the actions of the Median ruler <a href="/wiki/Astyages" title="Astyages">Astyages</a>, and was quickly spread to other provinces as they allied with the Persians. Later conquests under Cyrus and his successors expanded the empire to include <a href="/wiki/Lydia" title="Lydia">Lydia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Babylon" title="Babylon">Babylon</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Egypt" title="Ancient Egypt">Egypt</a>, parts of the <a href="/wiki/Balkans" title="Balkans">Balkans</a> and <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Europe" title="Eastern Europe">Eastern Europe</a> proper, as well as the lands to the west of the <a href="/wiki/Indus_River" title="Indus River">Indus</a> and <a href="/wiki/Amu_Darya" title="Amu Darya">Oxus</a> rivers.
</p><p>539 BC was the year in which Persian forces defeated the Babylonian army at <a href="/wiki/Opis" title="Opis">Opis</a>, and marked the end of around four centuries of Mesopotamian domination of the region by conquering the <a href="/wiki/Neo-Babylonian_Empire" title="Neo-Babylonian Empire">Neo-Babylonian Empire</a>. Cyrus entered Babylon and presented himself as a traditional Mesopotamian monarch. Subsequent Achaemenid art and iconography reflect the influence of the new political reality in Mesopotamia.
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Achaemenid_Empire_(flat_map).svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="442" data-file-width="672" decoding="async" height="145" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ed/Achaemenid_Empire_%28flat_map%29.svg/220px-Achaemenid_Empire_%28flat_map%29.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ed/Achaemenid_Empire_%28flat_map%29.svg/330px-Achaemenid_Empire_%28flat_map%29.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ed/Achaemenid_Empire_%28flat_map%29.svg/440px-Achaemenid_Empire_%28flat_map%29.svg.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Achaemenid_Empire_(flat_map).svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Achaemenid_Empire" title="Achaemenid Empire">Achaemenid Empire</a> (550 BCâ330 BC) around the time of <a href="/wiki/Darius_the_Great" title="Darius the Great">Darius the Great</a> and <a href="/wiki/Xerxes_I" title="Xerxes I">Xerxes I</a></div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Map_of_the_Parthian_Empire_under_Mithridates_II.svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1217" data-file-width="2187" decoding="async" height="122" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5d/Map_of_the_Parthian_Empire_under_Mithridates_II.svg/220px-Map_of_the_Parthian_Empire_under_Mithridates_II.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5d/Map_of_the_Parthian_Empire_under_Mithridates_II.svg/330px-Map_of_the_Parthian_Empire_under_Mithridates_II.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5d/Map_of_the_Parthian_Empire_under_Mithridates_II.svg/440px-Map_of_the_Parthian_Empire_under_Mithridates_II.svg.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Map_of_the_Parthian_Empire_under_Mithridates_II.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Parthian_Empire" title="Parthian Empire">Parthian Empire</a> (247 BCâ224 AD) in 94 BC at its greatest extent, during the reign of Mithridates II</div></div></div>
<p>At its greatest extent, the Achaemenid Empire included territories of modern-day Iran, Republic of <a href="/wiki/Azerbaijan" title="Azerbaijan">Azerbaijan</a> (<a href="/wiki/Arran_(Caucasus)" title="Arran (Caucasus)">Arran</a> and <a href="/wiki/Shirvan" title="Shirvan">Shirvan</a>), <a href="/wiki/Armenia" title="Armenia">Armenia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Georgia_(country)" title="Georgia (country)">Georgia</a>, Turkey (<a href="/wiki/Classical_Anatolia" title="Classical Anatolia">Anatolia</a>), much of the <a href="/wiki/Black_Sea" title="Black Sea">Black Sea</a> coastal regions, northeastern Greece and southern <a href="/wiki/Bulgaria" title="Bulgaria">Bulgaria</a> (<a href="/wiki/Thrace" title="Thrace">Thrace</a>), northern Greece and <a href="/wiki/North_Macedonia" title="North Macedonia">North Macedonia</a> (<a href="/wiki/Paeonia_(kingdom)" title="Paeonia (kingdom)">Paeonia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Macedonia_(ancient_kingdom)" title="Macedonia (ancient kingdom)">Macedon</a>), <a href="/wiki/Iraq" title="Iraq">Iraq</a>, <a href="/wiki/Syria" title="Syria">Syria</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lebanon" title="Lebanon">Lebanon</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jordan" title="Jordan">Jordan</a>, Israel and the <a href="/wiki/Palestinian_territories" title="Palestinian territories">Palestinian territories</a>, all significant population centers of <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Egypt" title="Ancient Egypt">ancient Egypt</a> as far west as <a href="/wiki/Libya" title="Libya">Libya</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kuwait" title="Kuwait">Kuwait</a>, northern <a href="/wiki/Saudi_Arabia" title="Saudi Arabia">Saudi Arabia</a>, parts of the <a href="/wiki/United_Arab_Emirates" title="United Arab Emirates">United Arab Emirates</a> and <a href="/wiki/Oman" title="Oman">Oman</a>, Pakistan, Afghanistan, and much of <a href="/wiki/Central_Asia" title="Central Asia">Central Asia</a>, making it the largest empire the world had yet seen.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-book_20-1"><a href="#cite_note-book-20">[19]</a></sup>
</p><p>It is estimated that in 480 BC, 50 million people lived in the Achaemenid Empire.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-1996,_p._47_84-0"><a href="#cite_note-1996,_p._47-84">[82]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Cook_85-0"><a href="#cite_note-Cook-85">[83]</a></sup> The empire at its peak ruled over 44% of the world's population, the highest such figure for any empire in history.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-86"><a href="#cite_note-86">[84]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Achaemenid Empire is noted for the release of the <a href="/wiki/Babylonian_captivity" title="Babylonian captivity">Jewish exiles in Babylon</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-87"><a href="#cite_note-87">[85]</a></sup> building infrastructures such as the <a href="/wiki/Royal_Road" title="Royal Road">Royal Road</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Chapar_Khaneh" title="Chapar Khaneh">Chapar</a> (postal service), and the use of an <a href="/wiki/Official_language" title="Official language">official language</a>, <a href="/wiki/Old_Aramaic#Imperial_Aramaic" title="Old Aramaic">Imperial Aramaic</a>, throughout its territories.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-book_20-2"><a href="#cite_note-book-20">[19]</a></sup> The empire had a centralized, bureaucratic administration under the emperor, a large professional army, and civil services, inspiring similar developments in later empires.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-88"><a href="#cite_note-88">[86]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-schmitt-EI-i_89-0"><a href="#cite_note-schmitt-EI-i-89">[87]</a></sup>
</p><p>Eventual conflict on the western borders began with the <a href="/wiki/Ionian_Revolt" title="Ionian Revolt">Ionian Revolt</a>, which erupted into the <a href="/wiki/Greco-Persian_Wars" title="Greco-Persian Wars">Greco-Persian Wars</a> and continued through the first half of the fifth century BC, and ended with the withdrawal of the Achaemenids from all of the territories in the <a href="/wiki/Balkans" title="Balkans">Balkans</a> and <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Europe" title="Eastern Europe">Eastern Europe</a> proper.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERoismanWorthington2011135â138,_342â345_90-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERoismanWorthington2011135â138,_342â345-90">[88]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 334Â BC, <a href="/wiki/Alexander_the_Great" title="Alexander the Great">Alexander the Great</a> invaded the Achaemenid Empire, defeating the last Achaemenid emperor, <a href="/wiki/Darius_III" title="Darius III">Darius III</a>, at the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Issus" title="Battle of Issus">Battle of Issus</a>. Following the premature death of Alexander, Iran came under the control of the <a href="/wiki/Hellenistic_period" title="Hellenistic period">Hellenistic</a> <a href="/wiki/Seleucid_Empire" title="Seleucid Empire">Seleucid Empire</a>. In the middle of the second century BC, the <a href="/wiki/Parthian_Empire" title="Parthian Empire">Parthian Empire</a> rose to become the main power in Iran, and the century-long geopolitical arch-rivalry between the Romans and the Parthians began, culminating in the <a href="/wiki/Roman%E2%80%93Parthian_Wars" title="RomanâParthian Wars">RomanâParthian Wars</a>. The Parthian Empire continued as a feudal monarchy for nearly five centuries, until 224Â CE, when it was succeeded by the <a href="/wiki/Sasanian_Empire" title="Sasanian Empire">Sasanian Empire</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-91"><a href="#cite_note-91">[89]</a></sup> Together with their neighboring arch-rival, the <a href="/wiki/Roman_Empire" title="Roman Empire">Roman</a>-<a href="/wiki/Byzantine_Empire" title="Byzantine Empire">Byzantines</a>, they made up the world's two most dominant powers at the time, for over four centuries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Norman_A._Stillman_p._22_21-1"><a href="#cite_note-Norman_A._Stillman_p._22-21">[20]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Byzantine_Studies_2006,_p._29_22-1"><a href="#cite_note-Byzantine_Studies_2006,_p._29-22">[21]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Sasanians established an empire within the frontiers achieved by the Achaemenids, with their capital at <a href="/wiki/Ctesiphon" title="Ctesiphon">Ctesiphon</a>. Late antiquity is considered one of Iran's most influential periods, as under the Sasanians their influence reached the <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_ancient_Rome" title="Culture of ancient Rome">culture of ancient Rome</a> (and through that as far as <a href="/wiki/Western_Europe" title="Western Europe">Western Europe</a>),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-J._B._Bury,_p._109_92-0"><a href="#cite_note-J._B._Bury,_p._109-92">[90]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-93"><a href="#cite_note-93">[91]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_Africa" title="Culture of Africa">Africa</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-94"><a href="#cite_note-94">[92]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Chinese_culture" title="Chinese culture">China</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_India" title="Culture of India">India</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-95"><a href="#cite_note-95">[93]</a></sup> and played a prominent role in the formation of the medieval art of both <a href="/wiki/Medieval_art" title="Medieval art">Europe</a> and <a href="/wiki/History_of_Asian_art" title="History of Asian art">Asia</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Iransaga:_The_art_of_Sassanians_96-0"><a href="#cite_note-Iransaga:_The_art_of_Sassanians-96">[94]</a></sup>
</p><p>Most of the era of the Sasanian Empire was overshadowed by the <a href="/wiki/Roman%E2%80%93Persian_Wars" title="RomanâPersian Wars">RomanâPersian Wars</a>, which raged on the western borders at Anatolia, the <a href="/wiki/Western_Caucasus" title="Western Caucasus">Western Caucasus</a>, Mesopotamia, and the <a href="/wiki/Levant" title="Levant">Levant</a>, for over 700 years. These wars ultimately exhausted both the Romans and the Sasanians and led to the defeat of both by the Muslim invasion.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (November 2020)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup>
</p><p>Throughout the Achaemenid, Parthian, and Sasanian eras, several offshoots of the Iranian dynasties established <a href="/wiki/Eponym" title="Eponym">eponymous</a> branches in Anatolia and the Caucasus, including the <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Pontus" title="Kingdom of Pontus">Pontic Kingdom</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Mihranids" title="Mihranids">Mihranids</a>, and the Arsacid dynasties of <a href="/wiki/Arsacid_dynasty_of_Armenia" title="Arsacid dynasty of Armenia">Armenia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Arsacid_dynasty_of_Iberia" title="Arsacid dynasty of Iberia">Iberia</a> (<a href="/wiki/Georgia_(country)" title="Georgia (country)">Georgia</a>), and <a href="/wiki/Arsacid_dynasty_of_Caucasian_Albania" title="Arsacid dynasty of Caucasian Albania">Caucasian Albania</a> (present-day Republic of <a href="/wiki/Azerbaijan" title="Azerbaijan">Azerbaijan</a> and southern <a href="/wiki/Dagestan" title="Dagestan">Dagestan</a>).<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (November 2020)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Medieval_period">Medieval period</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Muslim_conquest_of_Persia" title="Muslim conquest of Persia">Muslim conquest of Persia</a> and <a href="/wiki/History_of_Iran#Medieval_period" title="History of Iran">Medieval Iran</a></div>
<p>The prolonged <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Byzantine%E2%80%93Sasanian_wars" title="ByzantineâSasanian wars">ByzantineâSasanian wars</a>, most importantly the climactic <a href="/wiki/Byzantine%E2%80%93Sasanian_War_of_602%E2%80%93628" title="ByzantineâSasanian War of 602â628">war of 602â628</a>, as well as the <a href="/wiki/Muslim_conquest_of_Persia#Social_problems" title="Muslim conquest of Persia">social conflict within the Sasanian Empire</a>, opened the way for an Arab invasion of Iran in the seventh century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-97"><a href="#cite_note-97">[95]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-98"><a href="#cite_note-98">[96]</a></sup> The empire was initially defeated by the <a href="/wiki/Rashidun_Caliphate" title="Rashidun Caliphate">Rashidun Caliphate</a>, which was succeeded by the <a href="/wiki/Umayyad_Caliphate" title="Umayyad Caliphate">Umayyad Caliphate</a>, followed by the <a href="/wiki/Abbasid_Caliphate" title="Abbasid Caliphate">Abbasid Caliphate</a>. A prolonged and gradual process of state-imposed <a href="/wiki/Islamization_of_Iran" title="Islamization of Iran">Islamization</a> followed, which targeted Iran's then Zoroastrian majority and included religious persecution,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-99"><a href="#cite_note-99">[97]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-100"><a href="#cite_note-100">[98]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-101"><a href="#cite_note-101">[99]</a></sup> demolition of libraries<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bbc_102-0"><a href="#cite_note-bbc-102">[100]</a></sup> and fire temples,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-khan29_103-0"><a href="#cite_note-khan29-103">[101]</a></sup> a special tax penalty ("<a href="/wiki/Jizya" title="Jizya">jizya</a>"),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Hashemi2008_104-0"><a href="#cite_note-Hashemi2008-104">[102]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-105"><a href="#cite_note-105">[103]</a></sup> and language shift.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-106"><a href="#cite_note-106">[104]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-107"><a href="#cite_note-107">[105]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 750, the Abbasids overthrew the Umayyads.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-108"><a href="#cite_note-108">[106]</a></sup> Arabs Muslims and Persians of all strata made up the rebel army, which was united by the converted Persian Muslim, <a href="/wiki/Abu_Muslim" title="Abu Muslim">Abu Muslim</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-wsu_109-0"><a href="#cite_note-wsu-109">[107]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-110"><a href="#cite_note-110">[108]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-111"><a href="#cite_note-111">[109]</a></sup> In their struggle for power, the society in their times gradually became cosmopolitan and the old Arab simplicity and aristocratic dignity, bearing and prestige were lost. Persians and Turks began to replace the Arabs in most fields. The fusion of the Arab nobility with the subject races, the practice of polygamy and concubinage, made for a social amalgam wherein loyalties became uncertain and a hierarchy of officials emerged, a bureaucracy at first Persian and later Turkish which decreased Abbasid prestige and power for good.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Mahmud1988_112-0"><a href="#cite_note-Mahmud1988-112">[110]</a></sup>
</p><p>After two centuries of Arab rule, semi-independent and independent Iranian kingdomsâincluding the <a href="/wiki/Tahirid_dynasty" title="Tahirid dynasty">Tahirids</a>, <a href="/wiki/Saffarid_dynasty" title="Saffarid dynasty">Saffarids</a>, <a href="/wiki/Samanid_Empire" title="Samanid Empire">Samanids</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Buyid_dynasty" title="Buyid dynasty">Buyids</a>âbegan to appear on the fringes of the declining Abbasid Caliphate.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-113"><a href="#cite_note-113">[111]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Hafez_880714_095.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="490" data-file-width="700" decoding="async" height="154" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0d/Hafez_880714_095.jpg/220px-Hafez_880714_095.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0d/Hafez_880714_095.jpg/330px-Hafez_880714_095.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0d/Hafez_880714_095.jpg/440px-Hafez_880714_095.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Hafez_880714_095.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Tomb of <a href="/wiki/Hafez" title="Hafez">Hafez</a>, a medieval <a href="/wiki/Persian_literature" title="Persian literature">Persian poet</a> whose works are regarded as a pinnacle in <a href="/wiki/Persian_literature" title="Persian literature">Persian literature</a> and have left a considerable mark on later Western writers, most notably <a href="/wiki/Johann_Wolfgang_von_Goethe" title="Johann Wolfgang von Goethe">Johann Wolfgang von Goethe</a>, <a href="/wiki/Henry_David_Thoreau" title="Henry David Thoreau">Henry David Thoreau</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Ralph_Waldo_Emerson" title="Ralph Waldo Emerson">Emerson</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Paul_Kane_114-0"><a href="#cite_note-Paul_Kane-114">[112]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Shafiq_Shamel_115-0"><a href="#cite_note-Shafiq_Shamel-115">[113]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Adineh_Khojasteh_Pour_and_Behnam_Mirza_Baba_Zadeh_116-0"><a href="#cite_note-Adineh_Khojasteh_Pour_and_Behnam_Mirza_Baba_Zadeh-116">[114]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>The blossoming <a href="/wiki/Persian_literature" title="Persian literature">literature</a>, <a href="/wiki/Iranian_philosophy" title="Iranian philosophy">philosophy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Islamic_Golden_Age#Mathematics" title="Islamic Golden Age">mathematics</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Iranian_medicine" title="Ancient Iranian medicine">medicine</a>, <a href="/wiki/Islamic_Golden_Age#Astronomy" title="Islamic Golden Age">astronomy</a> and <a href="/wiki/Persian_art" title="Persian art">art</a> of Iran became major elements in the formation of a new age for the Iranian civilization, during a period known as the <i><a href="/wiki/Islamic_Golden_Age" title="Islamic Golden Age">Islamic Golden Age</a></i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-117"><a href="#cite_note-117">[115]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-118"><a href="#cite_note-118">[116]</a></sup> The Islamic Golden Age reached its peak by the 10th and 11th centuries, during which Iran was the main theater of scientific activities.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-rnfrye_119-0"><a href="#cite_note-rnfrye-119">[117]</a></sup>
</p><p>The cultural revival that began in the Abbasid period led to a resurfacing of the <a href="/wiki/Iranian_nationalism" title="Iranian nationalism">Iranian national identity</a>; thus, the attempts of <a href="/wiki/Arabization" title="Arabization">Arabization</a> never succeeded in Iran.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (November 2020)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> The <a href="/wiki/Shu%27ubiyya" title="Shu'ubiyya">Shu'ubiyya</a> movement became a catalyst for Iranians to regain independence in their relations with the Arab invaders.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-120"><a href="#cite_note-120">[118]</a></sup> The most notable effect of this movement was the continuation of the Persian language attested to the works of the epic poet <a href="/wiki/Ferdowsi" title="Ferdowsi">Ferdowsi</a>, now considered the most prominent figure in Iranian literature.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (November 2020)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup>
</p><p>The tenth century saw a mass migration of <a href="/wiki/Turkic_tribal_confederations" title="Turkic tribal confederations">Turkic tribes</a> from <a href="/wiki/Central_Asia" title="Central Asia">Central Asia</a> into the Iranian Plateau.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-thePersians_121-0"><a href="#cite_note-thePersians-121">[119]</a></sup> Turkic tribesmen were first used in the Abbasid army as <a href="/wiki/Mamluk" title="Mamluk">mamluks</a> (slave-warriors), replacing Iranian and Arab elements within the army.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-wsu_109-1"><a href="#cite_note-wsu-109">[107]</a></sup> As a result, the Mamluks gained significant political power.
