In 999, large portions of Iran came briefly under the rule of the <a href="/wiki/Ghaznavids" title="Ghaznavids">Ghaznavids</a>, whose rulers were of mamluk Turkic origin, and longer subsequently under the <a href="/wiki/Seljuk_Empire" title="Seljuk Empire">Seljuk</a> and <a href="/wiki/Anushtegin_dynasty" title="Anushtegin dynasty">Khwarezmian</a> empires.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-thePersians_121-1"><a href="#cite_note-thePersians-121">[119]</a></sup> The Seljuks subsequently gave rise to the <a href="/wiki/Sultanate_of_Rum" title="Sultanate of Rum">Sultanate of Rum</a> in Anatolia, while taking their thoroughly Persianized identity with them.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-122"><a href="#cite_note-122">[120]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-123"><a href="#cite_note-123">[121]</a></sup> The result of the adoption and patronage of Persian culture by Turkish rulers was the development of a distinct <a href="/wiki/Turco-Persian_tradition" title="Turco-Persian tradition">Turco-Persian tradition</a>.
</p><p>From 1219 to 1221, under the Khwarazmian Empire, Iran suffered <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mongol_conquest_of_the_Khwarazmian_Empire" title="Mongol conquest of the Khwarazmian Empire">a devastating invasion</a> by the <a href="/wiki/Mongol_Empire" title="Mongol Empire">Mongol Empire</a> army of <a href="/wiki/Genghis_Khan" title="Genghis Khan">Genghis Khan</a>. According to Steven R. Ward, "<a href="/wiki/Mongol_invasions_and_conquests" title="Mongol invasions and conquests">Mongol violence and depredations</a> killed up to three-fourths of the population of the Iranian Plateau, possibly 10 to 15 million people. Some historians have estimated that Iran's population did not again reach its pre-Mongol levels until the mid-20th century."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Immortal_124-0"><a href="#cite_note-Immortal-124">[122]</a></sup> Most modern historians either outright dismiss or are highly skeptical of such statistics of colossal magnitude pertaining the Mongol onslaught on the Khwarazmian empire, mainland Iran and other Muslim regions and deem them to be exaggerations by Muslim chroniclers of that era (whose recordings were naturally of an anti-Mongol bent). Indeed, as far as the Iranian plateau was concerned, the bulk of the Mongol onslaught and battles were in the northeast of what is modern-day Iran, such as in the cities of <a href="/wiki/Nishapur" title="Nishapur">Nishapur</a> and <a href="/wiki/Tus,_Iran" title="Tus, Iran">Tus</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-125"><a href="#cite_note-125">[123]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-126"><a href="#cite_note-126">[124]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-127"><a href="#cite_note-127">[125]</a></sup>
</p><p>Following the fracture of the Mongol Empire in 1256, <a href="/wiki/Hulagu_Khan" title="Hulagu Khan">Hulagu Khan</a>, grandson of Genghis Khan, established the <a href="/wiki/Ilkhanate" title="Ilkhanate">Ilkhanate</a> in Iran. In 1370, yet another conqueror, <a href="/wiki/Timur" title="Timur">Timur</a>, followed the example of Hulagu, establishing the <a href="/wiki/Timurid_Empire" title="Timurid Empire">Timurid Empire</a> which lasted for another 156 years. In 1387, Timur ordered the complete massacre of <a href="/wiki/Isfahan" title="Isfahan">Isfahan</a>, reportedly killing 70,000 citizens.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-128"><a href="#cite_note-128">[126]</a></sup> The Ilkhans and the Timurids soon came to adopt the ways and customs of the Iranians, surrounding themselves with a culture that was distinctively Iranian.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-129"><a href="#cite_note-129">[127]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Early_modern_period">Early modern period</span></h3>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Safavids">Safavids</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Safavid_Iran" title="Safavid Iran">Safavid Iran</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Shah_Ismail_I.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="993" data-file-width="776" decoding="async" height="218" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Shah_Ismail_I.jpg/170px-Shah_Ismail_I.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Shah_Ismail_I.jpg/255px-Shah_Ismail_I.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Shah_Ismail_I.jpg/340px-Shah_Ismail_I.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Shah_Ismail_I.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Venetian_school_(art)" title="Venetian school (art)">Venetian</a> portrait, kept at the <a href="/wiki/Uffizi" title="Uffizi">Uffizi</a>, of <a href="/wiki/Ismail_I" title="Ismail I">Ismail I</a>, the founder of the <a href="/wiki/Safavid_dynasty" title="Safavid dynasty">Safavid Empire</a></div></div></div>
<p>By the 1500s, <a href="/wiki/Ismail_I" title="Ismail I">Ismail I</a> of <a href="/wiki/Ardabil" title="Ardabil">Ardabil</a> established the <a href="/wiki/Safavid_Iran" title="Safavid Iran">Safavid Empire</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-130"><a href="#cite_note-130">[128]</a></sup> with his capital at <a href="/wiki/Tabriz" title="Tabriz">Tabriz</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-thePersians_121-2"><a href="#cite_note-thePersians-121">[119]</a></sup> Beginning with <a href="/wiki/Azerbaijan_(Iran)" title="Azerbaijan (Iran)">Azerbaijan</a>, he subsequently extended his authority over all of the Iranian territories, and established an intermittent Iranian hegemony over the vast relative regions, reasserting the Iranian identity within large parts of <a href="/wiki/Greater_Iran" title="Greater Iran">Greater Iran</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-131"><a href="#cite_note-131">[129]</a></sup> Iran was predominantly <a href="/wiki/Sunni_Islam" title="Sunni Islam">Sunni</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Abdullah2014_132-0"><a href="#cite_note-Abdullah2014-132">[130]</a></sup> but Ismail instigated <a href="/wiki/Safavid_conversion_of_Iran_to_Shia_Islam" title="Safavid conversion of Iran to Shia Islam">a forced conversion</a> to the <a href="/wiki/Shia_Islam" title="Shia Islam">Shia</a> branch of Islam,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BBCReligion_133-0"><a href="#cite_note-BBCReligion-133">[131]</a></sup> spreading throughout the Safavid territories in the <a href="/wiki/Caucasus" title="Caucasus">Caucasus</a>, Iran, <a href="/wiki/Anatolia" title="Anatolia">Anatolia</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Mesopotamia" title="Mesopotamia">Mesopotamia</a>. As a result, modern-day Iran is the only official Shia nation of the world, with it holding an absolute majority in Iran and the Republic of <a href="/wiki/Azerbaijan" title="Azerbaijan">Azerbaijan</a>, having there the first and the second highest number of Shia inhabitants by population percentage in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-134"><a href="#cite_note-134">[132]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-books.google.com.au_135-0"><a href="#cite_note-books.google.com.au-135">[133]</a></sup> Meanwhile, the centuries-long geopolitical and ideological rivalry between Safavid Iran and the neighboring <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">Ottoman Empire</a> led to numerous <a href="/wiki/Ottoman%E2%80%93Persian_Wars" title="OttomanâPersian Wars">OttomanâIranian wars</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Immortal_124-1"><a href="#cite_note-Immortal-124">[122]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Portrait_of_Safavid_ruler_Abbas_I.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1130" data-file-width="863" decoding="async" height="223" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2d/Portrait_of_Safavid_ruler_Abbas_I.jpg/170px-Portrait_of_Safavid_ruler_Abbas_I.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2d/Portrait_of_Safavid_ruler_Abbas_I.jpg/255px-Portrait_of_Safavid_ruler_Abbas_I.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2d/Portrait_of_Safavid_ruler_Abbas_I.jpg/340px-Portrait_of_Safavid_ruler_Abbas_I.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Portrait_of_Safavid_ruler_Abbas_I.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A portrait of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Abbas_I_of_Persia" title="Abbas I of Persia">Abbas<span class="nowrap">Â </span>I</a>, the powerful, pragmatic <a href="/wiki/Safavid_dynasty" title="Safavid dynasty">Safavid</a> ruler who reinforced Iran's military, political, and economic power</div></div></div>
<p>The Safavid era peaked in the reign of <a href="/wiki/Abbas_the_Great" title="Abbas the Great">Abbas I</a> (1587â1629),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Immortal_124-2"><a href="#cite_note-Immortal-124">[122]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FattahCaso2009_136-0"><a href="#cite_note-FattahCaso2009-136">[134]</a></sup> surpassing their Turkish archrivals in strength, and making Iran a leading science and art hub in western Eurasia. The Safavid era saw the start of mass integration from <a href="/wiki/Peoples_of_the_Caucasus" title="Peoples of the Caucasus">Caucasian populations</a> into new layers of the society of Iran, as well as mass resettlement of them within the heartlands of Iran, playing a pivotal role in the history of Iran for centuries onwards. Following a gradual decline in the late 1600s and the early 1700s, which was caused by internal conflicts, the continuous wars with the Ottomans, and the foreign interference (most notably the Russian interference), the Safavid rule was ended by the <a href="/wiki/Hotak_dynasty" title="Hotak dynasty">Pashtun rebels</a> who besieged Isfahan and defeated <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sultan_Husayn" title="Sultan Husayn">Sultan Husayn</a> in 1722.
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Afsharids">Afsharids</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Afsharid_dynasty" title="Afsharid dynasty">Afsharid dynasty</a></div>
<p>In 1729, <a href="/wiki/Nader_Shah" title="Nader Shah">Nader Shah</a>, a chieftain and military genius from <a href="/wiki/Greater_Khorasan" title="Greater Khorasan">Khorasan</a>, successfully drove out and conquered the Pashtun invaders. He subsequently took back the annexed Caucasian territories which <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Constantinople_(1724)" title="Treaty of Constantinople (1724)">were divided</a> among the Ottoman and <a href="/wiki/Russian_Empire" title="Russian Empire">Russian</a> authorities by the ongoing chaos in Iran. During the reign of Nader Shah, Iran reached its greatest extent since the Sasanian Empire, reestablishing the Iranian hegemony all over the <a href="/wiki/Caucasus" title="Caucasus">Caucasus</a>, as well as other major parts of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/West_Asia" title="West Asia">west</a> and <a href="/wiki/Central_Asia" title="Central Asia">central Asia</a>, and briefly possessing what was arguably the most powerful empire at the time.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-books.google.nl_24-1"><a href="#cite_note-books.google.nl-24">[23]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Mooze_Naderi.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="828" data-file-width="1200" decoding="async" height="152" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cb/Mooze_Naderi.jpg/220px-Mooze_Naderi.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cb/Mooze_Naderi.jpg/330px-Mooze_Naderi.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cb/Mooze_Naderi.jpg/440px-Mooze_Naderi.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Mooze_Naderi.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Statue of <a href="/wiki/Nader_Shah" title="Nader Shah">Nader Shah</a>, the first <a href="/wiki/Afsharid_dynasty" title="Afsharid dynasty">Afsharid</a> ruler of Iran, at his <a href="/wiki/Tomb_of_Nader_Shah" title="Tomb of Nader Shah">Tomb</a></div></div></div>
<p>Nader Shah <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nader_Shah%27s_invasion_of_the_Mughal_Empire" title="Nader Shah's invasion of the Mughal Empire">invaded India and sacked far off Delhi</a> by the late 1730s. His territorial expansion, as well as his military successes, went into a decline following the final <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nader%27s_Dagestan_campaign" title="Nader's Dagestan campaign">campaigns in the Northern Caucasus</a> against then revolting <a href="/wiki/Lezgins" title="Lezgins">Lezgins</a>. The assassination of Nader Shah sparked a brief period of civil war and turmoil, after which <a href="/wiki/Karim_Khan_Zand" title="Karim Khan Zand">Karim Khan</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Zand_dynasty" title="Zand dynasty">Zand dynasty</a> came to power in 1750, bringing a period of relative peace and prosperity.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Immortal_124-3"><a href="#cite_note-Immortal-124">[122]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Zands">Zands</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Zand_dynasty" title="Zand dynasty">Zand dynasty</a></div>
<p>Compared to its preceding dynasties, the geopolitical reach of the Zand dynasty was limited. Many of the Iranian territories in the Caucasus gained <i>de facto</i> autonomy and were locally ruled through various <a href="/wiki/Khanates_of_the_Caucasus" title="Khanates of the Caucasus">Caucasian khanates</a>. However, despite the self-ruling, they all remained <a href="/wiki/Commoner" title="Commoner">subjects</a> and vassals to the Zand king.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-137"><a href="#cite_note-137">[135]</a></sup> Another civil war ensued after the death of Karim Khan in 1779, out of which <a href="/wiki/Agha_Mohammad_Khan_Qajar" title="Agha Mohammad Khan Qajar">Agha Mohammad Khan</a> emerged, founding the <a href="/wiki/Qajar_dynasty" title="Qajar dynasty">Qajar dynasty</a> in 1794.
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Qajars">Qajars</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Qajar_Iran" title="Qajar Iran">Qajar Iran</a></div>
<p>In 1795, following the disobedience of the <a href="/wiki/Georgians" title="Georgians">Georgian</a> subjects and their <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Georgievsk" title="Treaty of Georgievsk">alliance with the Russians</a>, the Qajars captured <a href="/wiki/Tbilisi" title="Tbilisi">Tbilisi</a> by the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Krtsanisi" title="Battle of Krtsanisi">Battle of Krtsanisi</a>, and drove the Russians out of the entire Caucasus, reestablishing the Iranian <a href="/wiki/Suzerainty" title="Suzerainty">suzerainty</a> over the region.
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Gulistan-Treaty.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1200" data-file-width="1565" decoding="async" height="169" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Gulistan-Treaty.jpg/220px-Gulistan-Treaty.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Gulistan-Treaty.jpg/330px-Gulistan-Treaty.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Gulistan-Treaty.jpg/440px-Gulistan-Treaty.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Gulistan-Treaty.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A map showing the 19th-century northwestern borders of Iran, comprising modern-day eastern <a href="/wiki/Georgia_(country)" title="Georgia (country)">Georgia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dagestan" title="Dagestan">Dagestan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Armenia" title="Armenia">Armenia</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Azerbaijan" title="Azerbaijan">Republic of Azerbaijan</a>, before being ceded to the neighboring <a href="/wiki/Russian_Empire" title="Russian Empire">Russian Empire</a> by the <a href="/wiki/Russo-Persian_Wars" title="Russo-Persian Wars">Russo-Iranian wars</a></div></div></div>
<p>The Russo-Iranian wars of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Russo-Persian_War_(1804%E2%80%9313)" title="Russo-Persian War (1804â13)">1804â1813</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Russo-Persian_War_(1826%E2%80%9328)" title="Russo-Persian War (1826â28)">1826â1828</a> resulted in large irrevocable territorial losses for Iran in the Caucasus, comprising all of the <a href="/wiki/South_Caucasus" title="South Caucasus">South Caucasus</a> and <a href="/wiki/Dagestan" title="Dagestan">Dagestan</a>, which made part of the very concept of Iran for centuries,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFisherAveryHamblyMelville1991329â330_25-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFisherAveryHamblyMelville1991329â330-25">[24]</a></sup> and thus substantial gains for the neighboring Russian Empire.
</p><p>As a result of the 19th-century Russo-Iranian wars, the Russians took over the Caucasus, and Iran irrevocably lost control over its integral territories in the region (comprising modern-day Dagestan, <a href="/wiki/Georgia_(country)" title="Georgia (country)">Georgia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Armenia" title="Armenia">Armenia</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Azerbaijan" title="Azerbaijan">Republic of Azerbaijan</a>), which got confirmed per the treaties of <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Gulistan" title="Treaty of Gulistan">Gulistan</a> and <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Turkmenchay" title="Treaty of Turkmenchay">Turkmenchay</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Timothy_C._Dowling_pp._728-730_26-1"><a href="#cite_note-Timothy_C._Dowling_pp._728-730-26">[25]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-138"><a href="#cite_note-138">[136]</a></sup> The area to the north of <a href="/wiki/Aras_(river)" title="Aras (river)">Aras River</a>, among which the contemporary Republic of Azerbaijan, eastern Georgia, Dagestan, and Armenia are located, were Iranian territory until they were occupied by Russia in the course of the 19th century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Timothy_C._Dowling_pp._728-730_26-2"><a href="#cite_note-Timothy_C._Dowling_pp._728-730-26">[25]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Swietochowski_Borderland_139-0"><a href="#cite_note-Swietochowski_Borderland-139">[137]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-140"><a href="#cite_note-140">[138]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-141"><a href="#cite_note-141">[139]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-142"><a href="#cite_note-142">[140]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-143"><a href="#cite_note-143">[141]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-144"><a href="#cite_note-144">[142]</a></sup>
</p><p>As Iran shrank, many <a href="/wiki/South_Caucasus" title="South Caucasus">South Caucasian</a> and <a href="/wiki/North_Caucasus" title="North Caucasus">North Caucasian</a> Muslims moved towards Iran,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Mansoori_145-0"><a href="#cite_note-Mansoori-145">[143]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ReferenceA_146-0"><a href="#cite_note-ReferenceA-146">[144]</a></sup> especially until the aftermath of the <a href="/wiki/Circassian_genocide" title="Circassian genocide">Circassian Genocide</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ReferenceA_146-1"><a href="#cite_note-ReferenceA-146">[144]</a></sup> and the decades afterwards, while Iran's Armenians were encouraged to settle in the newly incorporated Russian territories,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-147"><a href="#cite_note-147">[145]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-148"><a href="#cite_note-148">[146]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-149"><a href="#cite_note-149">[147]</a></sup> causing significant demographic shifts.
</p><p>Around 1.5 million peopleâ20 to 25% of the population of Iranâdied as a result of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Persian_famine_of_1870-1872" title="Persian famine of 1870-1872">Great Famine of 1870â1872</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-150"><a href="#cite_note-150">[148]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Parliamenttehran1906.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1383" data-file-width="2088" decoding="async" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d3/Parliamenttehran1906.jpg/220px-Parliamenttehran1906.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d3/Parliamenttehran1906.jpg/330px-Parliamenttehran1906.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d3/Parliamenttehran1906.jpg/440px-Parliamenttehran1906.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Parliamenttehran1906.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Baharestan" title="Baharestan">first national Iranian Parliament</a> was established in 1906 during the <a href="/wiki/Persian_Constitutional_Revolution" title="Persian Constitutional Revolution">Persian Constitutional Revolution</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>Between 1872 and 1905, a series of protests took place in response to the sale of <a href="/wiki/Concession_(contract)" title="Concession (contract)">concessions</a> to foreigners by Qajar monarchs <a href="/wiki/Naser_al-Din_Shah_Qajar" title="Naser al-Din Shah Qajar">Naser-ed-Din</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mozaffar_ad-Din_Shah_Qajar" title="Mozaffar ad-Din Shah Qajar">Mozaffar-ed-Din</a>, and led to the <a href="/wiki/Persian_Constitutional_Revolution" title="Persian Constitutional Revolution">Constitutional Revolution</a> in 1905. The <a href="/wiki/Persian_Constitution_of_1906" title="Persian Constitution of 1906">first Iranian constitution</a> and the first national parliament of Iran were founded in 1906, through the ongoing revolution. The Constitution included the official recognition of Iran's three religious minorities, namely <a href="/wiki/Christianity_in_Iran" title="Christianity in Iran">Christians</a>, <a href="/wiki/Persian_Jews" title="Persian Jews">Jews</a>, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Zoroastrians_in_Iran" title="Zoroastrians in Iran">Zoroastrians</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Colin_Brock_p_99_151-0"><a href="#cite_note-Colin_Brock_p_99-151">[149]</a></sup> which has remained a basis in the legislation of Iran since then. The struggle related to the constitutional movement was followed by the <a href="/wiki/Triumph_of_Tehran" title="Triumph of Tehran">Triumph of Tehran</a> in 1909, when <a href="/wiki/Mohammad_Ali_Shah_Qajar" title="Mohammad Ali Shah Qajar">Mohammad Ali Shah</a> was defeated and forced to abdicate. On the pretext of restoring order, the Russians occupied northern Iran in 1911 and maintained a military presence in the region for years to come. But this did not put an end to the civil uprisings and was soon followed by <a href="/wiki/Mirza_Kuchik_Khan" title="Mirza Kuchik Khan">Mirza Kuchik Khan</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Jungle_Movement_of_Gilan" title="Jungle Movement of Gilan">Jungle Movement</a> against both the Qajar monarchy and foreign invaders.
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Reza-shah.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="659" data-file-width="450" decoding="async" height="249" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/92/Reza-shah.jpg/170px-Reza-shah.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/92/Reza-shah.jpg/255px-Reza-shah.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/92/Reza-shah.jpg/340px-Reza-shah.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Reza-shah.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Reza_Shah" title="Reza Shah">Reza Shah</a>, the first <a href="/wiki/Pahlavi_dynasty" title="Pahlavi dynasty">Pahlavi king</a> of Iran, in military uniform</div></div></div>
<p>Despite Iran's neutrality during <a href="/wiki/World_War_I" title="World War I">World War I</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">Ottoman</a>, <a href="/wiki/Russian_Empire" title="Russian Empire">Russian</a> and <a href="/wiki/British_Empire" title="British Empire">British</a> empires occupied the territory of western Iran and fought the <a href="/wiki/Persian_campaign_(World_War_I)" title="Persian campaign (World War I)">Persian Campaign</a> before fully withdrawing their forces in 1921. At least 2 million Persian civilians died either directly in the fighting, the <a href="/wiki/Armenian_genocide" title="Armenian genocide">Ottoman perpetrated anti-Christian genocides</a> or the war-induced <a href="/wiki/Persian_famine_of_1917%E2%80%931919" title="Persian famine of 1917â1919">famine of 1917â1919</a>. A large number of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Iranian_Assyrian" title="Iranian Assyrian">Iranian Assyrian</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Iranian_Armenian" title="Iranian Armenian">Iranian Armenian</a> Christians, as well as those Muslims who tried to protect them, were victims of mass murders committed by the invading <a href="/wiki/Military_of_the_Ottoman_Empire" title="Military of the Ottoman Empire">Ottoman troops</a>, notably in and around <a href="/wiki/Khoy" title="Khoy">Khoy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Maku,_Iran" title="Maku, Iran">Maku</a>, <a href="/wiki/Salmas" title="Salmas">Salmas</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Urmia" title="Urmia">Urmia</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-152"><a href="#cite_note-152">[150]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Kevorkian2011_153-0"><a href="#cite_note-Kevorkian2011-153">[151]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-154"><a href="#cite_note-154">[152]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-autogenerated2_155-0"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated2-155">[153]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Alexander_Laban_Hinton_p._117_156-0"><a href="#cite_note-Alexander_Laban_Hinton_p._117-156">[154]</a></sup>
</p><p>Apart from the rule of Agha Mohammad Khan, the Qajar rule is characterized as a century of misrule.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-thePersians_121-3"><a href="#cite_note-thePersians-121">[119]</a></sup> The inability of <a href="/wiki/Qajar_Iran" title="Qajar Iran">Qajar Iran</a>'s government to maintain the country's <a href="/wiki/Sovereignty" title="Sovereignty">sovereignty</a> during and immediately after World War I led to the British directed <a href="/wiki/1921_Persian_coup_d%27%C3%A9tat" title="1921 Persian coup d'Ã©tat">1921 Persian coup d'Ã©tat</a> and <a href="/wiki/Reza_Shah" title="Reza Shah">Reza Shah</a>'s establishment of the <a href="/wiki/Pahlavi_dynasty" title="Pahlavi dynasty">Pahlavi dynasty</a>. Reza Shah, became the new <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_Prime_Ministers_of_Iran" title="List of Prime Ministers of Iran">Prime Minister of Iran</a> and was declared the new monarch in 1925.
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Pahlavis">Pahlavis</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Pahlavi_Iran" title="Pahlavi Iran">Pahlavi Iran</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Anglo-Soviet_invasion_of_Iran" title="Anglo-Soviet invasion of Iran">Anglo-Soviet invasion of Iran</a></div>
<p>In the midst of <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a>, in June 1941, <a href="/wiki/Nazi_Germany" title="Nazi Germany">Nazi Germany</a> broke the <a href="/wiki/Molotov%E2%80%93Ribbentrop_Pact" title="MolotovâRibbentrop Pact">MolotovâRibbentrop Pact</a> and <a href="/wiki/Operation_Barbarossa" title="Operation Barbarossa">invaded</a> the <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union" title="Soviet Union">Soviet Union</a>, Iran's northern neighbor. The Soviets quickly allied themselves with the <a href="/wiki/Allies_of_World_War_II" title="Allies of World War II">Allied countries</a> and in July and August 1941 the British demanded that the Iranian government expel all Germans from Iran. Reza Shah refused to expel the Germans and on 25 August 1941, the British and Soviets launched a <a href="/wiki/Anglo-Soviet_invasion_of_Iran" title="Anglo-Soviet invasion of Iran">surprise invasion</a> and Reza Shah's government quickly surrendered.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-157"><a href="#cite_note-157">[155]</a></sup> The invasion's strategic purpose was to secure a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Supply_line" title="Supply line">supply line</a> to the USSR (later named the <a href="/wiki/Persian_Corridor" title="Persian Corridor">Persian Corridor</a>), secure the oil fields and <a href="/wiki/Abadan_Refinery" title="Abadan Refinery">Abadan Refinery</a> (of the UK-owned <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Anglo-Iranian_Oil_Company" title="Anglo-Iranian Oil Company">Anglo-Iranian Oil Company</a>), prevent a German advance via Turkey or the USSR on Baku's oil fields, and limit German influence in Iran. Following the invasion, on 16 September 1941 Reza Shah abdicated and was replaced by <a href="/wiki/Mohammad_Reza_Pahlavi" title="Mohammad Reza Pahlavi">Mohammad Reza Pahlavi</a>, his 21-year-old son.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Farrokh_03_158-0"><a href="#cite_note-Farrokh_03-158">[156]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-159"><a href="#cite_note-159">[157]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-160"><a href="#cite_note-160">[158]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Teheran_conference-1943.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="4602" data-file-width="5805" decoding="async" height="174" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cf/Teheran_conference-1943.jpg/220px-Teheran_conference-1943.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cf/Teheran_conference-1943.jpg/330px-Teheran_conference-1943.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cf/Teheran_conference-1943.jpg/440px-Teheran_conference-1943.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Teheran_conference-1943.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Allies_of_World_War_II" title="Allies of World War II">Allied</a> "Big Three" at the 1943 <a href="/wiki/Tehran_Conference" title="Tehran Conference">Tehran Conference</a></div></div></div>
<p>During the rest of World War II, Iran became <a href="/wiki/Persian_Corridor" title="Persian Corridor">a major conduit</a> for <a href="/wiki/Lend-Lease" title="Lend-Lease">British and American aid</a> to the Soviet Union and an avenue through which <a href="/wiki/Evacuation_of_Polish_civilians_from_the_USSR_in_World_War_II#Iran_and_the_Middle_East" title="Evacuation of Polish civilians from the USSR in World War II">over 120,000 Polish refugees</a> and <a href="/wiki/Anders%27_Army" title="Anders' Army">Polish Armed Forces</a> fled the Axis advance.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-161"><a href="#cite_note-161">[159]</a></sup> At the 1943 <a href="/wiki/Tehran_Conference" title="Tehran Conference">Tehran Conference</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Allies_of_World_War_II" title="Allies of World War II">Allied</a> "Big Three"â<a href="/wiki/Joseph_Stalin" title="Joseph Stalin">Joseph Stalin</a>, <a href="/wiki/Franklin_D._Roosevelt" title="Franklin D. Roosevelt">Franklin D. Roosevelt</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Winston_Churchill" title="Winston Churchill">Winston Churchill</a>âissued the <a href="/wiki/Tehran_Conference#Three_powers_come_together" title="Tehran Conference">Tehran Declaration</a> to guarantee the post-war independence and boundaries of Iran. However, at the end of the war, Soviet troops remained in Iran and established two puppet states in north-western Iran, namely the <a href="/wiki/Azerbaijan_People%27s_Government" title="Azerbaijan People's Government">People's Government of Azerbaijan</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Mahabad" title="Republic of Mahabad">Republic of Mahabad</a>. This led to the <a href="/wiki/Iran_crisis_of_1946" title="Iran crisis of 1946">Iran crisis of 1946</a>, one of the first confrontations of the <a href="/wiki/Cold_War" title="Cold War">Cold War</a>, which ended after oil concessions were promised to the USSR and Soviet forces withdrew from Iran proper in May 1946. The two puppet states were soon overthrown, and the oil concessions were later revoked.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-162"><a href="#cite_note-162">[160]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-163"><a href="#cite_note-163">[161]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="1951.E2.80.931978:_Mosaddegh.2C_Mohammad_Reza_Pahlavi"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="1951â1978:_Mosaddegh,_Mohammad_Reza_Pahlavi">1951â1978: Mosaddegh, Mohammad Reza Pahlavi</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/1953_Iranian_coup_d%27%C3%A9tat" title="1953 Iranian coup d'Ã©tat">1953 Iranian coup d'Ã©tat</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Mohammad_Pahlavi_Coronation_(cropped_version).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="328" data-file-width="417" decoding="async" height="173" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/32/Mohammad_Pahlavi_Coronation_%28cropped_version%29.jpg/220px-Mohammad_Pahlavi_Coronation_%28cropped_version%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/32/Mohammad_Pahlavi_Coronation_%28cropped_version%29.jpg/330px-Mohammad_Pahlavi_Coronation_%28cropped_version%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/3/32/Mohammad_Pahlavi_Coronation_%28cropped_version%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Mohammad_Pahlavi_Coronation_(cropped_version).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Mohammad_Reza_Pahlavi" title="Mohammad Reza Pahlavi">Mohammad Reza Pahlavi</a> and the Imperial Family during the coronation ceremony of the Shah of Iran in 1967</div></div></div>
<p>In 1951, <a href="/wiki/Mohammad_Mosaddegh" title="Mohammad Mosaddegh">Mohammad Mosaddegh</a> was appointed as the <a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Iran" title="Prime Minister of Iran">Prime Minister</a> of <a href="/wiki/Pahlavi_Iran" title="Pahlavi Iran">Pahlavi Iran</a>. After the <a href="/wiki/Nationalization_of_the_Iranian_oil_industry" title="Nationalization of the Iranian oil industry">nationalization of Iran's oil industry</a>, he became enormously popular.  He was deposed in the <a href="/wiki/1953_Iranian_coup_d%27%C3%A9tat" title="1953 Iranian coup d'Ã©tat">1953 Iranian coup d'Ã©tat</a>, an Anglo-American covert operation that marked the first time the United States had participated in an overthrow of a foreign government during the <a href="/wiki/Cold_War" title="Cold War">Cold War</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Kinzer2011_164-0"><a href="#cite_note-Kinzer2011-164">[162]</a></sup>
</p><p>After the coup, the Shah became increasingly <a href="/wiki/Autocracy" title="Autocracy">autocratic</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sultanism" title="Sultanism">sultanistic</a>, and Iran entered a decades-long phase of controversially close relations with the United States and some other foreign governments.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-165"><a href="#cite_note-165">[163]</a></sup> While the Shah increasingly modernized Iran and claimed to retain it as a fully <a href="/wiki/Secular_state" title="Secular state">secular state</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Anthony_H._Cordesman_p_22_27-1"><a href="#cite_note-Anthony_H._Cordesman_p_22-27">[26]</a></sup> arbitrary arrests and torture by his secret police, the <a href="/wiki/SAVAK" title="SAVAK">SAVAK</a>, were used for crushing all forms of political opposition.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-166"><a href="#cite_note-166">[164]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Ruhollah_Khomeini" title="Ruhollah Khomeini">Ruhollah Khomeini</a>, a radical Muslim cleric,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-167"><a href="#cite_note-167">[165]</a></sup> became an active critic of the Shah's far-reaching series of reforms known as the <i><a href="/wiki/White_Revolution" title="White Revolution">White Revolution</a></i>. Khomeini publicly denounced the government, and was arrested and imprisoned for 18 months. After his release in 1964, he refused to apologize and was eventually sent into exile.
</p><p>Due to the <a href="/wiki/1973_oil_crisis" title="1973 oil crisis">1973 spike in oil prices</a>, the economy of Iran was flooded with foreign currency, which caused <a href="/wiki/Inflation" title="Inflation">inflation</a>. By 1974, the economy of Iran was experiencing a double-digit inflation rate, and despite the many large projects to modernize the country, corruption was rampant and caused <a href="/wiki/Background_and_causes_of_the_Iranian_Revolution#1970â1975" title="Background and causes of the Iranian Revolution">large amounts of waste</a>. By 1975 and 1976, an <a href="/wiki/Recession" title="Recession">economic recession</a> led to an increased unemployment rate, especially among millions of youths who had migrated to the cities of Iran looking for construction jobs during the boom years of the early 1970s. By the late 1970s, many of these people opposed the Shah's regime and began organizing and joining the protests against it.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Hurd2009_168-0"><a href="#cite_note-Hurd2009-168">[166]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="After_the_1979_Iranian_Revolution">After the 1979 Iranian Revolution</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_Islamic_Republic_of_Iran" title="History of the Islamic Republic of Iran">History of the Islamic Republic of Iran</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Iranian_Revolution" title="Iranian Revolution">Iranian Revolution</a>, <a href="/wiki/Iran%E2%80%93Iraq_War" title="IranâIraq War">IranâIraq War</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Human_rights_in_the_Islamic_Republic_of_Iran" title="Human rights in the Islamic Republic of Iran">Human rights in the Islamic Republic of Iran</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Imam_Khomeini_in_Mehrabad.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="755" data-file-width="573" decoding="async" height="224" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/06/Imam_Khomeini_in_Mehrabad.jpg/170px-Imam_Khomeini_in_Mehrabad.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/06/Imam_Khomeini_in_Mehrabad.jpg/255px-Imam_Khomeini_in_Mehrabad.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/06/Imam_Khomeini_in_Mehrabad.jpg/340px-Imam_Khomeini_in_Mehrabad.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Imam_Khomeini_in_Mehrabad.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Ruhollah_Khomeini%27s_return_to_Iran" title="Ruhollah Khomeini's return to Iran">Ruhollah Khomeini's return to Iran</a> on 1<span class="nowrap">Â </span>February 1979</div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Iranian_Revolution" title="Iranian Revolution">1979 Revolution</a>, later known as the <i>Islamic Revolution</i>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-169"><a href="#cite_note-169">[167]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-170"><a href="#cite_note-170">[168]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-171"><a href="#cite_note-171">[169]</a></sup> began in January 1978 with the first major demonstrations against the Shah.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-172"><a href="#cite_note-172">[170]</a></sup> After <a href="/wiki/Iranian_Revolution#General_strike,_increasing_opposition,_and_military_government" title="Iranian Revolution">a year of strikes</a> and <a href="/wiki/Iranian_Revolution#Renewed_protests_(AugâSept)" title="Iranian Revolution">demonstrations</a> paralyzing the country and its economy, <a href="/wiki/Iranian_Revolution#The_Shah's_exile_and_Khomeini's_return" title="Iranian Revolution">Mohammad Reza Pahlavi fled to the United States, and Ruhollah Khomeini returned</a> from exile to Tehran in February 1979, forming a new government.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BBC_this_day_173-0"><a href="#cite_note-BBC_this_day-173">[171]</a></sup> After holding <a href="/wiki/March_1979_Iranian_Islamic_Republic_referendum" title="March 1979 Iranian Islamic Republic referendum">a referendum</a>, Iran officially became an <a href="/wiki/Islamic_republic" title="Islamic republic">Islamic republic</a> in April 1979.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-JohnsonUradnik2011_174-0"><a href="#cite_note-JohnsonUradnik2011-174">[172]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/December_1979_Iranian_constitutional_referendum" title="December 1979 Iranian constitutional referendum">A second referendum</a> in December 1979 approved <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Constitution_of_the_Islamic_Republic_of_Iran" title="Constitution of the Islamic Republic of Iran">a theocratic constitution</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-175"><a href="#cite_note-175">[173]</a></sup>
</p><p>The immediate nationwide uprisings against the new government began with the <a href="/wiki/1979_Kurdish_rebellion_in_Iran" title="1979 Kurdish rebellion in Iran">1979 Kurdish rebellion</a> and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/1979_Khuzestan_uprising" title="1979 Khuzestan uprising">Khuzestan uprisings</a>, along with the uprisings in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sistan_and_Baluchestan_Province" title="Sistan and Baluchestan Province">Sistan and Baluchestan</a> and other areas. Over the next several years, these uprisings were <a href="/wiki/Consolidation_of_the_Iranian_Revolution" title="Consolidation of the Iranian Revolution">subdued violently</a> by the new Islamic government. The new government began <a href="/wiki/Consolidation_of_the_Iranian_Revolution#Suppression_of_opposition" title="Consolidation of the Iranian Revolution">purging itself of the non-Islamist political opposition</a>, as well as of those Islamists who were not considered radical enough. Although both nationalists and Marxists had initially joined with Islamists to overthrow the Shah, tens of thousands were executed by the new regime afterward.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Benard_176-0"><a href="#cite_note-Benard-176">[174]</a></sup> Following Khomeini's order to purge the new government of any remaining officials still loyal to the exiled Shah, many former ministers and officials in the Shah's government, including former prime minister <a href="/wiki/Amir-Abbas_Hoveyda" title="Amir-Abbas Hoveyda">Amir-Abbas Hoveyda</a>, were <a href="/wiki/Casualties_of_the_Iranian_Revolution" title="Casualties of the Iranian Revolution">executed</a>.
</p><p>On 4 November 1979, after the United States refusal for the extradition of Mohammad Reza Pahlavi to the new government, <a href="/wiki/Muslim_Student_Followers_of_the_Imam%27s_Line" title="Muslim Student Followers of the Imam's Line">a group of Muslim students</a> seized the United States Embassy and <a href="/wiki/Iran_hostage_crisis" title="Iran hostage crisis">took the embassy with 52 personnel and citizens hostage</a> .<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-carterpbs_177-0"><a href="#cite_note-carterpbs-177">[175]</a></sup> Attempts by the <a href="/wiki/Jimmy_Carter" title="Jimmy Carter">Jimmy Carter</a> administration to <a href="/wiki/Iran_hostage_crisis_negotiations" title="Iran hostage crisis negotiations">negotiate for the release of the hostages</a>, and a failed <a href="/wiki/Operation_Eagle_Claw" title="Operation Eagle Claw">rescue attempt</a>, helped with the falling popularity of Carter among the US citizens and it pushed him out of the presidential office and brought <a href="/wiki/Ronald_Reagan" title="Ronald Reagan">Ronald Reagan</a> to power. On Jimmy Carter's final day in office, the last hostages were finally set free due to the <a href="/wiki/Algiers_Accords" title="Algiers Accords">Algiers Accords</a>. Mohammad Reza Pahlavi left the United States for Egypt, where he died of complications from cancer only months later, on 27 July 1980.
</p><p>The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Iranian_Cultural_Revolution" title="Iranian Cultural Revolution">Cultural Revolution</a> began in 1980, with an initial closure of universities for three years, in order to perform an inspection and clean up in the cultural policy of the education and training system.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-autogenerated1_178-0"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated1-178">[176]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Chemical_weapon1.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="528" data-file-width="768" decoding="async" height="151" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e1/Chemical_weapon1.jpg/220px-Chemical_weapon1.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e1/Chemical_weapon1.jpg/330px-Chemical_weapon1.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e1/Chemical_weapon1.jpg/440px-Chemical_weapon1.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Chemical_weapon1.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>An Iranian soldier wearing a gas mask on the front line during the <a href="/wiki/Iran%E2%80%93Iraq_War" title="IranâIraq War">IranâIraq War</a></div></div></div>
<p>On 22 September 1980, the Iraqi army <a href="/wiki/Iran%E2%80%93Iraq_War#1980:_Iraqi_invasion" title="IranâIraq War">invaded the western Iranian province of Khuzestan</a>, initiating the <a href="/wiki/Iran%E2%80%93Iraq_War" title="IranâIraq War">IranâIraq War</a>. Although the forces of Saddam Hussein made several early advances, by mid-1982, the Iranian forces successfully managed to <a href="/wiki/Iran%E2%80%93Iraq_War#1982:_Iraqi_retreat,_Iranian_offensive" title="IranâIraq War">drive the Iraqi army back</a> into Iraq. In July 1982, with Iraq thrown on the defensive, the regime of Iran decided to invade Iraq and conducted countless offensives to conquer Iraqi territory and capture cities, such as Basra. The war continued until 1988 when the Iraqi army defeated the Iranian forces inside Iraq and pushed the remaining Iranian troops back across the border. Subsequently, Khomeini accepted <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Security_Council_Resolution_598" title="United Nations Security Council Resolution 598">a truce mediated by the United Nations</a>. The total Iranian casualties in the war were estimated to be 123,220â160,000 <a href="/wiki/Killed_in_action" title="Killed in action">KIA</a>, 60,711 <a href="/wiki/Missing_in_action" title="Missing in action">MIA</a>, and 11,000â16,000 <a href="/wiki/Civilian_casualties" title="Civilian casualties">civilians killed</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-179"><a href="#cite_note-179">[177]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-180"><a href="#cite_note-180">[178]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:3rd_Day_-_The_Green_Protest_Rally.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1416" data-file-width="2128" decoding="async" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/08/3rd_Day_-_The_Green_Protest_Rally.jpg/220px-3rd_Day_-_The_Green_Protest_Rally.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/08/3rd_Day_-_The_Green_Protest_Rally.jpg/330px-3rd_Day_-_The_Green_Protest_Rally.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/08/3rd_Day_-_The_Green_Protest_Rally.jpg/440px-3rd_Day_-_The_Green_Protest_Rally.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:3rd_Day_-_The_Green_Protest_Rally.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Iranian_Green_Movement" title="Iranian Green Movement">Green Movement</a>'s <i>Silent Demonstration</i> during the <a href="/wiki/2009_Iranian_presidential_election_protests" title="2009 Iranian presidential election protests">2009â10 Iranian election protests</a></div></div></div>
<p>Following the IranâIraq War, in 1989, <a href="/wiki/Akbar_Hashemi_Rafsanjani" title="Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani">Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani</a> and his administration concentrated on a pragmatic pro-business policy of rebuilding and strengthening the economy without making any dramatic break with the ideology of the revolution. In 1997, Rafsanjani was succeeded by moderate <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Iranian_reform_movement" title="Iranian reform movement">reformist</a> <a href="/wiki/Mohammad_Khatami" title="Mohammad Khatami">Mohammad Khatami</a>, whose government attempted, unsuccessfully, to make the country more free and democratic.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-autogenerated3_181-0"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated3-181">[179]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/2005_Iranian_presidential_election" title="2005 Iranian presidential election">2005 presidential election</a> brought conservative <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Populist" title="Populist">populist</a> candidate, <a href="/wiki/Mahmoud_Ahmadinejad" title="Mahmoud Ahmadinejad">Mahmoud Ahmadinejad</a>, to power.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-182"><a href="#cite_note-182">[180]</a></sup> By the time of the <a href="/wiki/2009_Iranian_presidential_election" title="2009 Iranian presidential election">2009 Iranian presidential election</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Interior_(Iran)" title="Ministry of Interior (Iran)">Interior Ministry</a> announced incumbent President Ahmadinejad had won 62.63% of the vote, while <a href="/wiki/Mir-Hossein_Mousavi" title="Mir-Hossein Mousavi">Mir-Hossein Mousavi</a> had come in second place with 33.75%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-183"><a href="#cite_note-183">[181]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-The_Guardian_November_29_2015c_184-0"><a href="#cite_note-The_Guardian_November_29_2015c-184">[182]</a></sup> The election results were widely disputed,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-185"><a href="#cite_note-185">[183]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-186"><a href="#cite_note-186">[184]</a></sup> and resulted in <a href="/wiki/2009_Iranian_presidential_election_protests" title="2009 Iranian presidential election protests">widespread protests</a>, both within Iran and in major cities outside the country,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-187"><a href="#cite_note-187">[185]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-188"><a href="#cite_note-188">[186]</a></sup> and the creation of the <a href="/wiki/Iranian_Green_Movement" title="Iranian Green Movement">Iranian Green Movement</a>.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Hassan_Rouhani" title="Hassan Rouhani">Hassan Rouhani</a> was elected as the president on 15 June 2013, defeating <a href="/wiki/Mohammad_Bagher_Ghalibaf" title="Mohammad Bagher Ghalibaf">Mohammad Bagher Ghalibaf</a> and four other candidates.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BBCannouncedwinner_189-0"><a href="#cite_note-BBCannouncedwinner-189">[187]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-WSJannouncedwinner_190-0"><a href="#cite_note-WSJannouncedwinner-190">[188]</a></sup> The electoral victory of Rouhani relatively improved the relations of Iran with other countries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-191"><a href="#cite_note-191">[189]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Protests_in_Tehran_by_Fars_News_03.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="699" data-file-width="901" decoding="async" height="171" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6c/Protests_in_Tehran_by_Fars_News_03.jpg/220px-Protests_in_Tehran_by_Fars_News_03.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6c/Protests_in_Tehran_by_Fars_News_03.jpg/330px-Protests_in_Tehran_by_Fars_News_03.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6c/Protests_in_Tehran_by_Fars_News_03.jpg/440px-Protests_in_Tehran_by_Fars_News_03.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Protests_in_Tehran_by_Fars_News_03.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/2017%E2%80%9318_Iranian_protests" title="2017â18 Iranian protests">2017â18 Iranian protests</a> were initiated on 31 December 2017 and continued for months.</div></div></div>
<p>The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/2017%E2%80%9318_Iranian_protests" title="2017â18 Iranian protests">2017â18 Iranian protests</a> swept across the country against the government and its longtime Supreme Leader in response to the economic and political situation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-192"><a href="#cite_note-192">[190]</a></sup> The scale of protests throughout the country and the number of people participating were significant,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-193"><a href="#cite_note-193">[191]</a></sup> and it was formally confirmed that thousands of protesters were arrested.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-194"><a href="#cite_note-194">[192]</a></sup> The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/2019%E2%80%9320_Iranian_protests" title="2019â20 Iranian protests">2019â20 Iranian protests</a> started on 15 November in <a href="/wiki/Ahvaz" title="Ahvaz">Ahvaz</a>, spreading across the country within hours, after the government announced increases in the fuel price of up to 300%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-195"><a href="#cite_note-195">[193]</a></sup> A <a href="/wiki/2019_Internet_blackout_in_Iran" title="2019 Internet blackout in Iran">week-long total Internet shutdown</a> throughout the country marked one of the most severe Internet blackouts in any country, and in the bloodiest governmental crackdown of the protestors in the history of Islamic Republic,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-196"><a href="#cite_note-196">[194]</a></sup> tens of thousands were arrested and hundreds were killed within a few days according to multiple international observers, including <a href="/wiki/Amnesty_International" title="Amnesty International">Amnesty International</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-197"><a href="#cite_note-197">[195]</a></sup>
</p><p>On 3 January 2020, the revolutionary guard's general, <a href="/wiki/Qasem_Soleimani" title="Qasem Soleimani">Qasem Soleimani</a>, was <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/2020_Baghdad_International_Airport_airstrike" title="2020 Baghdad International Airport airstrike">assassinated by the United States in Iraq</a>, which considerably heightened the <a href="/wiki/Iran%E2%80%93United_States_relations" title="IranâUnited States relations">existing tensions between the two countries</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Roelants_198-0"><a href="#cite_note-Roelants-198">[196]</a></sup> Three days after, Iran's <a href="/wiki/Islamic_Revolutionary_Guard_Corps" title="Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps">Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps</a> launched a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/2020_Iranian_attack_on_U.S._forces_in_Iraq" title="2020 Iranian attack on U.S. forces in Iraq">retaliatory attack on US forces in Iraq</a> and by accident shot down <a href="/wiki/Ukraine_International_Airlines_Flight_752" title="Ukraine International Airlines Flight 752">Ukraine International Airlines Flight 752</a>, killing 176 civilians and leading to <a href="/wiki/Ukraine_International_Airlines_Flight_752_protests" title="Ukraine International Airlines Flight 752 protests">nation-wide protests</a>. An international investigation led to the government admitting to the shootdown of the plane by a surface-to-air missile after three days of denial, calling it a "human error".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-199"><a href="#cite_note-199">[197]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-200"><a href="#cite_note-200">[198]</a></sup>
</p><p>Beginning on 16 September 2022 <a href="/wiki/Mahsa_Amini_protests" title="Mahsa Amini protests">protests</a> started against the <a href="/wiki/Government_of_the_Islamic_Republic_of_Iran" title="Government of the Islamic Republic of Iran">government of Iran</a> following the death of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mahsa_Amini(Jina)" title="Mahsa Amini(Jina)">Mahsa Amini(Jina)</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-201"><a href="#cite_note-201">[199]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-202"><a href="#cite_note-202">[200]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-203"><a href="#cite_note-203">[201]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Geography">Geography</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Geography_of_Iran" title="Geography of Iran">Geography of Iran</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Borders_of_Iran" title="Borders of Iran">Borders of Iran</a>, <a href="/wiki/Agriculture_in_Iran" title="Agriculture in Iran">Agriculture in Iran</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Environmental_issues_in_Iran" title="Environmental issues in Iran">Environmental issues in Iran</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:981012-Damavand-South-IMG_9861-2.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2219" data-file-width="3628" decoding="async" height="135" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8d/981012-Damavand-South-IMG_9861-2.jpg/220px-981012-Damavand-South-IMG_9861-2.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8d/981012-Damavand-South-IMG_9861-2.jpg/330px-981012-Damavand-South-IMG_9861-2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8d/981012-Damavand-South-IMG_9861-2.jpg/440px-981012-Damavand-South-IMG_9861-2.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:981012-Damavand-South-IMG_9861-2.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Mount_Damavand" title="Mount Damavand">Mount Damavand</a>, Iran's highest point, is located in <a href="/wiki/Amol_County" title="Amol County">Amol</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mazandaran_Province" title="Mazandaran Province">Mazenderan</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>Iran has an area of 1,648,195Â km<sup>2</sup> (636,372Â sqÂ mi).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CIA_3-3"><a href="#cite_note-CIA-3">[3]</a></sup> It lies between latitudes <a href="/wiki/24th_parallel_north" title="24th parallel north">24Â°</a> and <a href="/wiki/40th_parallel_north" title="40th parallel north">40Â° N</a>, and longitudes <a href="/wiki/44th_meridian_east" title="44th meridian east">44Â°</a> and <a href="/wiki/64th_meridian_east" title="64th meridian east">64Â° E</a>. It is bordered to the northwest by <a href="/wiki/Armenia" title="Armenia">Armenia</a> (35Â km or 22Â mi), the Azeri exclave of <a href="/wiki/Nakhchivan_Autonomous_Republic" title="Nakhchivan Autonomous Republic">Nakhchivan</a> (179Â km or 111Â mi),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-204"><a href="#cite_note-204">[202]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/Azerbaijan" title="Azerbaijan">Republic of Azerbaijan</a> (611Â km or 380Â mi); to the north by the <a href="/wiki/Caspian_Sea" title="Caspian Sea">Caspian Sea</a>; to the northeast by <a href="/wiki/Turkmenistan" title="Turkmenistan">Turkmenistan</a> (992Â km or 616Â mi); to the east by <a href="/wiki/Afghanistan" title="Afghanistan">Afghanistan</a> (936Â km or 582Â mi) and Pakistan (909Â km or 565Â mi); to the south by the <a href="/wiki/Persian_Gulf" title="Persian Gulf">Persian Gulf</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Gulf_of_Oman" title="Gulf of Oman">Gulf of Oman</a>; and to the west by <a href="/wiki/Iraq" title="Iraq">Iraq</a> (1,458Â km or 906Â mi) and Turkey (499Â km or 310Â mi).
</p><p>Iran is located in a seismically active area.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-205"><a href="#cite_note-205">[203]</a></sup> On average, an earthquake of magnitude seven on the Richter scale occurs once every ten years.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-206"><a href="#cite_note-206">[204]</a></sup> Most earthquakes are shallow-focus and can be very devastating, such as the tragic <a href="/wiki/2003_Bam_earthquake" title="2003 Bam earthquake">2003 Bam earthquake</a>.
</p><p>Iran consists of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Iranian_Plateau" title="Iranian Plateau">Iranian Plateau</a>, with the exception of the coasts of the Caspian Sea and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Khuzestan_Province" title="Khuzestan Province">Khuzestan</a>. It is one of the world's most mountainous countries, its landscape dominated by rugged <a href="/wiki/Mountain_range" title="Mountain range">mountain ranges</a> that separate various <a href="/wiki/Drainage_basin" title="Drainage basin">basins</a> or <a href="/wiki/Plateau" title="Plateau">plateaus</a> from one another. The populous western part is the most mountainous, with ranges such as the <a href="/wiki/Caucasus_Mountains" title="Caucasus Mountains">Caucasus</a>, <a href="/wiki/Zagros_Mountains" title="Zagros Mountains">Zagros</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Alborz" title="Alborz">Alborz</a>, the last containing <a href="/wiki/Mount_Damavand" title="Mount Damavand">Mount Damavand</a>, Iran's highest point at 5,610Â m (18,406Â ft), which is also the highest mountain in Asia west of the <a href="/wiki/Hindu_Kush" title="Hindu Kush">Hindu Kush</a>.
</p><p>The northern part of Iran is covered by the lush lowland <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Caspian_Hyrcanian_mixed_forests" title="Caspian Hyrcanian mixed forests">Caspian Hyrcanian mixed forests</a>, located near the southern shores of the Caspian Sea. The eastern part consists mostly of <a href="/wiki/Desert" title="Desert">desert</a> basins, such as the <a href="/wiki/Dasht-e_Kavir" title="Dasht-e Kavir">Kavir Desert</a>, which is the country's largest desert, and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Dasht-e_Loot" title="Dasht-e Loot">Lut Desert</a>, as well as some <a href="/wiki/Salt_lake" title="Salt lake">salt lakes</a>. Iran had a 2019 <a href="/wiki/Forest_Landscape_Integrity_Index" title="Forest Landscape Integrity Index">Forest Landscape Integrity Index</a> mean score of 7.67/10, ranking it 34th globally out of 172 countries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FLII-Supplementary_207-0"><a href="#cite_note-FLII-Supplementary-207">[205]</a></sup>
The only large <a href="/wiki/Plain" title="Plain">plains</a> are found along the coast of the Caspian Sea and at the northern end of the Persian Gulf, where the country borders the mouth of the <a href="/wiki/Shatt_al-Arab" title="Shatt al-Arab">Arvand river</a>. Smaller, discontinuous plains are found along the remaining coast of the Persian Gulf, the <a href="/wiki/Strait_of_Hormuz" title="Strait of Hormuz">Strait of Hormuz</a>, and the Gulf of Oman.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Climate">Climate</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Koppen-Geiger_Map_IRN_present.svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="850" data-file-width="1456" decoding="async" height="128" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/00/Koppen-Geiger_Map_IRN_present.svg/220px-Koppen-Geiger_Map_IRN_present.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/00/Koppen-Geiger_Map_IRN_present.svg/330px-Koppen-Geiger_Map_IRN_present.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/00/Koppen-Geiger_Map_IRN_present.svg/440px-Koppen-Geiger_Map_IRN_present.svg.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Koppen-Geiger_Map_IRN_present.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Climate of Iran (<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/K%C3%B6ppen-Geiger" title="KÃ¶ppen-Geiger">KÃ¶ppen-Geiger</a>) <table style="width:100%;"> <tbody><tr> <td valign="top"><small><style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r981673959">.mw-parser-output .legend{page-break-inside:avoid;break-inside:avoid-column}.mw-parser-output .legend-color{display:inline-block;min-width:1.25em;height:1.25em;line-height:1.25;margin:1px 0;text-align:center;border:1px solid black;background-color:transparent;color:black}.mw-parser-output .legend-text{}</style><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#FF0000; color:black;">Â </span>Â <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hot_desert_climate" title="Hot desert climate">Hot desert climate</a></div><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#FF9696; color:black;">Â </span>Â <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cold_desert_climate" title="Cold desert climate">Cold desert climate</a></div><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#F5A500; color:black;">Â </span>Â <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hot_semi-arid_climate" title="Hot semi-arid climate">Hot semi-arid climate</a></div><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#FFDC64; color:black;">Â </span>Â <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cold_semi-arid_climate" title="Cold semi-arid climate">Cold semi-arid climate</a></div><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#FFFF00; color:black;">Â </span>Â <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hot-summer_Mediterranean_climate" title="Hot-summer Mediterranean climate">Hot-summer Mediterranean climate</a></div><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:#FF00FF; color:black;">Â </span>Â <a href="/wiki/Humid_continental_climate" title="Humid continental climate">Continental Mediterranean climate</a></div></small> </td></tr></tbody></table></div></div></div>
<p>Having 11 <a href="/wiki/Climate" title="Climate">climates</a> out of the world's 13, Iran's climate is diverse,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-en.journals.sid.ir_208-0"><a href="#cite_note-en.journals.sid.ir-208">[206]</a></sup> ranging from <a href="/wiki/Desert_climate" title="Desert climate">arid</a> and <a href="/wiki/Semi-arid_climate" title="Semi-arid climate">semi-arid</a>, to <a href="/wiki/Subtropics" title="Subtropics">subtropical</a> along the Caspian coast and the northern forests.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-HaftlangLang2003_209-0"><a href="#cite_note-HaftlangLang2003-209">[207]</a></sup> On the northern edge of the country (the Caspian coastal plain), temperatures rarely fall below freezing and the area remains humid for the rest of the year. Summer temperatures rarely exceed 29Â Â°C (84.2Â Â°F).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Nagarajan2010_210-0"><a href="#cite_note-Nagarajan2010-210">[208]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-211"><a href="#cite_note-211">[209]</a></sup> Annual precipitation is 680Â mm (26.8Â in) in the eastern part of the plain and more than 1,700Â mm (66.9Â in) in the western part. Gary Lewis, the United Nations Resident Coordinator for Iran, has said that "<a href="/wiki/Water_scarcity" title="Water scarcity">Water scarcity</a> poses the most severe human security challenge in Iran today".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-212"><a href="#cite_note-212">[210]</a></sup>
</p><p>To the west, settlements in the Zagros basin experience lower temperatures, severe winters with below zero average daily temperatures and heavy snowfall. The eastern and central basins are arid, with less than 200Â mm (7.9Â in) of rain, and have occasional deserts.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Nicholson2011_213-0"><a href="#cite_note-Nicholson2011-213">[211]</a></sup> Average summer temperatures rarely exceed 38Â Â°C (100.4Â Â°F).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Nagarajan2010_210-1"><a href="#cite_note-Nagarajan2010-210">[208]</a></sup> The coastal plains of the Persian Gulf and Gulf of Oman in southern Iran have mild winters, and very humid and hot summers. The annual precipitation ranges from 135 to 355Â mm (5.3 to 14.0Â in).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Nagarajan2010_210-2"><a href="#cite_note-Nagarajan2010-210">[208]</a></sup>
</p><p>Despite <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Climate_change_in_Iran" title="Climate change in Iran">climate change in the region</a>, Iran is by far the largest of the few countries in the world which have not ratified the <a href="/wiki/Paris_Agreement" title="Paris Agreement">Paris Agreement</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-214"><a href="#cite_note-214">[212]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Wildlife">Wildlife</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Wildlife_of_Iran" title="Wildlife of Iran">Wildlife of Iran</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Persian_Leopard_sitting.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1944" data-file-width="2592" decoding="async" height="135" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7d/Persian_Leopard_sitting.jpg/180px-Persian_Leopard_sitting.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7d/Persian_Leopard_sitting.jpg/270px-Persian_Leopard_sitting.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7d/Persian_Leopard_sitting.jpg/360px-Persian_Leopard_sitting.jpg 2x" width="180"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Persian_Leopard_sitting.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Persian_leopard" title="Persian leopard">Persian leopard</a>, listed as <a href="/wiki/Endangered_species" title="Endangered species">Endangered</a> on the <a href="/wiki/IUCN_Red_List" title="IUCN Red List">IUCN Red List</a></div></div></div>
<p>The wildlife of Iran includes <a href="/wiki/Bear" title="Bear">bears</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Eurasian_lynx" title="Eurasian lynx">Eurasian lynx</a>, <a href="/wiki/Fox" title="Fox">foxes</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gazelle" title="Gazelle">gazelles</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gray_wolf" title="Gray wolf">gray wolves</a>, <a href="/wiki/Golden_jackal" title="Golden jackal">jackals</a>, <a href="/wiki/Leopard" title="Leopard">panthers</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Wild_boar" title="Wild boar">wild pigs</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Fast2005_215-0"><a href="#cite_note-Fast2005-215">[213]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Firouz2005_216-0"><a href="#cite_note-Firouz2005-216">[214]</a></sup> Domestic animals include <a href="/wiki/Water_buffalo" title="Water buffalo">Asian water buffaloes</a>, <a href="/wiki/Camel" title="Camel">camels</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cattle" title="Cattle">cattle</a>, <a href="/wiki/Donkey" title="Donkey">donkeys</a>, <a href="/wiki/Goat" title="Goat">goats</a>, <a href="/wiki/Horse" title="Horse">horses</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Sheep" title="Sheep">sheep</a>. <a href="/wiki/Eagle" title="Eagle">Eagles</a>, <a href="/wiki/Falcon" title="Falcon">falcons</a>, <a href="/wiki/Partridge" title="Partridge">partridges</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pheasant" title="Pheasant">pheasants</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Stork" title="Stork">storks</a> are also native to Iran.
</p><p>One of the most famous species of animal is the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Critically_endangered" title="Critically endangered">critically endangered</a> <a href="/wiki/Asiatic_cheetah" title="Asiatic cheetah">Asiatic cheetah</a>, also known as the <i>Iranian cheetah</i>, whose numbers were greatly reduced after the 1979 Revolution.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Borrini-FeyerabendFarvar2013_217-0"><a href="#cite_note-Borrini-FeyerabendFarvar2013-217">[215]</a></sup> The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Persian_leopard" title="Persian leopard">Persian leopard</a>, which is the world's largest <a href="/wiki/Leopard" title="Leopard">leopard</a> subspecies and lives primarily in northern Iran, is also endangered.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-iucn_218-0"><a href="#cite_note-iucn-218">[216]</a></sup> Iran lost all its <a href="/wiki/Asiatic_lion" title="Asiatic lion">Asiatic lions</a> and the now extinct <a href="/wiki/Caspian_tiger" title="Caspian tiger">Caspian tigers</a> by the earlier part of the 20th century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-219"><a href="#cite_note-219">[217]</a></sup>
</p><p>At least 74 species of Iranian wildlife are on the red list of the <a href="/wiki/International_Union_for_Conservation_of_Nature" title="International Union for Conservation of Nature">International Union for Conservation of Nature</a>, a sign of serious threats against the country's biodiversity. The Iranian Parliament has been showing disregard for wildlife by passing laws and regulations such as the act that lets the <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Industries_and_Mines_(Iran)" title="Ministry of Industries and Mines (Iran)">Ministry of Industries and Mines</a> exploit mines without the involvement of the <a href="/wiki/Department_of_Environment_(Iran)" title="Department of Environment (Iran)">Department of Environment</a>, and by approving large national development projects without demanding comprehensive study of their impact on wildlife habitats.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-220"><a href="#cite_note-220">[218]</a></sup>
</p><p><span class="anchor" id="Provinces_and_cities"></span><span class="anchor" id="Regions,_provinces_and_cities"></span><span class="anchor" id="Subdivisions"></span><span class="anchor" id="Administrative_divisions"></span>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Administrative_divisions">Administrative divisions</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Regions_of_Iran" title="Regions of Iran">Regions of Iran</a>, <a href="/wiki/Provinces_of_Iran" title="Provinces of Iran">Provinces of Iran</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Counties_of_Iran" title="Counties of Iran">Counties of Iran</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_Iranian_cities_by_population" title="List of Iranian cities by population">List of Iranian cities by population</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_cities_in_Iran_by_province" title="List of cities in Iran by province">List of cities in Iran by province</a></div>
<table class="wikitable" style="float: right; margin-left: 1em; clear: right; font-size: 88%">
