</div>
</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Iran is divided into <a href="/wiki/Regions_of_Iran" title="Regions of Iran">five regions</a> with <a href="/wiki/Provinces_of_Iran" title="Provinces of Iran">31 provinces</a> (<span title="Persian-language text"><i lang="fa-Latn">ostÄn</i></span>, <span title="Persian-language text"><span dir="rtl" lang="fa">Ø§Ø³ØªØ§Ù</span></span>),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-221"><a href="#cite_note-221">[219]</a></sup> each governed by an appointed governor (<span title="Persian-language text"><i lang="fa-Latn">ostÄndÄr</i></span>, <span title="Persian-language text"><span dir="rtl" lang="fa">Ø§Ø³ØªØ§ÙØ¯Ø§Ø±</span></span>). The provinces are divided into <a href="/wiki/Counties_of_Iran" title="Counties of Iran">counties</a> (<span title="Persian-language text"><i lang="fa-Latn">Å¡ahrestÄn</i></span>, <span title="Persian-language text"><span dir="rtl" lang="fa">Ø´ÙØ±Ø³ØªØ§Ù</span></span>), and subdivided into districts (<span title="Persian-language text"><i lang="fa-Latn"><a href="/wiki/Bakhsh" title="Bakhsh">baxÅ¡</a></i></span>, <span title="Persian-language text"><span dir="rtl" lang="fa">Ø¨Ø®Ø´</span></span>) and sub-districts (<span title="Persian-language text"><i lang="fa-Latn">dehestÄn</i></span>, <span title="Persian-language text"><span dir="rtl" lang="fa">Ø¯ÙØ³ØªØ§Ù</span></span>).
</p><p>The country has one of the highest urban growth rates in the world. From 1950 to 2002, the urban proportion of the population increased from 27% to 60%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-payvand2_222-0"><a href="#cite_note-payvand2-222">[220]</a></sup> Most internal migrants have settled around the cities of <a href="/wiki/Tehran" title="Tehran">Tehran</a>, <a href="/wiki/Isfahan" title="Isfahan">Isfahan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ahvaz" title="Ahvaz">Ahvaz</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Qom" title="Qom">Qom</a>. The listed populations are from the 2006/07 (1385Â <a href="/wiki/Iranian_calendars" title="Iranian calendars">AP</a>) census.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-223"><a href="#cite_note-223">[221]</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability" title="Wikipedia:Verifiability"><span title="The material near this tag failed verification of its source citation(s). (June 2013)">failed verification</span></a></i>]</sup>
</p><p>Iran's population is concentrated in its western half, especially in the north, north-west and west of the country.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-224"><a href="#cite_note-224">[222]</a></sup>
</p><p>Tehran, with a population of around 8.8 million (2016 census), is Iran's capital and largest city. It is an economical and cultural center, and is the hub of the country's <a href="/wiki/Communications_in_Iran" title="Communications in Iran">communication</a> and <a href="/wiki/Transport_in_Iran" title="Transport in Iran">transport</a> network.
</p><p>The country's second most populous city, <a href="/wiki/Mashhad" title="Mashhad">Mashhad</a>, has a population of around 3.3 million (2016 census), and is capital of the province of <a href="/wiki/Razavi_Khorasan_province" title="Razavi Khorasan province">Razavi Khorasan</a>. Being the site of the <a href="/wiki/Imam_Reza_shrine" title="Imam Reza shrine">Imam Reza shrine</a>, it is a holy city in <a href="/wiki/Shia_Islam" title="Shia Islam">Shia Islam</a>. About 15 to 20 million pilgrims visit the shrine every year.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-225"><a href="#cite_note-225">[223]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-226"><a href="#cite_note-226">[224]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="center"><div class="thumb tnone"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:402px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:The_most_populated_cities_of_iran.svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="800" data-file-width="900" decoding="async" height="356" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/14/The_most_populated_cities_of_iran.svg/400px-The_most_populated_cities_of_iran.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/14/The_most_populated_cities_of_iran.svg/600px-The_most_populated_cities_of_iran.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/14/The_most_populated_cities_of_iran.svg/800px-The_most_populated_cities_of_iran.svg.png 2x" width="400"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:The_most_populated_cities_of_iran.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Map showing locations for Iran's most populated cities as of 2010</div></div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Isfahan" title="Isfahan">Isfahan</a> has a population of around 2.2 million (2016 census), and is Iran's third most populous city. It is the capital of <a href="/wiki/Isfahan_province" title="Isfahan province">Isfahan province</a>, and was also the third capital of the <a href="/wiki/Safavid_dynasty" title="Safavid dynasty">Safavid Empire</a>. It is home to a wide variety of historical sites, including the famous <a href="/wiki/Naqsh-e_Jahan_Square" title="Naqsh-e Jahan Square">Shah Square</a>, <a href="/wiki/Si-o-se-pol" title="Si-o-se-pol">Siosepol</a>, and the churches at the Armenian district of <a href="/wiki/New_Julfa" title="New Julfa">New Julfa</a>. It is also home to <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_largest_shopping_malls" title="List of largest shopping malls">one of the world's largest shopping malls</a>, <a href="/wiki/Isfahan_City_Center" title="Isfahan City Center">Isfahan City Center</a>.
</p><p>The fourth most populous city of Iran, <a href="/wiki/Karaj" title="Karaj">Karaj</a>, has a population of around 1.9 million (2016 census). It is the capital of <a href="/wiki/Alborz_province" title="Alborz province">Alborz province</a>, and is situated 20Â km (12 miles) west of Tehran, at the foot of the <a href="/wiki/Alborz" title="Alborz">Alborz</a> mountain range. It is a major industrial city in Iran, with large factories producing sugar, textiles, wire, and alcohol.
</p><p>With a population of around 1.7 million (2016 census), <a href="/wiki/Tabriz" title="Tabriz">Tabriz</a> is the fifth most populous city of Iran, and had been the second most populous until the late 1960s. It was the first capital of the Safavid Empire and is now the capital of the province of <a href="/wiki/East_Azerbaijan_province" title="East Azerbaijan province">East Azerbaijan</a>. It is also considered the country's second major industrial city (after Tehran).
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Shiraz" title="Shiraz">Shiraz</a>, with a population of around 1.8 million (2016 census), is Iran's sixth most populous city. It is the capital of the province of <a href="/wiki/Fars_province" title="Fars province">Fars</a>, and was also the capital of Iran under the reign of the <a href="/wiki/Zand_dynasty" title="Zand dynasty">Zand dynasty</a>. It is located near the ruins of <a href="/wiki/Persepolis" title="Persepolis">Persepolis</a> and <a href="/wiki/Pasargadae" title="Pasargadae">Pasargadae</a>, two of the four capitals of the <a href="/wiki/Achaemenid_Empire" title="Achaemenid Empire">Achaemenid Empire</a>.
</p>
<div>

<p><br/>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Government_and_politics">Government and politics</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Politics_of_Iran" title="Politics of Iran">Politics of Iran</a> and <a href="/wiki/Government_of_the_Islamic_Republic_of_Iran" title="Government of the Islamic Republic of Iran">Government of the Islamic Republic of Iran</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Iran_gov_power_structure.svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="522" data-file-width="996" decoding="async" height="115" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/33/Iran_gov_power_structure.svg/220px-Iran_gov_power_structure.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/33/Iran_gov_power_structure.svg/330px-Iran_gov_power_structure.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/33/Iran_gov_power_structure.svg/440px-Iran_gov_power_structure.svg.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Iran_gov_power_structure.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Iran's syncretic political system combines elements of an Islamic theocracy with vetted democracy.</div></div></div>
<p>The political system of the Islamic Republic is based on the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Constitution_of_the_Islamic_Republic_of_Iran" title="Constitution of the Islamic Republic of Iran">1979 Constitution</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-servcons_227-0"><a href="#cite_note-servcons-227">[225]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Juan_Jos%C3%A9_Linz" title="Juan JosÃ© Linz">Juan JosÃ© Linz</a> wrote in 2000 that "it is difficult to fit the Iranian regime into the existing typology, as it combines the ideological bent of <a href="/wiki/Totalitarianism" title="Totalitarianism">totalitarianism</a> with the limited pluralism of <a href="/wiki/Authoritarianism" title="Authoritarianism">authoritarianism</a> and holds regular elections in which candidates advocating differing policies and incumbents are often defeated".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-228"><a href="#cite_note-228">[226]</a></sup> However, Iran scored lower than Saudi Arabia in the 2021 <a href="/wiki/Democracy_Index" title="Democracy Index">Democracy Index</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-229"><a href="#cite_note-229">[227]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Supreme_Leader">Supreme Leader</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ali_Khamenei_met_with_Xi_Jinping_in_Tehran_2016_(1).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1333" data-file-width="2000" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/Ali_Khamenei_met_with_Xi_Jinping_in_Tehran_2016_%281%29.jpg/220px-Ali_Khamenei_met_with_Xi_Jinping_in_Tehran_2016_%281%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/Ali_Khamenei_met_with_Xi_Jinping_in_Tehran_2016_%281%29.jpg/330px-Ali_Khamenei_met_with_Xi_Jinping_in_Tehran_2016_%281%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/Ali_Khamenei_met_with_Xi_Jinping_in_Tehran_2016_%281%29.jpg/440px-Ali_Khamenei_met_with_Xi_Jinping_in_Tehran_2016_%281%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Ali_Khamenei_met_with_Xi_Jinping_in_Tehran_2016_(1).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Ali_Khamenei" title="Ali Khamenei">Ali Khamenei</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Supreme_Leader_of_Iran" title="Supreme Leader of Iran">Supreme Leader of Iran</a>, meeting with his counterpart, China's <a href="/wiki/Paramount_leader" title="Paramount leader">paramount leader</a> <a href="/wiki/Xi_Jinping" title="Xi Jinping">Xi Jinping</a> on 23 January 2016. Iran and China are <a href="/wiki/China%E2%80%93Iran_relations" title="ChinaâIran relations">strategic allies</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-230"><a href="#cite_note-230">[228]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-231"><a href="#cite_note-231">[229]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Supreme_Leader_of_Iran" title="Supreme Leader of Iran">Leader of the Revolution</a> ("Supreme Leader") is responsible for delineation and supervision of the policies of the Islamic Republic of Iran.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-leader_232-0"><a href="#cite_note-leader-232">[230]</a></sup> The Iranian president has limited power compared to the Supreme Leader Khamenei.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-reuters.com_233-0"><a href="#cite_note-reuters.com-233">[231]</a></sup> The current longtime Supreme Leader, <a href="/wiki/Ali_Khamenei" title="Ali Khamenei">Ali Khamenei</a>, has been issuing decrees and making the final decisions on the economy, environment, foreign policy, education, national planning, and everything else in the country.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-english.aawsat.com_234-0"><a href="#cite_note-english.aawsat.com-234">[232]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Middle_East_Eye_235-0"><a href="#cite_note-Middle_East_Eye-235">[233]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-al-monitor.com_236-0"><a href="#cite_note-al-monitor.com-236">[234]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Louis_Charbonneau_and_Parisa_Hafezi_237-0"><a href="#cite_note-Louis_Charbonneau_and_Parisa_Hafezi-237">[235]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-en.iranwire.com_238-0"><a href="#cite_note-en.iranwire.com-238">[236]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-irpop_239-0"><a href="#cite_note-irpop-239">[237]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-payjul_240-0"><a href="#cite_note-payjul-240">[238]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-241"><a href="#cite_note-241">[239]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Ali_Khamenei" title="Ali Khamenei">Khamenei</a> also outlines elections guidelines and urges for the transparency,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-tehtrans_242-0"><a href="#cite_note-tehtrans-242">[240]</a></sup> and has fired and reinstated presidential cabinet appointments.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-stalbertgazette.com_243-0"><a href="#cite_note-stalbertgazette.com-243">[241]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-news.bbc.co.uk_244-0"><a href="#cite_note-news.bbc.co.uk-244">[242]</a></sup> Key ministers are selected with the Supreme Leader Ali Khamenei's agreement and he has the ultimate say on Iran's foreign policy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-reuters.com_233-1"><a href="#cite_note-reuters.com-233">[231]</a></sup> The president-elect is required to gain the Leader Khamenei's official approval before being sworn in before the Parliament (Majlis). Through this process, known as Tanfiz (validation), the Leader agrees to the outcome of the presidential election.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (November 2020)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> The Supreme Leader is directly involved in ministerial appointments for Defense, Intelligence and Foreign Affairs, as well as other top ministries after submission of candidates from the president.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MagriPerteghella2017_245-0"><a href="#cite_note-MagriPerteghella2017-245">[243]</a></sup> Iran's regional policy is directly controlled by the office of the Supreme Leader with the Ministry of Foreign Affairs' task limited to protocol and ceremonial occasions. All of Iran's ambassadors to Arab countries, for example, are chosen by the Quds Corps, which directly reports to the Supreme Leader.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-english.aawsat.com_234-1"><a href="#cite_note-english.aawsat.com-234">[232]</a></sup> The budget bill for every year, as well as withdrawing money from the <a href="/wiki/National_Development_Fund_of_Iran" title="National Development Fund of Iran">National Development Fund of Iran</a>, require Supreme Leader Ali Khamenei's approval and permission.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (November 2020)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> The Supreme Leader Khamenei can and did order laws to be amended.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-246"><a href="#cite_note-246">[244]</a></sup> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Setad" title="Setad">Setad</a>, estimated at $95 billion in 2013 by the Reuters, accounts of which are secret even to the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Iranian_parliament" title="Iranian parliament">Iranian parliament</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-247"><a href="#cite_note-247">[245]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-StephensOpinion_248-0"><a href="#cite_note-StephensOpinion-248">[246]</a></sup> is controlled only by the Supreme Leader.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-249"><a href="#cite_note-249">[247]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SetadWins_250-0"><a href="#cite_note-SetadWins-250">[248]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ali_Khamenei_voting_in_the_2017_Presidential_election20.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1600" data-file-width="2400" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b3/Ali_Khamenei_voting_in_the_2017_Presidential_election20.jpg/220px-Ali_Khamenei_voting_in_the_2017_Presidential_election20.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b3/Ali_Khamenei_voting_in_the_2017_Presidential_election20.jpg/330px-Ali_Khamenei_voting_in_the_2017_Presidential_election20.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b3/Ali_Khamenei_voting_in_the_2017_Presidential_election20.jpg/440px-Ali_Khamenei_voting_in_the_2017_Presidential_election20.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Ali_Khamenei_voting_in_the_2017_Presidential_election20.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Ali Khamenei voting in the 2017 presidential election</div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Supreme_Leader_of_Iran" title="Supreme Leader of Iran">Supreme Leader</a> is the <a href="/wiki/Commander-in-chief" title="Commander-in-chief">commander-in-chief</a> of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Armed_Forces_of_the_Islamic_Republic_of_Iran" title="Armed Forces of the Islamic Republic of Iran">armed forces</a>, controls the military intelligence and security operations, and has sole power to declare war or peace.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-leader_232-1"><a href="#cite_note-leader-232">[230]</a></sup> The heads of the judiciary, the state radio and television networks, the commanders of the police and military forces, and six of the twelve members of the <a href="/wiki/Guardian_Council" title="Guardian Council">Guardian Council</a> are directly appointed by the Supreme Leader.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-leader_232-2"><a href="#cite_note-leader-232">[230]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Assembly_of_Experts" title="Assembly of Experts">Assembly of Experts</a> is responsible for electing the Supreme Leader, and has the power to dismiss him on the basis of qualifications and popular esteem.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-loc_251-0"><a href="#cite_note-loc-251">[249]</a></sup> To date, the Assembly of Experts has not challenged any of the Supreme Leader's decisions, nor has it attempted to dismiss him.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Judiciary_252-0"><a href="#cite_note-Judiciary-252">[250]</a></sup> The previous head of the judicial system, <a href="/wiki/Sadeq_Larijani" title="Sadeq Larijani">Sadeq Larijani</a>, appointed by the <a href="/wiki/Supreme_Leader_of_Iran" title="Supreme Leader of Iran">Supreme Leader</a>, said that it is illegal for the Assembly of Experts to supervise the Supreme Leader.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Al-awsat_253-0"><a href="#cite_note-Al-awsat-253">[251]</a></sup> Due to <a href="/wiki/Ali_Khamenei" title="Ali Khamenei">Khamenei</a>'s very longtime unchallenged rule, many believe the Assembly of Experts has become a ceremonial body without any real power.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-254"><a href="#cite_note-254">[252]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-255"><a href="#cite_note-255">[253]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-256"><a href="#cite_note-256">[254]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-257"><a href="#cite_note-257">[255]</a></sup> There have been instances when the current Supreme Leader publicly criticized members of the Assembly of Experts, resulting in their arrest and dismissal. For example, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Khamenei" title="Khamenei">Khamenei</a> publicly called then-member of the Assembly of Experts <a href="/wiki/Ahmad_Azari_Qomi" title="Ahmad Azari Qomi">Ahmad Azari Qomi</a> a traitor, resulting in Qomi's arrest and eventual dismissal from the Assembly of Experts. Another instance is when Khamenei indirectly called <a href="/wiki/Akbar_Hashemi_Rafsanjani" title="Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani">Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani</a> a traitor for a statement he made, causing Rafsanjani to retract it.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-258"><a href="#cite_note-258">[256]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Guardian_Council">Guardian Council</span></h3>
<p>Presidential candidates and parliamentary candidates must be approved by the <a href="/wiki/Guardian_Council" title="Guardian Council">Guardian Council</a> (all members of which are directly or indirectly appointed by the Leader) or the Leader before running to ensure their allegiance to the <a href="/wiki/Supreme_Leader_of_Iran" title="Supreme Leader of Iran">Supreme Leader</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-259"><a href="#cite_note-259">[257]</a></sup> The Leader very rarely does the vetting himself directly but has the power to do so, in which case additional approval of the Guardian Council would not be needed. The Leader can also revert the decisions of the Guardian Council.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-260"><a href="#cite_note-260">[258]</a></sup> The Guardian Council can, and has dismissed some elected members of the Iranian parliament in the past.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-261"><a href="#cite_note-261">[259]</a></sup> For example, <a href="/wiki/Minoo_Khaleghi" title="Minoo Khaleghi">Minoo Khaleghi</a> was disqualified by Guardian Council even after winning election, as she had been photographed in a meeting without wearing headscarf.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-262"><a href="#cite_note-262">[260]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="President">President</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Hassan_Rouhani_and_Vladimir_Putin_(1).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="780" data-file-width="1200" decoding="async" height="143" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/75/Hassan_Rouhani_and_Vladimir_Putin_%281%29.jpg/220px-Hassan_Rouhani_and_Vladimir_Putin_%281%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/75/Hassan_Rouhani_and_Vladimir_Putin_%281%29.jpg/330px-Hassan_Rouhani_and_Vladimir_Putin_%281%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/75/Hassan_Rouhani_and_Vladimir_Putin_%281%29.jpg/440px-Hassan_Rouhani_and_Vladimir_Putin_%281%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Hassan_Rouhani_and_Vladimir_Putin_(1).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Iranian former President <a href="/wiki/Hassan_Rouhani" title="Hassan Rouhani">Hassan Rouhani</a> meeting with Russian President <a href="/wiki/Vladimir_Putin" title="Vladimir Putin">Vladimir Putin</a>. Iran and Russia are strategic allies.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-263"><a href="#cite_note-263">[261]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-264"><a href="#cite_note-264">[262]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-265"><a href="#cite_note-265">[263]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>After the Supreme Leader, the Constitution defines the <a href="/wiki/President_of_Iran" title="President of Iran">President of Iran</a> as the highest state authority.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-leader_232-3"><a href="#cite_note-leader-232">[230]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-photius_266-0"><a href="#cite_note-photius-266">[264]</a></sup> The President is elected by <a href="/wiki/Universal_suffrage" title="Universal suffrage">universal suffrage</a> for a term of four years, however, the president is still required to gain the Leader's official approval before being sworn in before the Parliament (Majlis). The Leader also has the power to dismiss the elected president anytime.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-267"><a href="#cite_note-267">[265]</a></sup> The President can only be re-elected for one term.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-photius_266-1"><a href="#cite_note-photius-266">[264]</a></sup>
</p><p>The President is responsible for the implementation of the constitution, and for the exercise of executive powers in implementing the decrees and general policies as outlined by the Supreme Leader, except for matters directly related to the Supreme Leader, who has the final say in all matters.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-leader_232-4"><a href="#cite_note-leader-232">[230]</a></sup> Unlike the executive in other countries, the President of Iran does not have full control over anything, as these are ultimately under the control of the Supreme Leader.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-servcons_227-1"><a href="#cite_note-servcons-227">[225]</a></sup> Chapter IX of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Constitution_of_the_Islamic_Republic_of_Iran" title="Constitution of the Islamic Republic of Iran">Constitution of the Islamic Republic of Iran</a> sets forth the qualifications for presidential candidates. The procedures for presidential election and all other elections in Iran are outlined by the Supreme Leader.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-tehtrans_242-1"><a href="#cite_note-tehtrans-242">[240]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Mahmoud_Ahmadinejad_268-0"><a href="#cite_note-Mahmoud_Ahmadinejad-268">[266]</a></sup> The President functions as the executive of affairs such as signing treaties and other international agreements, and administering national planning, budget, and state employment affairs, all as approved by the Supreme Leader.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Middle_East_Eye_235-1"><a href="#cite_note-Middle_East_Eye-235">[233]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-al-monitor.com_236-1"><a href="#cite_note-al-monitor.com-236">[234]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Mahmoud_Ahmadinejad_268-1"><a href="#cite_note-Mahmoud_Ahmadinejad-268">[266]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Louis_Charbonneau_and_Parisa_Hafezi_237-1"><a href="#cite_note-Louis_Charbonneau_and_Parisa_Hafezi-237">[235]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-en.iranwire.com_238-1"><a href="#cite_note-en.iranwire.com-238">[236]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-irpop_239-1"><a href="#cite_note-irpop-239">[237]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-payjul_240-1"><a href="#cite_note-payjul-240">[238]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-269"><a href="#cite_note-269">[267]</a></sup>
</p><p>The President appoints the ministers, subject to the approval of the Parliament, as well as the approval of the Supreme Leader, who can dismiss or reinstate any of the ministers at any time, regardless of the decisions made by the President or the Parliament.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-stalbertgazette.com_243-1"><a href="#cite_note-stalbertgazette.com-243">[241]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-news.bbc.co.uk_244-1"><a href="#cite_note-news.bbc.co.uk-244">[242]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-270"><a href="#cite_note-270">[268]</a></sup> The President supervises the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Council_of_Ministers_of_Iran" title="Council of Ministers of Iran">Council of Ministers</a>, coordinates government decisions, and selects government policies to be placed before the legislature.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-271"><a href="#cite_note-271">[269]</a></sup> The current Supreme Leader, Ali Khamenei, has fired as well as reinstated Council of Ministers members.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-272"><a href="#cite_note-272">[270]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-273"><a href="#cite_note-273">[271]</a></sup> Eight Vice Presidents serve under the President, as well as a cabinet of twenty-two ministers, who must all be approved by the legislature.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-274"><a href="#cite_note-274">[272]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Legislature">Legislature</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Iranian_Majlis.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="583" data-file-width="900" decoding="async" height="143" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4a/Iranian_Majlis.jpg/220px-Iranian_Majlis.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4a/Iranian_Majlis.jpg/330px-Iranian_Majlis.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4a/Iranian_Majlis.jpg/440px-Iranian_Majlis.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Iranian_Majlis.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Islamic_Consultative_Assembly" title="Islamic Consultative Assembly">Islamic Consultative Assembly</a>, also known as the <i>Iranian Parliament</i></div></div></div>
<p>The legislature of Iran, known as the <i><a href="/wiki/Islamic_Consultative_Assembly" title="Islamic Consultative Assembly">Islamic Consultative Assembly</a></i>, is a <a href="/wiki/Unicameralism" title="Unicameralism">unicameral</a> body comprising 290 members elected for four-year terms.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Majlis_275-0"><a href="#cite_note-Majlis-275">[273]</a></sup> It drafts legislation, ratifies international <a href="/wiki/Treaty" title="Treaty">treaties</a>, and approves the national budget. All parliamentary candidates and all legislation from the assembly must be approved by the Guardian Council.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-276"><a href="#cite_note-276">[274]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Guardian Council comprises twelve jurists, including six appointed by the Supreme Leader. Others are elected by the Parliament, from among the jurists nominated by the Head of the <a href="/wiki/Judicial_system_of_the_Islamic_Republic_of_Iran" title="Judicial system of the Islamic Republic of Iran">Judiciary</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-autogenerated4_277-0"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated4-277">[275]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-278"><a href="#cite_note-278">[276]</a></sup> The Council interprets the constitution and may veto the Parliament. If a law is deemed incompatible with the constitution or <a href="/wiki/Sharia" title="Sharia">Sharia</a> (Islamic law), it is referred back to the Parliament for revision.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-photius_266-2"><a href="#cite_note-photius-266">[264]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Expediency_Discernment_Council" title="Expediency Discernment Council">Expediency Council</a> has the authority to mediate disputes between the Parliament and the Guardian Council, and serves as an advisory body to the Supreme Leader, making it one of the most powerful governing bodies in the country.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-279"><a href="#cite_note-279">[277]</a></sup> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/City_and_Village_Councils_of_Iran" title="City and Village Councils of Iran">Local city councils</a> are elected by public vote to four-year terms in all cities and villages of Iran.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Law">Law</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Judicial_system_of_the_Islamic_Republic_of_Iran" title="Judicial system of the Islamic Republic of Iran">Judicial system of the Islamic Republic of Iran</a></div>
<p>The Supreme Leader appoints the head of the country's judiciary, appointing the head of the Supreme Court and the chief public prosecutor.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Judiciary_252-1"><a href="#cite_note-Judiciary-252">[250]</a></sup> There are several types of courts, including public courts that deal with civil and criminal cases, and <a href="/wiki/Islamic_Revolutionary_Court" title="Islamic Revolutionary Court">revolutionary courts</a> which deal with certain categories of offenses, such as crimes against <a href="/wiki/National_security" title="National security">national security</a>. The decisions of the revolutionary courts are final and cannot be appealed.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Judiciary_252-2"><a href="#cite_note-Judiciary-252">[250]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Chief Justice of Iran is the head of the Judicial system of the Islamic Republic of Iran and is responsible for its administration and supervision. He is also the highest judge of the <a href="/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_Iran" title="Supreme Court of Iran">Supreme Court of Iran</a>. The Supreme Leader of Iran appoints and can dismiss the Chief Justice. The Chief Justice nominates some candidates for serving as minister of justice, and then the President select one of them. The Chief Justice can serve for two five-year terms.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-280"><a href="#cite_note-280">[278]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Special_Clerical_Court" title="Special Clerical Court">Special Clerical Court</a> handles crimes allegedly committed by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cleric" title="Cleric">clerics</a>, although it has also taken on cases involving <a href="/wiki/Laity" title="Laity">laypeople</a>. The Special Clerical Court functions independently of the regular judicial framework, and is accountable only to the <a href="/wiki/Supreme_Leader_of_Iran" title="Supreme Leader of Iran">Supreme Leader</a>. The Court's rulings are final and cannot be appealed.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Judiciary_252-3"><a href="#cite_note-Judiciary-252">[250]</a></sup> The Assembly of Experts, which meets for one week annually, comprises 86 "virtuous and learned" clerics elected by adult suffrage for eight-year terms.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Foreign_relations">Foreign relations</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Foreign_relations_of_Iran" title="Foreign relations of Iran">Foreign relations of Iran</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Iran_Saudi_conflict_2022.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3316" data-file-width="7192" decoding="async" height="101" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7d/Iran_Saudi_conflict_2022.png/220px-Iran_Saudi_conflict_2022.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7d/Iran_Saudi_conflict_2022.png/330px-Iran_Saudi_conflict_2022.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7d/Iran_Saudi_conflict_2022.png/440px-Iran_Saudi_conflict_2022.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Iran_Saudi_conflict_2022.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend" style="text-align:left;"><span class="legend-color" style="background-color:#EC1C24; color:black; -webkit-column-break-inside: avoid;">Â </span>Â Current <a href="/wiki/Iran%E2%80%93Saudi_Arabia_proxy_conflict" title="IranâSaudi Arabia proxy conflict">IranâSaudi Arabia proxy conflict</a> across several regions</div></div></div></div>
<p>Since the time of the 1979 Revolution, Iran's foreign relations have often been portrayed as being based on two strategic principles: eliminating outside influences in the region, and pursuing extensive diplomatic contacts with developing and <a href="/wiki/Non-Aligned_Movement" title="Non-Aligned Movement">non-aligned countries</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-281"><a href="#cite_note-281">[279]</a></sup>
</p><p>Since 2005, <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_program_of_Iran" title="Nuclear program of Iran">Iran's nuclear program</a> has become the subject of contention with the international community, mainly the United States. Many countries have expressed concern that Iran's nuclear program could divert civilian nuclear technology into a <a href="/wiki/Iran_and_weapons_of_mass_destruction" title="Iran and weapons of mass destruction">weapons program</a>. This has led the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Security_Council" title="United Nations Security Council">United Nations Security Council</a> to impose <a href="/wiki/Sanctions_against_Iran" title="Sanctions against Iran">sanctions against Iran</a> which had further isolated Iran politically and economically from the rest of the global community. In 2009, the U.S. <a href="/wiki/Director_of_National_Intelligence" title="Director of National Intelligence">Director of National Intelligence</a> said that Iran, if choosing to, would not be able to develop a nuclear weapon until 2013.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-282"><a href="#cite_note-282">[280]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Demonstrations_and_protests_against_United_States_recognition_of_Jerusalem_in_Tehran_032.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="537" data-file-width="745" decoding="async" height="159" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/97/Demonstrations_and_protests_against_United_States_recognition_of_Jerusalem_in_Tehran_032.jpg/220px-Demonstrations_and_protests_against_United_States_recognition_of_Jerusalem_in_Tehran_032.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/97/Demonstrations_and_protests_against_United_States_recognition_of_Jerusalem_in_Tehran_032.jpg/330px-Demonstrations_and_protests_against_United_States_recognition_of_Jerusalem_in_Tehran_032.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/97/Demonstrations_and_protests_against_United_States_recognition_of_Jerusalem_in_Tehran_032.jpg/440px-Demonstrations_and_protests_against_United_States_recognition_of_Jerusalem_in_Tehran_032.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Demonstrations_and_protests_against_United_States_recognition_of_Jerusalem_in_Tehran_032.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Protest against <a href="/wiki/United_States_recognition_of_Jerusalem_as_capital_of_Israel" title="United States recognition of Jerusalem as capital of Israel">U.S. recognition of Jerusalem as capital of Israel</a>. Tehran, 11 December 2017.</div></div></div>
<p>As of 2009<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Iran&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, the government of Iran maintains diplomatic relations with 99 members of the United Nations,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-283"><a href="#cite_note-283">[281]</a></sup> but not with the <a href="/wiki/Iran%E2%80%93United_States_relations" title="IranâUnited States relations">United States</a>, and not with <a href="/wiki/Iran%E2%80%93Israel_relations" title="IranâIsrael relations">Israel</a>âa state which Iran's government has derecognized since the 1979 Revolution.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MousavianShahidsaless2014_284-0"><a href="#cite_note-MousavianShahidsaless2014-284">[282]</a></sup> Among Muslim nations, Iran has an adversarial relationship with <a href="/wiki/Iran%E2%80%93Saudi_Arabia_relations" title="IranâSaudi Arabia relations">Saudi Arabia</a> due to different political and Islamic ideologies. While Iran is a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Shia" title="Shia">Shia</a> Islamic Republic, Saudi Arabia is a conservative <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sunni" title="Sunni">Sunni</a> monarchy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-285"><a href="#cite_note-285">[283]</a></sup> Regarding the <a href="/wiki/Israeli%E2%80%93Palestinian_conflict" title="IsraeliâPalestinian conflict">IsraeliâPalestinian conflict</a>, the government of Iran has recognized <a href="/wiki/Jerusalem" title="Jerusalem">Jerusalem</a> as the capital of the <a href="/wiki/State_of_Palestine" title="State of Palestine">State of Palestine</a>, after Trump recognized Jerusalem as the capital of Israel.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-286"><a href="#cite_note-286">[284]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-287"><a href="#cite_note-287">[285]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-288"><a href="#cite_note-288">[286]</a></sup>
</p><p>Since the 2000s, Iran's controversial <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_program_of_Iran" title="Nuclear program of Iran">nuclear program</a> has <a href="/wiki/Views_on_the_nuclear_program_of_Iran" title="Views on the nuclear program of Iran">raised concerns</a>, which is part of the basis of the <a href="/wiki/Sanctions_against_Iran" title="Sanctions against Iran">international sanctions against the country</a>. On 14 July 2015, Tehran and the <a href="/wiki/P5%2B1" title="P5+1">P5+1</a> came to a historic <a href="/wiki/Joint_Comprehensive_Plan_of_Action" title="Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action">agreement</a> (<i>Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action</i>) to end <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Security_Council_Resolution_1929" title="United Nations Security Council Resolution 1929">economic sanctions</a> in exchange for Iran's restriction in producing <a href="/wiki/Enriched_uranium" title="Enriched uranium">enriched uranium</a> after demonstrating a peaceful nuclear research project that would meet the <a href="/wiki/International_Atomic_Energy_Agency" title="International Atomic Energy Agency">International Atomic Energy Agency</a> standards.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-289"><a href="#cite_note-289">[287]</a></sup>
</p><p>Iran is a member of dozens of international organizations, including the <a href="/wiki/Group_of_15" title="Group of 15">G-15</a>, <a href="/wiki/Group_of_24" title="Group of 24">G-24</a>, <a href="/wiki/Group_of_77" title="Group of 77">G-77</a>, <a href="/wiki/International_Atomic_Energy_Agency" title="International Atomic Energy Agency">IAEA</a>, <a href="/wiki/International_Bank_for_Reconstruction_and_Development" title="International Bank for Reconstruction and Development">IBRD</a>, <a href="/wiki/International_Development_Association" title="International Development Association">IDA</a>, <a href="/wiki/Islamic_Development_Bank" title="Islamic Development Bank">IDB</a>, <a href="/wiki/International_Finance_Corporation" title="International Finance Corporation">IFC</a>, <a href="/wiki/International_Labour_Organization" title="International Labour Organization">ILO</a>, <a href="/wiki/International_Monetary_Fund" title="International Monetary Fund">IMF</a>, <a href="/wiki/International_Maritime_Organization" title="International Maritime Organization">IMO</a>, <a href="/wiki/Interpol" title="Interpol">Interpol</a>, <a href="/wiki/Organisation_of_Islamic_Cooperation" title="Organisation of Islamic Cooperation">OIC</a>, <a href="/wiki/OPEC" title="OPEC">OPEC</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-rubin80_290-0"><a href="#cite_note-rubin80-290">[288]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/World_Health_Organization" title="World Health Organization">WHO</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations" title="United Nations">United Nations</a>, and currently has observer status at the <a href="/wiki/World_Trade_Organization" title="World Trade Organization">World Trade Organization</a>.
</p><p>On 17 September 2021 Iran began the processes of becoming a full member of the <a href="/wiki/Shanghai_Cooperation_Organisation" title="Shanghai Cooperation Organisation">Shanghai Cooperation Organization</a> (SCO), a <a href="/wiki/Eurasia" title="Eurasia">Eurasian</a> <a href="/wiki/Politics" title="Politics">political</a>, <a href="/wiki/Economy" title="Economy">economic</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Security" title="Security">security</a> alliance.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-291"><a href="#cite_note-291">[289]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-292"><a href="#cite_note-292">[290]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Military">Military</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Armed_Forces_of_the_Islamic_Republic_of_Iran" title="Armed Forces of the Islamic Republic of Iran">Armed Forces of the Islamic Republic of Iran</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Iranian_involvement_in_the_Syrian_Civil_War" title="Iranian involvement in the Syrian Civil War">Iranian involvement in the Syrian Civil War</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:2019_Sacred_Defence_Week_parade_(148).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="700" data-file-width="1050" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b1/2019_Sacred_Defence_Week_parade_%28148%29.jpg/220px-2019_Sacred_Defence_Week_parade_%28148%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b1/2019_Sacred_Defence_Week_parade_%28148%29.jpg/330px-2019_Sacred_Defence_Week_parade_%28148%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b1/2019_Sacred_Defence_Week_parade_%28148%29.jpg/440px-2019_Sacred_Defence_Week_parade_%28148%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:2019_Sacred_Defence_Week_parade_(148).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Sophisticated indigenous long range missile system <a href="/wiki/Bavar-373" title="Bavar-373">Bavar-373</a> paraded in Tehran</div></div></div>
<p>The Islamic Republic of Iran has two types of armed forces: the regular forces of the <a href="/wiki/Islamic_Republic_of_Iran_Army" title="Islamic Republic of Iran Army">Army</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Islamic_Republic_of_Iran_Air_Force" title="Islamic Republic of Iran Air Force">Air Force</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Islamic_Republic_of_Iran_Navy" title="Islamic Republic of Iran Navy">Navy</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Islamic_Revolutionary_Guard_Corps" title="Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps">Revolutionary Guards</a>, totaling about 545,000 active troops. Iran also has around 350,000 Reserve Force, totaling around 900,000 trained troops.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-293"><a href="#cite_note-293">[291]</a></sup>
</p><p>The government of Iran has a paramilitary, volunteer militia force within the <a href="/wiki/Islamic_Revolutionary_Guard_Corps" title="Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps">Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps</a>, called the <i><a href="/wiki/Basij" title="Basij">Basij</a></i>, which includes about 90,000 full-time, active-duty uniformed members. Up to 11 million men and women are members of the Basij who could potentially be called up for service. GlobalSecurity.org estimates Iran could mobilize "up to one million men", which would be among the largest troop mobilizations in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-294"><a href="#cite_note-294">[292]</a></sup> In 2007, Iran's military spending represented 2.6% of the GDP or $102 per capita, the lowest figure of the <a href="/wiki/Persian_Gulf" title="Persian Gulf">Persian Gulf</a> nations.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-295"><a href="#cite_note-295">[293]</a></sup> Iran's military doctrine is based on <a href="/wiki/Deterrence_theory" title="Deterrence theory">deterrence</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-296"><a href="#cite_note-296">[294]</a></sup> In 2014, the country spent $15 billion on arms, while the states of the <a href="/wiki/Gulf_Cooperation_Council" title="Gulf Cooperation Council">Gulf Cooperation Council</a> spent eight times more.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-297"><a href="#cite_note-297">[295]</a></sup>
</p><p>The government of Iran supports the military activities of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Allies_of_Iran" title="Allies of Iran">its allies</a> in Syria, Iraq, and Lebanon (<a href="/wiki/Hezbollah" title="Hezbollah">Hezbollah</a>) with military and financial aid.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-298"><a href="#cite_note-298">[296]</a></sup> Iran and Syria are <a href="/wiki/Iran%E2%80%93Syria_relations" title="IranâSyria relations">close strategic allies</a>, and Iran has provided <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Foreign_involvement_in_the_Syrian_Civil_War" title="Foreign involvement in the Syrian Civil War">significant support</a> for the Syrian Government in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Syrian_Civil_War" title="Syrian Civil War">Syrian Civil War</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-syria_299-0"><a href="#cite_note-syria-299">[297]</a></sup> According to some estimates, Iran controlled over 80,000 pro-Assad <a href="/wiki/Shia_Islam" title="Shia Islam">Shi'ite</a> fighters in Syria.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-syria_299-1"><a href="#cite_note-syria-299">[297]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-300"><a href="#cite_note-300">[298]</a></sup>
</p><p>Since the 1979 Revolution, to overcome foreign embargoes, the government of Iran has developed its own military industry, produced its own <a href="/wiki/Tank" title="Tank">tanks</a>, <a href="/wiki/Armoured_personnel_carrier" title="Armoured personnel carrier">armored personnel carriers</a>, <a href="/wiki/Missile" title="Missile">missiles</a>, <a href="/wiki/Submarine" title="Submarine">submarines</a>, military vessels, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Iranian_frigate_Jamaran" title="Iranian frigate Jamaran">missile destroyer</a>, <a href="/wiki/Radar" title="Radar">radar</a> systems, <a href="/wiki/Helicopter" title="Helicopter">helicopters</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Fighter_aircraft" title="Fighter aircraft">fighter planes</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AskariMohseni2010_301-0"><a href="#cite_note-AskariMohseni2010-301">[299]</a></sup> In recent years, official announcements have highlighted the development of weapons such as the <a href="/wiki/Hoot_(torpedo)" title="Hoot (torpedo)">Hoot</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kowsar" title="Kowsar">Kowsar</a>, <a href="/wiki/Zelzal" title="Zelzal">Zelzal</a>, <a href="/wiki/Fateh-110" title="Fateh-110">Fateh-110</a>, <a href="/wiki/Shahab-3" title="Shahab-3">Shahab-3</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sejjil" title="Sejjil">Sejjil</a>, and a variety of <a href="/wiki/Unmanned_aerial_vehicle" title="Unmanned aerial vehicle">unmanned aerial vehicles</a> (UAVs).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-302"><a href="#cite_note-302">[300]</a></sup> Iran has the largest and most diverse <a href="/wiki/Ballistic_missile" title="Ballistic missile">ballistic missile</a> arsenal in the Middle East.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-303"><a href="#cite_note-303">[301]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Fajr-3_(missile)" title="Fajr-3 (missile)">Fajr-3</a>, a <a href="/wiki/Liquid_fuel" title="Liquid fuel">liquid fuel</a> missile with an undisclosed range which was developed and produced domestically, is currently the most advanced ballistic missile of the country.
</p><p>In June 1925, <a href="/wiki/Reza_Shah" title="Reza Shah">Reza Shah</a> introduced conscription law at <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/National_Consultative_Majlis" title="National Consultative Majlis">National Consultative Majlis</a>. At that time, every male person who had reached 21 years old must serve in the military for two years. The conscription exempted women from military service after <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/1979_revolution" title="1979 revolution">1979 revolution</a>. Iranian constitution obliges all men of 18 years old and higher to serve on military or police bases. They cannot leave the country or be employed without completion of the service period.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-304"><a href="#cite_note-304">[302]</a></sup> The period varies from 18 to 24 months.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Human_rights">Human rights</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Human_rights_in_Iran" title="Human rights in Iran">Human rights in Iran</a> and <a href="/wiki/Human_rights_in_the_Islamic_Republic_of_Iran" title="Human rights in the Islamic Republic of Iran">Human rights in the Islamic Republic of Iran</a></div>
<p>According to international reports, Iran's <a href="/wiki/Human_rights_in_the_Islamic_Republic_of_Iran" title="Human rights in the Islamic Republic of Iran">human rights record</a> is exceptionally poor. The regime in Iran is undemocratic,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-305"><a href="#cite_note-305">[303]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-306"><a href="#cite_note-306">[304]</a></sup> has frequently persecuted and arrested critics of the government and its Supreme Leader, and severely restricts the participation of candidates in popular elections as well as other forms of political activity.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-307"><a href="#cite_note-307">[305]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-308"><a href="#cite_note-308">[306]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Women%27s_rights_in_Iran" title="Women's rights in Iran">Women's rights in Iran</a> are described as seriously inadequate,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-309"><a href="#cite_note-309">[307]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Children%27s_rights" title="Children's rights">children's rights</a> have been severely violated, with more child offenders being executed in Iran than in any other country in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-310"><a href="#cite_note-310">[308]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-311"><a href="#cite_note-311">[309]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/LGBT_rights_in_Iran" title="LGBT rights in Iran">Sexual activity</a> between members of the same sex is illegal and is <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Death_penalty_for_homosexuality" title="Death penalty for homosexuality">punishable</a> by up to death.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-312"><a href="#cite_note-312">[310]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-313"><a href="#cite_note-313">[311]</a></sup>
</p><p>Over the past decade, numbers of anti-government protests have broken out throughout Iran (such as the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/2019%E2%80%9320_Iranian_protests" title="2019â20 Iranian protests">2019â20 Iranian protests</a>), demanding reforms or the end to the Islamic Republic. However, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/IRGC" title="IRGC">IRGC</a> and police often suppressed mass protests violently, resulting in thousands of protesters being killed.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Censorship_in_Iran">Censorship in Iran</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Censorship_in_Iran" title="Censorship in Iran">Censorship in Iran</a>, <a href="/wiki/Internet_censorship_in_Iran" title="Internet censorship in Iran">Internet censorship in Iran</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Mass_media_in_Iran" title="Mass media in Iran">Mass media in Iran</a></div>
<p>Censorship in Iran under the government of the Islamic Republic was ranked among the most extreme worldwide.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-314"><a href="#cite_note-314">[312]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-315"><a href="#cite_note-315">[313]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-316"><a href="#cite_note-316">[314]</a></sup>
</p><p>Iran also has strict regulations when it comes to <a href="/wiki/Internet_censorship_in_Iran" title="Internet censorship in Iran">internet censorship</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-social.techcrunch.com_317-0"><a href="#cite_note-social.techcrunch.com-317">[315]</a></sup> with the government and the <a href="/wiki/Islamic_Revolutionary_Guard_Corps" title="Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps">Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps</a> persistently blocking <a href="/wiki/Social_media" title="Social media">social media</a> and other websites.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-318"><a href="#cite_note-318">[316]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-319"><a href="#cite_note-319">[317]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-320"><a href="#cite_note-320">[318]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:3_321-0"><a href="#cite_note-:3-321">[319]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-322"><a href="#cite_note-322">[320]</a></sup> In January 2021, Iranian authorities added Signal to the list of blocked social media platforms, which included Facebook, Telegram, Twitter and YouTube. They carried out arbitrary arrests for social media postings deemed "counter-revolutionary" or "un-Islamic".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-323"><a href="#cite_note-323">[321]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Economy">Economy</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Iran" title="Economy of Iran">Economy of Iran</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Iranian_subsidy_reform_plan" title="Iranian subsidy reform plan">Iranian subsidy reform plan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Banking_and_insurance_in_Iran" title="Banking and insurance in Iran">Banking and insurance in Iran</a>, <a href="/wiki/Transport_in_Iran" title="Transport in Iran">Transport in Iran</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Communications_in_Iran" title="Communications in Iran">Communications in Iran</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Provinces_of_Iran_by_contribution_to_national_GDP.svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="800" data-file-width="900" decoding="async" height="196" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ea/Provinces_of_Iran_by_contribution_to_national_GDP.svg/220px-Provinces_of_Iran_by_contribution_to_national_GDP.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ea/Provinces_of_Iran_by_contribution_to_national_GDP.svg/330px-Provinces_of_Iran_by_contribution_to_national_GDP.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ea/Provinces_of_Iran_by_contribution_to_national_GDP.svg/440px-Provinces_of_Iran_by_contribution_to_national_GDP.svg.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Provinces_of_Iran_by_contribution_to_national_GDP.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Provinces_of_Iran" title="Provinces of Iran">Iran's provinces</a> by their contribution to national GDP (2020)</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:GPD_per_capita_development_of_Iran.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="654" data-file-width="1053" decoding="async" height="137" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0b/GPD_per_capita_development_of_Iran.jpg/220px-GPD_per_capita_development_of_Iran.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0b/GPD_per_capita_development_of_Iran.jpg/330px-GPD_per_capita_development_of_Iran.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0b/GPD_per_capita_development_of_Iran.jpg/440px-GPD_per_capita_development_of_Iran.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:GPD_per_capita_development_of_Iran.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Historical GDP per capita development</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:302px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Iran_Product_Exports_(2019).svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="715" data-file-width="1100" decoding="async" height="195" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/00/Iran_Product_Exports_%282019%29.svg/300px-Iran_Product_Exports_%282019%29.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/00/Iran_Product_Exports_%282019%29.svg/450px-Iran_Product_Exports_%282019%29.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/00/Iran_Product_Exports_%282019%29.svg/600px-Iran_Product_Exports_%282019%29.svg.png 2x" width="300"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Iran_Product_Exports_(2019).svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A proportional representation of Iran exports, 2019</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Iran" title="Economy of Iran">Iran's economy</a> is a <a href="/wiki/Mixed_economy" title="Mixed economy">mixture</a> of <a href="/wiki/Planned_economy" title="Planned economy">central planning</a>, <a href="/wiki/State_ownership" title="State ownership">state ownership</a> of oil and other large enterprises, village agriculture, and small-scale private trading and service ventures.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-324"><a href="#cite_note-324">[322]</a></sup> In 2017, GDP was $427.7 billion ($1.631 trillion at PPP), or $20,000 at <a href="/wiki/Purchasing_power_parity" title="Purchasing power parity">PPP</a> per capita.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CIA_3-4"><a href="#cite_note-CIA-3">[3]</a></sup> Iran is ranked as a lower-middle income economy by the <a href="/wiki/World_Bank" title="World Bank">World Bank</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-325"><a href="#cite_note-325">[323]</a></sup> In the early 21st century, the service sector contributed the largest percentage of the GDP, followed by industry (<a href="/wiki/Mining_in_Iran" title="Mining in Iran">mining</a> and manufacturing) and <a href="/wiki/Agriculture_in_Iran" title="Agriculture in Iran">agriculture</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-326"><a href="#cite_note-326">[324]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Central_Bank_of_the_Islamic_Republic_of_Iran" title="Central Bank of the Islamic Republic of Iran">Central Bank of the Islamic Republic of Iran</a> is responsible for developing and maintaining the <a href="/wiki/Iranian_rial" title="Iranian rial">Iranian rial</a>, which serves as the country's <a href="/wiki/Currency" title="Currency">currency</a>. The government does not recognize <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_trade_unions_in_Iran" title="List of trade unions in Iran">trade unions</a> other than the <a href="/wiki/Iranian_labor_law" title="Iranian labor law">Islamic labour councils</a>, which are subject to the approval of employers and the security services.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ayatoil_327-0"><a href="#cite_note-ayatoil-327">[325]</a></sup> The minimum wage in June 2013 was 487 million rials a month ($134).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-irannum_328-0"><a href="#cite_note-irannum-328">[326]</a></sup> Unemployment has remained above 10% since 1997, and the unemployment rate for women is almost double that of the men.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-irannum_328-1"><a href="#cite_note-irannum-328">[326]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2006, about 45% of the government's budget came from oil and natural gas revenues, and 31% came from taxes and fees.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-payvand.com_329-0"><a href="#cite_note-payvand.com-329">[327]</a></sup> As of 2007<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Iran&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, Iran had earned $70 billion in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Foreign-exchange_reserves" title="Foreign-exchange reserves">foreign-exchange reserves</a>, mostly (80%) from crude oil exports.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-330"><a href="#cite_note-330">[328]</a></sup> Iranian <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Government_of_Iran#Budget" title="Government of Iran">budget deficits</a> have been a chronic problem, mostly due to <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Iranian_subsidy_reform_plan" title="Iranian subsidy reform plan">large-scale state subsidies</a>, that include foodstuffs and especially gasoline, totaling more than $84 billion in 2008 for the energy sector alone.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-331"><a href="#cite_note-331">[329]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-332"><a href="#cite_note-332">[330]</a></sup> In 2010, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Iranian_subsidy_reform_plan" title="Iranian subsidy reform plan">economic reform plan</a> was approved by parliament to <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Iranian_subsidy_reform_plan" title="Iranian subsidy reform plan">cut subsidies</a> gradually and replace them with targeted social assistance. The objective is to move towards <a href="/wiki/Free_market" title="Free market">free market</a> prices in a five-year period and increase productivity and <a href="/wiki/Social_justice" title="Social justice">social justice</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-333"><a href="#cite_note-333">[331]</a></sup>
</p><p>The administration continues to follow the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Iranian_subsidy_reform_plan" title="Iranian subsidy reform plan">market reform plans</a> of the previous one, and indicates that it will diversify Iran's oil-reliant economy. Iran has also developed a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Biotechnology_in_Iran" title="Biotechnology in Iran">biotechnology</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chemistry_in_Iran" title="Chemistry in Iran">nanotechnology</a>, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pharmaceuticals_in_Iran" title="Pharmaceuticals in Iran">pharmaceutical</a> industry.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-334"><a href="#cite_note-334">[332]</a></sup> However, nationalized industries such as the <a href="/wiki/Bonyad" title="Bonyad">bonyads</a> have often been managed badly, making them ineffective and uncompetitive with years. Currently, the government is trying to <a href="/wiki/Privatization_in_Iran" title="Privatization in Iran">privatize these industries</a>, and, despite successes, there are still several problems to be overcome, such as the <a href="/wiki/Corruption_in_Iran" title="Corruption in Iran">lagging corruption in the public sector</a> and lack of competitiveness.
</p><p>Iran has leading manufacturing industries in the fields of automobile manufacture, transportation, construction materials, home appliances, food and agricultural goods, armaments, pharmaceuticals, information technology, and petrochemicals in the Middle East.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Economy_335-0"><a href="#cite_note-Economy-335">[333]</a></sup> According to the 2012 data from the <a href="/wiki/Food_and_Agriculture_Organization" title="Food and Agriculture Organization">Food and Agriculture Organization</a>, Iran has been among the world's top five producers of <a href="/wiki/Apricot" title="Apricot">apricots</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cherry" title="Cherry">cherries</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sour_cherry" title="Sour cherry">sour cherries</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cucumber" title="Cucumber">cucumbers</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gherkin" title="Gherkin">gherkins</a>, <a href="/wiki/Date_palm#Dates" title="Date palm">dates</a>, <a href="/wiki/Eggplant" title="Eggplant">eggplants</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Common_fig" title="Common fig">figs</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pistachio" title="Pistachio">pistachios</a>, <a href="/wiki/Quince" title="Quince">quinces</a>, <a href="/wiki/Walnut" title="Walnut">walnuts</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Watermelon" title="Watermelon">watermelons</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-336"><a href="#cite_note-336">[334]</a></sup>
</p><p>Economic <a href="/wiki/Sanctions_against_Iran" title="Sanctions against Iran">sanctions against Iran</a>, such as the embargo against Iranian crude oil, have injured the economy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-everend_337-0"><a href="#cite_note-everend-337">[335]</a></sup> In 2015, Iran and the <a href="/wiki/P5%2B1" title="P5+1">P5+1</a> reached a <a href="/wiki/Joint_Comprehensive_Plan_of_Action" title="Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action">deal on the nuclear program</a> that removed the main sanctions pertaining to <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_program_of_Iran" title="Nuclear program of Iran">Iran's nuclear program</a> by 2016.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-338"><a href="#cite_note-338">[336]</a></sup> According to the BBC, <a href="/wiki/United_States_sanctions_against_Iran" title="United States sanctions against Iran">renewed U.S. sanctions against Iran</a> "have led to a sharp downturn in Iran's economy, pushing the value of its currency to record lows, quadrupling its annual inflation rate, driving away foreign investors, and triggering protests".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-339"><a href="#cite_note-339">[337]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Tourism">Tourism</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Tourism_in_Iran" title="Tourism in Iran">Tourism in Iran</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Kish_beach_02.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="470" data-file-width="800" decoding="async" height="129" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/94/Kish_beach_02.jpg/220px-Kish_beach_02.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/94/Kish_beach_02.jpg/330px-Kish_beach_02.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/94/Kish_beach_02.jpg/440px-Kish_beach_02.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Kish_beach_02.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>More than a million tourists visit <a href="/wiki/Kish_Island" title="Kish Island">Kish Island</a> each year.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-340"><a href="#cite_note-340">[338]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>Although tourism declined significantly during the war with Iraq, it has been subsequently recovered.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-341"><a href="#cite_note-341">[339]</a></sup> About 1,659,000 foreign tourists visited Iran in 2004, and 2.3 million in 2009, mostly from Asian countries, including the republics of <a href="/wiki/Central_Asia" title="Central Asia">Central Asia</a>, while about 10% came from the <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a> and North America.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Encarta:_Iran's_entry_342-0"><a href="#cite_note-Encarta:_Iran's_entry-342">[340]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Tourism_343-0"><a href="#cite_note-Tourism-343">[341]</a></sup> Since the removal of some sanctions against Iran in 2015, tourism has re-surged in the country. Over five million tourists visited Iran in the fiscal year of 2014â2015, four percent more than the previous year.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-344"><a href="#cite_note-344">[342]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-345"><a href="#cite_note-345">[343]</a></sup>
</p><p>Alongside the capital, the most popular tourist destinations are <a href="/wiki/Isfahan" title="Isfahan">Isfahan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mashhad" title="Mashhad">Mashhad</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Shiraz" title="Shiraz">Shiraz</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-346"><a href="#cite_note-346">[344]</a></sup> In the early 2000s, the industry faced serious limitations in infrastructure, communications, industry standards, and personnel training.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-LOC7_347-0"><a href="#cite_note-LOC7-347">[345]</a></sup> The majority of the 300,000 <a href="/wiki/Travel_visa" title="Travel visa">travel visas</a> granted in 2003 were obtained by Asian Muslims, who presumably intended to visit <a href="/wiki/Pilgrimage" title="Pilgrimage">pilgrimage</a> sites in <a href="/wiki/Mashhad" title="Mashhad">Mashhad</a> and <a href="/wiki/Qom" title="Qom">Qom</a>.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (November 2020)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> Several organized tours from Germany, France, and other European countries come to Iran annually to visit archaeological sites and monuments. In 2003, Iran ranked 68th in tourism revenues worldwide.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-IRNA5_348-0"><a href="#cite_note-IRNA5-348">[346]</a></sup> According to the <a href="/wiki/UNESCO" title="UNESCO">UNESCO</a> and the deputy head of research for <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cultural_Heritage,_Handicrafts_and_Tourism_Organization_of_Iran" title="Cultural Heritage, Handicrafts and Tourism Organization of Iran">Iran's Tourism Organization</a>, Iran is rated fourth among the top 10 destinations in the Middle East.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-IRNA5_348-1"><a href="#cite_note-IRNA5-348">[346]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Domestic_tourism" title="Domestic tourism">Domestic tourism</a> in Iran is one of the largest in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Tourism2_349-0"><a href="#cite_note-Tourism2-349">[347]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BYI_350-0"><a href="#cite_note-BYI-350">[348]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MACooper2012_351-0"><a href="#cite_note-MACooper2012-351">[349]</a></sup> Weak advertising, unstable regional conditions, a poor public image in some parts of the world, and absence of efficient planning schemes in the tourism sector have all hindered the growth of tourism.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Transportation">Transportation</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Transport_in_Iran" title="Transport in Iran">Transport in Iran</a></div>
<p>Iran has a long paved road system linking most of its towns and all of its cities. In 2011 the country had 173,000 kilometers (107,000Â mi) of roads, of which 73% were paved.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-352"><a href="#cite_note-352">[350]</a></sup> In 2008 there were nearly 100 passenger cars for every 1,000 inhabitants.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-iran-daily.com_353-0"><a href="#cite_note-iran-daily.com-353">[351]</a></sup>
</p><p>Trains operate on 11,106Â km (6,942Â mi) of railroad track.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-rai.ir_354-0"><a href="#cite_note-rai.ir-354">[352]</a></sup> The country's major port of entry is <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bandar-Abbas" title="Bandar-Abbas">Bandar-Abbas</a> on the <a href="/wiki/Strait_of_Hormuz" title="Strait of Hormuz">Strait of Hormuz</a>. After arriving in Iran, imported goods are distributed throughout the country by trucks and freight trains. The <a href="/wiki/Tehran" title="Tehran">Tehran</a>â<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bandar-Abbas" title="Bandar-Abbas">Bandar-Abbas</a> railroad, opened in 1995, connects Bandar-Abbas to the railroad system of Central Asia via Tehran and <a href="/wiki/Mashhad" title="Mashhad">Mashhad</a>. Other major ports include <a href="/wiki/Bandar-e_Anzali" title="Bandar-e Anzali">Bandar e-Anzali</a> and <a href="/wiki/Bandar_Torkaman" title="Bandar Torkaman">Bandar e-Torkeman</a> on the <a href="/wiki/Caspian_Sea" title="Caspian Sea">Caspian Sea</a> and <a href="/wiki/Khorramshahr" title="Khorramshahr">Khorramshahr</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bandar_Imam" title="Bandar Imam">Bandar-e Emam Khomeyni</a> on the <a href="/wiki/Persian_Gulf" title="Persian Gulf">Persian Gulf</a>.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/List_of_airports_in_Iran" title="List of airports in Iran">Dozens of cities have airports</a> that serve passenger and cargo planes. <a href="/wiki/Iran_Air" title="Iran Air">Iran Air</a>, the national airline, was founded in 1962 and operated <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Iran_Air_destinations" title="Iran Air destinations">domestic and international flights</a>. All large cities have mass transit systems using buses, and several private companies provide bus services between cities.
</p><p>Transport in Iran is inexpensive because of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Iranian_Economic_Reform_Plan" title="Iranian Economic Reform Plan">the government's subsidization of the price of gasoline</a>. The downside is a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Iranian_targeted_subsidy_plan" title="Iranian targeted subsidy plan">huge draw on government coffers</a>, economic inefficiency because of highly <a href="/wiki/Energy_in_Iran" title="Energy in Iran">wasteful consumption patterns</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/2007_Gasoline_Rationing_Plan_in_Iran#Fuel_smuggling" title="2007 Gasoline Rationing Plan in Iran">smuggling to neighboring countries</a> and <a href="/wiki/Environmental_issues_in_Iran" title="Environmental issues in Iran">air pollution</a>. In 2008, more than one million people worked in the transportation sector, accounting for 9% of GDP.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ReferenceB_355-0"><a href="#cite_note-ReferenceB-355">[353]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Energy">Energy</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Energy_in_Iran" title="Energy in Iran">Energy in Iran</a>, <a href="/wiki/Petroleum_industry_in_Iran" title="Petroleum industry in Iran">Petroleum industry in Iran</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_program_of_Iran" title="Nuclear program of Iran">Nuclear program of Iran</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Foreign_direct_investment_in_Iran" title="Foreign direct investment in Iran">Foreign direct investment in Iran</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:CIAIranKarteOelGas.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="705" data-file-width="687" decoding="async" height="226" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ae/CIAIranKarteOelGas.jpg/220px-CIAIranKarteOelGas.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ae/CIAIranKarteOelGas.jpg/330px-CIAIranKarteOelGas.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ae/CIAIranKarteOelGas.jpg/440px-CIAIranKarteOelGas.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:CIAIranKarteOelGas.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Iran holds 10% of the world's proven <a href="/wiki/Oil_reserves" title="Oil reserves">oil reserves</a> and 15% of its gas. It is <a href="/wiki/OPEC" title="OPEC">OPEC</a>'s second-largest exporter and the world's seventh largest oil producer.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-356"><a href="#cite_note-356">[354]</a></sup></div></div></div>
