<p>Iran has the world's second largest proved <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Natural_gas_reserves_in_Iran" title="Natural gas reserves in Iran">gas reserves</a> after Russia, with 33.6 trillion <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cubic_meter" title="Cubic meter">cubic meters</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-The_Wall_Street_Journalgas_357-0"><a href="#cite_note-The_Wall_Street_Journalgas-357">[355]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_natural_gas_production" title="List of countries by natural gas production">third largest natural gas production</a> after <a href="/wiki/Indonesia" title="Indonesia">Indonesia</a> and Russia. It also ranks fourth in <a href="/wiki/Oil_reserves_in_Iran" title="Oil reserves in Iran">oil reserves</a> with an estimated 153,600,000,000 barrels.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:0_358-0"><a href="#cite_note-:0-358">[356]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-359"><a href="#cite_note-359">[357]</a></sup> It is <a href="/wiki/OPEC" title="OPEC">OPEC</a>'s second largest oil exporter, and is an <a href="/wiki/Energy_superpower#Iran" title="Energy superpower">energy superpower</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-360"><a href="#cite_note-360">[358]</a></sup>
In 2005, Iran spent US$4 billion on fuel imports, because of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Smuggling_in_Iran" title="Smuggling in Iran">contraband</a> and inefficient domestic use.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-361"><a href="#cite_note-361">[359]</a></sup> Oil industry output averaged 4 million barrels per day (640,000Â m<sup>3</sup>/d) in 2005, compared with the peak of six million barrels per day reached in 1974. In the early 2000s, industry infrastructure was increasingly inefficient because of technological lags. Few exploratory <a href="/wiki/Oil_well" title="Oil well">wells</a> were drilled in 2005.
</p><p>In 2004, a large share of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Natural_gas_reserves_in_Iran" title="Natural gas reserves in Iran">Iran's natural gas reserves</a> were untapped. The addition of new <a href="/wiki/Hydroelectricity" title="Hydroelectricity">hydroelectric</a> stations and the streamlining of conventional coal and oil-fired stations increased installed capacity to 33,000 megawatts. Of that amount, about 75% was based on natural gas, 18% on oil, and 7% on hydroelectric power. In 2004, Iran opened its first wind-powered and geothermal plants, and the first <a href="/wiki/Solar_power" title="Solar power">solar</a> thermal plant was to come online in 2009. Iran is the world's third country to have developed <a href="/wiki/Gas_to_liquids" title="Gas to liquids">GTL</a> technology.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-362"><a href="#cite_note-362">[360]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Demographics_of_Iran" title="Demographics of Iran">Demographic</a> trends and intensified industrialization have caused <a href="/wiki/Electric_power" title="Electric power">electric power</a> demand to grow by 8% per year. The government's goal of 53,000 megawatts of installed capacity by 2010 is to be reached by bringing on line <a href="/wiki/List_of_power_stations_in_Iran" title="List of power stations in Iran">new gas-fired plants</a>, and adding hydropower and nuclear power generation capacity. <a href="/wiki/Bushehr_Nuclear_Power_Plant" title="Bushehr Nuclear Power Plant">Iran's first nuclear power plant</a> at <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bushire" title="Bushire">Bushire</a> went online in 2011. It is the second <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_power_plant" title="Nuclear power plant">nuclear power plant</a> ever built in the Middle East after the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Metsamor_Nuclear_Power_Plant" title="Metsamor Nuclear Power Plant">Metsamor Nuclear Power Plant</a> in <a href="/wiki/Armenia" title="Armenia">Armenia</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-nuclear_363-0"><a href="#cite_note-nuclear-363">[361]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MÃ¼llerMÃ¼ller2015_364-0"><a href="#cite_note-MÃ¼llerMÃ¼ller2015-364">[362]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span id="Education.2C_science_and_technology"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Education,_science_and_technology">Education, science and technology</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Education_in_Iran" title="Education in Iran">Education in Iran</a> and <a href="/wiki/Science_and_technology_in_Iran" title="Science and technology in Iran">Science and technology in Iran</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:UIS_Literacy_Rate_Iran_population_plus_15_1975-2015.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="315" data-file-width="396" decoding="async" height="175" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1e/UIS_Literacy_Rate_Iran_population_plus_15_1975-2015.png/220px-UIS_Literacy_Rate_Iran_population_plus_15_1975-2015.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1e/UIS_Literacy_Rate_Iran_population_plus_15_1975-2015.png/330px-UIS_Literacy_Rate_Iran_population_plus_15_1975-2015.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/1/1e/UIS_Literacy_Rate_Iran_population_plus_15_1975-2015.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:UIS_Literacy_Rate_Iran_population_plus_15_1975-2015.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Literacy rate of Iran's population plus 15, 1975â2015, according to UNESCO Institute of Statistics</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Education_in_Iran" title="Education in Iran">Education in Iran</a> is highly centralized. <a href="/wiki/K%E2%80%9312" title="Kâ12">Kâ12</a> is supervised by the <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Education_(Iran)" title="Ministry of Education (Iran)">Ministry of Education</a>, and higher education is under the supervision of the <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Science,_Research_and_Technology_(Iran)" title="Ministry of Science, Research and Technology (Iran)">Ministry of Science and Technology</a>.
</p><p>The rate of adult literacy(among Iranians of ages 10 to 49) has reached 96% on March 19, 2020;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-365"><a href="#cite_note-365">[363]</a></sup> while according to <a href="/wiki/UNESCO" title="UNESCO">UNESCO</a> it had rated 85.0% in 2008 (up from 36.5% in 1976).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-unescolit_366-0"><a href="#cite_note-unescolit-366">[364]</a></sup>
</p><p>According to the data provided by <a href="/wiki/UNESCO" title="UNESCO">UNESCO</a>, Iran's literacy rate among people aged 15 years and older was 85.54% as of 2016, with men (90.35%) being significantly more educated than women (80.79%), with the number of illiterate people of the same age amounting to around 8,700,000 of the country's 85 million population.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-367"><a href="#cite_note-367">[365]</a></sup> According to this report, Iranian government's expenditure on education amounts to around 4% of the GDP.
</p><p>The requirement to enter into higher education is to have a <a href="/wiki/High_school_diploma" title="High school diploma">high school diploma</a> and pass the <a href="/wiki/Iranian_University_Entrance_Exam" title="Iranian University Entrance Exam">Iranian University Entrance Exam</a> (officially known as <i>konkur</i> (Ú©ÙÚ©ÙØ±)), which is the equivalent of the <a href="/wiki/SAT" title="SAT">SAT</a> and <a href="/wiki/ACT_(test)" title="ACT (test)">ACT</a> exams of the United States. Many students do a 1â2-year course of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/University-preparatory_school" title="University-preparatory school">pre-university</a> (<i>piÅ¡-dÄneÅ¡gÄh</i>), which is the equivalent of the <a href="/wiki/General_Certificate_of_Education" title="General Certificate of Education">GCE</a> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/GCE_Advanced_Level" title="GCE Advanced Level">A-levels</a> and the <a href="/wiki/International_Baccalaureate" title="International Baccalaureate">International Baccalaureate</a>. The completion of the pre-university course earns students the Pre-University Certificate.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-368"><a href="#cite_note-368">[366]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Sharif_University_of_Technology.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1500" data-file-width="2000" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0a/Sharif_University_of_Technology.jpg/220px-Sharif_University_of_Technology.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0a/Sharif_University_of_Technology.jpg/330px-Sharif_University_of_Technology.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0a/Sharif_University_of_Technology.jpg/440px-Sharif_University_of_Technology.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Sharif_University_of_Technology.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Sharif_University_of_Technology" title="Sharif University of Technology">Sharif University of Technology</a> is one of Iran's most prestigious higher education institutions.</div></div></div>
<p>Iran's higher education is sanctioned by different levels of diplomas, including an <a href="/wiki/Associate_degree" title="Associate degree">associate degree</a> (<i>kÄrdÄni</i>; also known as <i>fowq e diplom</i>) delivered in two years, a <a href="/wiki/Bachelor%27s_degree" title="Bachelor's degree">bachelor's degree</a> (<i>kÄrÅ¡enÄsi</i>; also known as <i>lisÄns</i>) delivered in four years, and a <a href="/wiki/Master%27s_degree" title="Master's degree">master's degree</a> (<i>kÄrÅ¡enÄsi e arÅ¡ad</i>) delivered in two years, after which another exam allows the candidate to pursue a doctoral program (<a href="/wiki/Doctor_of_Philosophy" title="Doctor of Philosophy">PhD</a>; known as <i>doktorÄ</i>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-wes.org_369-0"><a href="#cite_note-wes.org-369">[367]</a></sup>
</p><p>According to the <a href="/wiki/Webometrics_Ranking_of_World_Universities" title="Webometrics Ranking of World Universities">Webometrics Ranking of World Universities</a> (as of JanuaryÂ 2017<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Iran&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>), Iran's top five universities include <a href="/wiki/Tehran_University_of_Medical_Sciences" title="Tehran University of Medical Sciences">Tehran University of Medical Sciences</a> (478th worldwide), the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Tehran" title="University of Tehran">University of Tehran</a> (514th worldwide), <a href="/wiki/Sharif_University_of_Technology" title="Sharif University of Technology">Sharif University of Technology</a> (605th worldwide), <a href="/wiki/Amirkabir_University_of_Technology" title="Amirkabir University of Technology">Amirkabir University of Technology</a> (726th worldwide), and the <a href="/wiki/Tarbiat_Modares_University" title="Tarbiat Modares University">Tarbiat Modares University</a> (789th worldwide).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-370"><a href="#cite_note-370">[368]</a></sup> Iran was ranked 60th in the <a href="/wiki/Global_Innovation_Index" title="Global Innovation Index">Global Innovation Index</a> in 2021, up from 67th in 2020.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-371"><a href="#cite_note-371">[369]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-372"><a href="#cite_note-372">[370]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-373"><a href="#cite_note-373">[371]</a></sup>
</p><p>Iran has increased its publication output nearly tenfold from 1996 through 2004, and has been ranked first in terms of output growth rate, followed by China.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-374"><a href="#cite_note-374">[372]</a></sup> According to a study by <a href="/wiki/SCImago_Journal_Rank" title="SCImago Journal Rank">SCImago</a> in 2012, Iran would rank fourth in the world in terms of research output by 2018, if the current trend persists.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SCImago_December_2012c_375-0"><a href="#cite_note-SCImago_December_2012c-375">[373]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Inside_Aryogen.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="534" data-file-width="800" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/11/Inside_Aryogen.jpg/220px-Inside_Aryogen.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/11/Inside_Aryogen.jpg/330px-Inside_Aryogen.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/11/Inside_Aryogen.jpg/440px-Inside_Aryogen.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Inside_Aryogen.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The production line for <a href="/wiki/Recombinant_factor_VIIa" title="Recombinant factor VIIa">AryoSeven</a> at the Iranian biopharmaceutical company of <a href="/wiki/AryoGen" title="AryoGen">AryoGen</a></div></div></div>
<p>In 2009, a SUSE Linux-based HPC system made by the Aerospace Research Institute of Iran (ARI) was launched with 32 cores, and now runs 96 cores. Its performance was pegged at 192 <a href="/wiki/FLOPS" title="FLOPS">GFLOPS</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-376"><a href="#cite_note-376">[374]</a></sup> The Iranian humanoid robot <a href="/wiki/Surena_(robot)" title="Surena (robot)">Sorena 2</a>, which was designed by engineers at the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Tehran" title="University of Tehran">University of Tehran</a>, was unveiled in 2010. The <a href="/wiki/Institute_of_Electrical_and_Electronics_Engineers" title="Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers">Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers</a> (IEEE) has placed the name of Surena among the five prominent robots of the world after analyzing its performance.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-377"><a href="#cite_note-377">[375]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the biomedical sciences, Iran's <a href="/wiki/Institute_of_Biochemistry_and_Biophysics" title="Institute of Biochemistry and Biophysics">Institute of Biochemistry and Biophysics</a> has a UNESCO chair in biology.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-378"><a href="#cite_note-378">[376]</a></sup> In late 2006, <a href="/wiki/List_of_contemporary_Iranian_scientists,_scholars,_and_engineers" title="List of contemporary Iranian scientists, scholars, and engineers">Iranian scientists</a> successfully <a href="/wiki/Cloning" title="Cloning">cloned</a> a sheep by somatic cell nuclear transfer, at the <a href="/wiki/Royan_Institute" title="Royan Institute">Royan Research Center</a> in Tehran.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-379"><a href="#cite_note-379">[377]</a></sup>
</p><p>According to a study by David Morrison and Ali Khadem Hosseini (Harvard-MIT and Cambridge), <a href="/wiki/Stem_cell" title="Stem cell">stem cell</a> research in Iran is amongst the top 10 in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-380"><a href="#cite_note-380">[378]</a></sup> Iran ranks 15th in the world in <a href="/wiki/Nanotechnology" title="Nanotechnology">nanotechnologies</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-381"><a href="#cite_note-381">[379]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-382"><a href="#cite_note-382">[380]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-383"><a href="#cite_note-383">[381]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:%D8%B3%DB%8C%D9%85%D8%B1%D8%BA_-_%D8%A7%D9%81%D8%AA%D8%AA%D8%A7%D8%AD_%D9%BE%D8%A7%DB%8C%DA%AF%D8%A7%D9%87_%D9%85%D9%84%DB%8C_%D9%81%D8%B6%D8%A7%DB%8C%DB%8C_%D8%A7%D9%85%D8%A7%D9%85_%D8%AE%D9%85%DB%8C%D9%86%DB%8C(%D8%B1%D9%87)_(2).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="557" data-file-width="800" decoding="async" height="153" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cd/%D8%B3%DB%8C%D9%85%D8%B1%D8%BA_-_%D8%A7%D9%81%D8%AA%D8%AA%D8%A7%D8%AD_%D9%BE%D8%A7%DB%8C%DA%AF%D8%A7%D9%87_%D9%85%D9%84%DB%8C_%D9%81%D8%B6%D8%A7%DB%8C%DB%8C_%D8%A7%D9%85%D8%A7%D9%85_%D8%AE%D9%85%DB%8C%D9%86%DB%8C%28%D8%B1%D9%87%29_%282%29.jpg/220px-%D8%B3%DB%8C%D9%85%D8%B1%D8%BA_-_%D8%A7%D9%81%D8%AA%D8%AA%D8%A7%D8%AD_%D9%BE%D8%A7%DB%8C%DA%AF%D8%A7%D9%87_%D9%85%D9%84%DB%8C_%D9%81%D8%B6%D8%A7%DB%8C%DB%8C_%D8%A7%D9%85%D8%A7%D9%85_%D8%AE%D9%85%DB%8C%D9%86%DB%8C%28%D8%B1%D9%87%29_%282%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cd/%D8%B3%DB%8C%D9%85%D8%B1%D8%BA_-_%D8%A7%D9%81%D8%AA%D8%AA%D8%A7%D8%AD_%D9%BE%D8%A7%DB%8C%DA%AF%D8%A7%D9%87_%D9%85%D9%84%DB%8C_%D9%81%D8%B6%D8%A7%DB%8C%DB%8C_%D8%A7%D9%85%D8%A7%D9%85_%D8%AE%D9%85%DB%8C%D9%86%DB%8C%28%D8%B1%D9%87%29_%282%29.jpg/330px-%D8%B3%DB%8C%D9%85%D8%B1%D8%BA_-_%D8%A7%D9%81%D8%AA%D8%AA%D8%A7%D8%AD_%D9%BE%D8%A7%DB%8C%DA%AF%D8%A7%D9%87_%D9%85%D9%84%DB%8C_%D9%81%D8%B6%D8%A7%DB%8C%DB%8C_%D8%A7%D9%85%D8%A7%D9%85_%D8%AE%D9%85%DB%8C%D9%86%DB%8C%28%D8%B1%D9%87%29_%282%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cd/%D8%B3%DB%8C%D9%85%D8%B1%D8%BA_-_%D8%A7%D9%81%D8%AA%D8%AA%D8%A7%D8%AD_%D9%BE%D8%A7%DB%8C%DA%AF%D8%A7%D9%87_%D9%85%D9%84%DB%8C_%D9%81%D8%B6%D8%A7%DB%8C%DB%8C_%D8%A7%D9%85%D8%A7%D9%85_%D8%AE%D9%85%DB%8C%D9%86%DB%8C%28%D8%B1%D9%87%29_%282%29.jpg/440px-%D8%B3%DB%8C%D9%85%D8%B1%D8%BA_-_%D8%A7%D9%81%D8%AA%D8%AA%D8%A7%D8%AD_%D9%BE%D8%A7%DB%8C%DA%AF%D8%A7%D9%87_%D9%85%D9%84%DB%8C_%D9%81%D8%B6%D8%A7%DB%8C%DB%8C_%D8%A7%D9%85%D8%A7%D9%85_%D8%AE%D9%85%DB%8C%D9%86%DB%8C%28%D8%B1%D9%87%29_%282%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:%D8%B3%DB%8C%D9%85%D8%B1%D8%BA_-_%D8%A7%D9%81%D8%AA%D8%AA%D8%A7%D8%AD_%D9%BE%D8%A7%DB%8C%DA%AF%D8%A7%D9%87_%D9%85%D9%84%DB%8C_%D9%81%D8%B6%D8%A7%DB%8C%DB%8C_%D8%A7%D9%85%D8%A7%D9%85_%D8%AE%D9%85%DB%8C%D9%86%DB%8C(%D8%B1%D9%87)_(2).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Simorgh_(rocket)" title="Simorgh (rocket)">Simorgh launch</a>, <a href="/wiki/Iranian_Space_Agency" title="Iranian Space Agency">Iranian Space Agency</a></div></div></div>
<p>Iran placed its domestically built <a href="/wiki/Satellite" title="Satellite">satellite</a> <a href="/wiki/Omid" title="Omid">Omid</a> into orbit on the 30th anniversary of the 1979 Revolution, on 2<span class="nowrap">Â </span>February 2009,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-HarveySmid2011_384-0"><a href="#cite_note-HarveySmid2011-384">[382]</a></sup> through its first expendable launch vehicle <a href="/wiki/Safir_(rocket)" title="Safir (rocket)">Safir</a>, becoming the <a href="/wiki/Timeline_of_first_orbital_launches_by_country" title="Timeline of first orbital launches by country">ninth country</a> in the world capable of both producing a satellite and sending it into <a href="/wiki/Space" title="Space">space</a> from a domestically made <a href="/wiki/Launch_pad" title="Launch pad">launcher</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Hvac-conference.ir_November_29_2015c_385-0"><a href="#cite_note-Hvac-conference.ir_November_29_2015c-385">[383]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Iranian_nuclear_program" title="Iranian nuclear program">Iranian nuclear program</a> was launched in the 1950s. Iran is the seventh country to produce <a href="/wiki/Uranium_hexafluoride" title="Uranium hexafluoride">uranium hexafluoride</a>, and controls the entire <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_fuel_cycle" title="Nuclear fuel cycle">nuclear fuel cycle</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-386"><a href="#cite_note-386">[384]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-387"><a href="#cite_note-387">[385]</a></sup>
</p><p>Iranian scientists outside Iran have also made some major contributions to science. In 1960, <a href="/wiki/Ali_Javan" title="Ali Javan">Ali Javan</a> co-invented the first <a href="/wiki/Gas_laser" title="Gas laser">gas laser</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Fuzzy_set" title="Fuzzy set">fuzzy set theory</a> was introduced by <a href="/wiki/Lotfi_A._Zadeh" title="Lotfi A. Zadeh">Lotfi A. Zadeh</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-388"><a href="#cite_note-388">[386]</a></sup> Iranian cardiologist <a href="/wiki/Tofy_Mussivand" title="Tofy Mussivand">Tofigh Mussivand</a> invented and developed the first artificial cardiac pump, the precursor of the <a href="/wiki/Artificial_heart" title="Artificial heart">artificial heart</a>. Furthering research and treatment of diabetes, the <a href="/wiki/Glycated_hemoglobin" title="Glycated hemoglobin">HbA1c</a> was discovered by <a href="/wiki/Samuel_Rahbar" title="Samuel Rahbar">Samuel Rahbar</a>. A substantial number of papers in <a href="/wiki/String_theory" title="String theory">string theory</a> are published in Iran.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Nasr2007_389-0"><a href="#cite_note-Nasr2007-389">[387]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Iranian_Americans" title="Iranian Americans">Iranian American</a> string theorist <a href="/wiki/Cumrun_Vafa" title="Cumrun Vafa">Cumrun Vafa</a> proposed the <a href="/wiki/Vafa%E2%80%93Witten_theorem" title="VafaâWitten theorem">VafaâWitten theorem</a> together with <a href="/wiki/Edward_Witten" title="Edward Witten">Edward Witten</a>. In August 2014, Iranian mathematician <a href="/wiki/Maryam_Mirzakhani" title="Maryam Mirzakhani">Maryam Mirzakhani</a> became the first woman, as well as the first Iranian, to receive the <a href="/wiki/Fields_Medal" title="Fields Medal">Fields Medal</a>, the highest prize in mathematics.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-390"><a href="#cite_note-390">[388]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Demographics">Demographics</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Demographics_of_Iran" title="Demographics of Iran">Demographics of Iran</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Healthcare_in_Iran" title="Healthcare in Iran">Healthcare in Iran</a></div>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">.mw-parser-output .tmulti .multiimageinner{display:flex;flex-direction:column}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow{display:flex;flex-direction:row;clear:left;flex-wrap:wrap;width:100%;box-sizing:border-box}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle{margin:1px;float:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .theader{clear:both;font-weight:bold;text-align:center;align-self:center;background-color:transparent;width:100%}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbcaption{background-color:transparent}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-left{text-align:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-right{text-align:right}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-center{text-align:center}@media all and (max-width:720px){.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbinner{width:100%!important;box-sizing:border-box;max-width:none!important;align-items:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow{justify-content:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle{float:none!important;max-width:100%!important;box-sizing:border-box;text-align:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle .thumbcaption{text-align:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow>.thumbcaption{text-align:center}}</style><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:292px;max-width:292px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:290px;max-width:290px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:257px;overflow:hidden"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Provinces_of_Iran_by_population.svg"><img alt="" data-file-height="1071" data-file-width="1200" decoding="async" height="257" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e6/Provinces_of_Iran_by_population.svg/288px-Provinces_of_Iran_by_population.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e6/Provinces_of_Iran_by_population.svg/432px-Provinces_of_Iran_by_population.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e6/Provinces_of_Iran_by_population.svg/576px-Provinces_of_Iran_by_population.svg.png 2x" width="288"/></a></div></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:290px;max-width:290px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:257px;overflow:hidden"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Iran_Counties_by_Population_(2021).svg"><img alt="" data-file-height="1071" data-file-width="1200" decoding="async" height="257" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7b/Iran_Counties_by_Population_%282021%29.svg/288px-Iran_Counties_by_Population_%282021%29.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7b/Iran_Counties_by_Population_%282021%29.svg/432px-Iran_Counties_by_Population_%282021%29.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7b/Iran_Counties_by_Population_%282021%29.svg/576px-Iran_Counties_by_Population_%282021%29.svg.png 2x" width="288"/></a></div></div></div><div class="trow" style="display:flex"><div class="thumbcaption">Population of Iranian provinces and counties in 2021.</div></div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Iran_Population_(1880-2016).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="483" data-file-width="687" decoding="async" height="155" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/75/Iran_Population_%281880-2016%29.jpg/220px-Iran_Population_%281880-2016%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/75/Iran_Population_%281880-2016%29.jpg/330px-Iran_Population_%281880-2016%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/75/Iran_Population_%281880-2016%29.jpg/440px-Iran_Population_%281880-2016%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Iran_Population_(1880-2016).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Iran's population growth (1880â2016)</div></div></div>
<p>Iran is a diverse country, consisting of <a href="/wiki/Ethnicities_in_Iran" title="Ethnicities in Iran">numerous ethnic</a> and linguistic groups that are unified through a shared Iranian nationality.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-391"><a href="#cite_note-391">[389]</a></sup>
</p><p>Iran's population grew rapidly during the latter half of the 20th century, increasing from about 19Â million in 1956 to more than 84 million by July 2020.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-392"><a href="#cite_note-392">[390]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-una_393-0"><a href="#cite_note-una-393">[391]</a></sup> However, Iran's <a href="/wiki/Total_fertility_rate" title="Total fertility rate">fertility rate</a> has dropped significantly in recent years, coming down from a fertility rate of 6.5 per woman to just a little more than 2 two decades later,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-394"><a href="#cite_note-394">[392]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-395"><a href="#cite_note-395">[393]</a></sup> leading to a population growth rate of about 1.39% as of 2018.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-396"><a href="#cite_note-396">[394]</a></sup> Due to its young population, studies project that the growth will continue to slow until it stabilizes around 105Â million by 2050.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bureau_397-0"><a href="#cite_note-bureau-397">[395]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-payvand_398-0"><a href="#cite_note-payvand-398">[396]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-399"><a href="#cite_note-399">[397]</a></sup>
</p><p>Iran hosts one of the largest <a href="/wiki/Refugee" title="Refugee">refugee</a> populations in the world, with almost one million refugees,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-400"><a href="#cite_note-400">[398]</a></sup> mostly from <a href="/wiki/Afghan_refugees" title="Afghan refugees">Afghanistan</a> and <a href="/wiki/Iraq" title="Iraq">Iraq</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-401"><a href="#cite_note-401">[399]</a></sup> Since 2006, Iranian officials have been working with the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_High_Commissioner_for_Refugees" title="United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees">UNHCR</a> and Afghan officials for their <a href="/wiki/Repatriation" title="Repatriation">repatriation</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bbcb_402-0"><a href="#cite_note-bbcb-402">[400]</a></sup> According to estimates, about five million Iranian citizens have emigrated to other countries, mostly since the 1979 Revolution.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ganji2002_403-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ganji2002-403">[401]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-404"><a href="#cite_note-404">[402]</a></sup>
</p><p>According to the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Constitution_of_the_Islamic_Republic_of_Iran" title="Constitution of the Islamic Republic of Iran">Iranian Constitution</a>, the government is required to provide every citizen of the country with access to <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Social_security" title="Social security">social security</a>, covering retirement, unemployment, old age, <a href="/wiki/Disability" title="Disability">disability</a>, accidents, calamities, health and medical treatment and care services.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-405"><a href="#cite_note-405">[403]</a></sup> This is covered by <a href="/wiki/Taxation_in_Iran" title="Taxation in Iran">tax revenues</a> and income derived from public contributions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-406"><a href="#cite_note-406">[404]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Languages">Languages</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Languages_of_Iran" title="Languages of Iran">Languages of Iran</a></div>
<p>The majority of the population speaks <a href="/wiki/Persian_language" title="Persian language">Persian</a>, which is also the <a href="/wiki/Official_language" title="Official language">official language</a> of the country. Others include speakers of several other <a href="/wiki/Iranian_languages" title="Iranian languages">Iranian languages</a> within the greater <a href="/wiki/Indo-European_languages" title="Indo-European languages">Indo-European</a> family and languages belonging to some other ethnicities living in Iran.
</p><p>In northern Iran, mostly confined to <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gilan_Province" title="Gilan Province">Gilan</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mazandaran_Province" title="Mazandaran Province">Mazenderan</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Gilaki_language" title="Gilaki language">Gilaki</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mazanderani_language" title="Mazanderani language">Mazenderani</a> languages are widely spoken, both having affinities to the neighboring <a href="/wiki/Languages_of_the_Caucasus" title="Languages of the Caucasus">Caucasian languages</a>. In parts of Gilan, the <a href="/wiki/Talysh_language" title="Talysh language">Talysh language</a> is also widely spoken, which stretches up to the neighboring <a href="/wiki/Azerbaijan" title="Azerbaijan">Republic of Azerbaijan</a>. Varieties of <a href="/wiki/Kurdish_languages" title="Kurdish languages">Kurdish</a> are widely spoken in the province of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kurdistan_Province" title="Kurdistan Province">Kurdistan</a> and nearby areas. In <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Khuzestan_Province" title="Khuzestan Province">Khuzestan</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Persian_dialects_in_Khuzestan" title="Persian dialects in Khuzestan">several distinct varieties of Persian</a> are spoken. <a href="/wiki/Luri_language" title="Luri language">Luri</a> and <a href="/wiki/Achomi_language" title="Achomi language">Lari</a> are also spoken in southern Iran.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Azerbaijani_language" title="Azerbaijani language">Azerbaijani</a>, which is by far the most spoken language in the country after Persian,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-407"><a href="#cite_note-407">[405]</a></sup> as well as several other <a href="/wiki/Turkic_languages" title="Turkic languages">Turkic languages</a> and dialects, is spoken in various regions of Iran, especially in the region of <a href="/wiki/Azerbaijan_(Iran)" title="Azerbaijan (Iran)">Azerbaijan</a>.
</p><p>Notable minority languages in Iran include <a href="/wiki/Armenian_language" title="Armenian language">Armenian</a>, <a href="/wiki/Georgian_language" title="Georgian language">Georgian</a>, <a href="/wiki/Neo-Aramaic_languages" title="Neo-Aramaic languages">Neo-Aramaic</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Arabic" title="Arabic">Arabic</a>. <a href="/wiki/Khuzestani_Arabic" title="Khuzestani Arabic">Khuzi Arabic</a> is spoken by the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ahwazi_Arabs" title="Ahwazi Arabs">Arabs in Khuzestan</a>, as well as the wider group of <a href="/wiki/Iranian_Arabs" title="Iranian Arabs">Iranian Arabs</a>. <a href="/wiki/Circassian_languages" title="Circassian languages">Circassian</a> was also once widely spoken by the large Circassian minority, but, due to assimilation over the many years, no sizable number of Circassians speak the language anymore.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-408"><a href="#cite_note-408">[406]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-409"><a href="#cite_note-409">[407]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-410"><a href="#cite_note-410">[408]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-411"><a href="#cite_note-411">[409]</a></sup>
</p><p>Percentages of spoken language continue to be a point of debate, as many opt that they are politically motivated; most notably regarding the largest and second largest ethnicities in Iran, the Persians and <a href="/wiki/Azerbaijanis" title="Azerbaijanis">Azerbaijanis</a>. Percentages given by the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/CIA" title="CIA">CIA</a>'s <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/World_Factbook" title="World Factbook">World Factbook</a> include 53% Persian, 16% <a href="/wiki/Azerbaijani_language" title="Azerbaijani language">Azerbaijani</a>, 10% <a href="/wiki/Kurdish_languages" title="Kurdish languages">Kurdish</a>, 7% <a href="/wiki/Mazanderani_language" title="Mazanderani language">Mazenderani</a> and <a href="/wiki/Gilaki_language" title="Gilaki language">Gilaki</a>, 7% <a href="/wiki/Luri_language" title="Luri language">Luri</a>, 2% <a href="/wiki/Turkmen_language" title="Turkmen language">Turkmen</a>, 2% <a href="/wiki/Balochi_language" title="Balochi language">Balochi</a>, 2% <a href="/wiki/Arabic" title="Arabic">Arabic</a>, and 2% the remainder <a href="/wiki/Armenian_language" title="Armenian language">Armenian</a>, <a href="/wiki/Georgian_language" title="Georgian language">Georgian</a>, <a href="/wiki/Neo-Aramaic_languages" title="Neo-Aramaic languages">Neo-Aramaic</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Circassian_languages" title="Circassian languages">Circassian</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CIA_3-5"><a href="#cite_note-CIA-3">[3]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Ethnic_groups">Ethnic groups</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Ethnicities_in_Iran" title="Ethnicities in Iran">Ethnicities in Iran</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Provinces_of_Iran_by_population_density.svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="800" data-file-width="900" decoding="async" height="196" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/60/Provinces_of_Iran_by_population_density.svg/220px-Provinces_of_Iran_by_population_density.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/60/Provinces_of_Iran_by_population_density.svg/330px-Provinces_of_Iran_by_population_density.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/60/Provinces_of_Iran_by_population_density.svg/440px-Provinces_of_Iran_by_population_density.svg.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Provinces_of_Iran_by_population_density.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Iran's provinces by population density (2013)</div></div></div>
<p>As with the spoken languages, the ethnic group composition also remains a point of debate, mainly regarding the largest and second largest ethnic groups, the Persians and Azerbaijanis, due to the lack of Iranian state censuses based on ethnicity. <a href="/wiki/The_World_Factbook" title="The World Factbook">The CIA's World Factbook</a> has estimated that around 79% of the population of Iran is a diverse <a href="/wiki/Proto-Indo-Europeans" title="Proto-Indo-Europeans">Indo-European</a> <a href="/wiki/Ethnolinguistics" title="Ethnolinguistics">ethno-linguistic group</a> that comprise speakers of various <a href="/wiki/Iranian_languages" title="Iranian languages">Iranian languages</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-412"><a href="#cite_note-412">[410]</a></sup> with <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Persian_people" title="Persian people">Persians</a> (including <a href="/wiki/Mazanderani_people" title="Mazanderani people">Mazenderanis</a> and <a href="/wiki/Gilaks" title="Gilaks">Gilaks</a>) constituting 61% of the population, <a href="/wiki/Kurds" title="Kurds">Kurds</a> 10%, <a href="/wiki/Lurs" title="Lurs">Lurs</a> 6%, and <a href="/wiki/Baloch_people" title="Baloch people">Balochs</a> 2%. Peoples of other ethnolinguistic groups make up the remaining 21%, with <a href="/wiki/Iranian_Azerbaijanis" title="Iranian Azerbaijanis">Azerbaijanis</a> constituting 16%, <a href="/wiki/Arabs" title="Arabs">Arabs</a> 2%, <a href="/wiki/Turkmens" title="Turkmens">Turkmens</a> and other <a href="/wiki/Turkic_peoples" title="Turkic peoples">Turkic tribes</a> 2%, and others (such as <a href="/wiki/Iranian_Armenians" title="Iranian Armenians">Armenians</a>, <a href="/wiki/Talysh_people" title="Talysh people">Talysh</a>, <a href="/wiki/Iranian_Georgians" title="Iranian Georgians">Georgians</a>, <a href="/wiki/Circassians_in_Iran" title="Circassians in Iran">Circassians</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Iranian_Assyrians" title="Iranian Assyrians">Assyrians</a>) 1%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CIA_3-6"><a href="#cite_note-CIA-3">[3]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Library_of_Congress" title="Library of Congress">Library of Congress</a> issued slightly different estimates: 65% Persians (including Mazenderanis, Gilaks, and the Talysh), 16% Azerbaijanis, 7% Kurds, 6% Lurs, 2% Baloch, 1% Turkic tribal groups (incl. <a href="/wiki/Qashqai_people" title="Qashqai people">Qashqai</a> and <a href="/wiki/Turkmens" title="Turkmens">Turkmens</a>), and non-Iranian, non-Turkic groups (incl. Armenians, Georgians, Assyrians, Circassians, and Arabs) less than 3%. It determined that Persian is the first language of at least 65% of the country's population, and is the second language for most of the remaining 35%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-loc2_413-0"><a href="#cite_note-loc2-413">[411]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Religion">Religion</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Religion_in_Iran" title="Religion in Iran">Religion in Iran</a> and <a href="/wiki/Irreligion_in_Iran" title="Irreligion in Iran">Irreligion in Iran</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Islamization_of_Iran" title="Islamization of Iran">Islamization of Iran</a></div>
<table class="wikitable" style="margin-left:1em; font-size: 88%; float:right; clear:right">
<caption><b>Iranian people by religion, <br/> 2011 General Census Results</b><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-414"><a href="#cite_note-414">[412]</a></sup>
</caption>

<td style="text-align:center"><b>Religion</b></td>
<td style="background:#ccf; text-align:center"><b>Percent</b></td>
<td style="background:#ccf; text-align:center"><b>Number</b>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><a href="/wiki/Islam_in_Iran" title="Islam in Iran">Muslim</a></td>
<td style="text-align:center">99.3989%<br/><small>(90â95% Shia)</small></td>
<td style="text-align:right">74,682,938
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bah%C3%A1%27%C3%ADs_in_Iran" title="BahÃ¡'Ã­s in Iran">BahÃ¡'Ã­ Faith</a></td>
<td style="text-align:center">0.4%</td>
<td style="text-align:right">300,000
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><a href="/wiki/Christianity_in_Iran" title="Christianity in Iran">Christian</a></td>

<td style="text-align:right">117,704
</td></tr>

<td style="text-align:right">8,756
</td></tr>

<td>Other</td>
<td style="text-align:center">0.0653%</td>
<td style="text-align:right">49,101
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>Undeclared</td>
<td style="text-align:center">0.3538%</td>
<td style="text-align:right">205,317
</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Twelver" title="Twelver">Twelver</a> Shia Islam is the official <a href="/wiki/State_religion" title="State religion">state religion</a>, to which about 90% to 95%<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-415"><a href="#cite_note-415">[413]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-416"><a href="#cite_note-416">[414]</a></sup> of the population adhere. About 4% to 8% of the population are Sunni Muslims, mainly <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Iranian_Kurds" title="Iranian Kurds">Kurds</a> and Baloches. The remaining 2% are non-Muslim religious minorities, including <a href="/wiki/Christianity_in_Iran" title="Christianity in Iran">Christians</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Zoroastrians_in_Iran" title="Zoroastrians in Iran">Zoroastrians</a>, <a href="/wiki/Persian_Jews" title="Persian Jews">Jews</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bah%C3%A1%CA%BC%C3%AD_Faith_in_Iran" title="BahÃ¡Ê¼Ã­ Faith in Iran">BahÃ¡Ê¼Ã­s</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mandaeans" title="Mandaeans">Mandaeans</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Yarsanism" title="Yarsanism">Yarsanis</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CIA_3-7"><a href="#cite_note-CIA-3">[3]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-saving_417-0"><a href="#cite_note-saving-417">[415]</a></sup>
</p><p>A 2020 survey by the <a href="/wiki/World_Values_Survey" title="World Values Survey">World Values Survey</a> found that 96.6% of Iranians believe in Islam.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-worldvaluessurvey.org_418-0"><a href="#cite_note-worldvaluessurvey.org-418">[416]</a></sup>  On the other hand, another 2020 survey conducted online by an organization based outside of Iran found a much smaller percentage of Iranians identifying as Muslim (32.2% as Shia, 5.0% as Sunni, and 3.2% as <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sufi" title="Sufi">Sufi</a>), and a significant fraction not identifying with any organized religion (22.2% identifying as "None," and some others identifying as <a href="/wiki/Atheism" title="Atheism">atheists</a>, <a href="/wiki/Spiritual_but_not_religious" title="Spiritual but not religious">spiritual</a>, <a href="/wiki/Agnosticism" title="Agnosticism">agnostics</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Secular_humanism" title="Secular humanism">secular humanists</a>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-gamaan-attitudes_419-0"><a href="#cite_note-gamaan-attitudes-419">[417]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-conversation-shift_420-0"><a href="#cite_note-conversation-shift-420">[418]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-iranint-lost-2020_421-0"><a href="#cite_note-iranint-lost-2020-421">[419]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-422"><a href="#cite_note-422">[420]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-423"><a href="#cite_note-423">[421]</a></sup> According to the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/CIA_World_Factbook" title="CIA World Factbook">CIA World Factbook</a>, around 90â95% of Iranian Muslims associate themselves with the Shia branch of Islam, the official state religion, and about 5â10% with the Sunni and Sufi branches of Islam.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cia.gov_424-0"><a href="#cite_note-cia.gov-424">[422]</a></sup>
</p><p>There are a large population of adherents of <a href="/wiki/Yarsanism" title="Yarsanism">Yarsanism</a>, a <a href="/wiki/Kurds_in_Iran" title="Kurds in Iran">Kurdish</a> indigenous religion, making it the largest (unrecognized) minority religion in Iran. Its followers are mainly <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Guran_(Kurdish_tribe)" title="Guran (Kurdish tribe)">Gorani Kurds</a> and certain groups of <a href="/wiki/Lurs" title="Lurs">Lurs</a>. They are based in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kurdistan_Province" title="Kurdistan Province">Kurdistan Province</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kermanshah_Province" title="Kermanshah Province">Kermanshah Province</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Lorestan" title="Lorestan">Lorestan</a> mainly.
</p><p>Christianity, Judaism, Zoroastrianism, and the Sunni branch of Islam are officially recognized by the government and have reserved seats in the Iranian Parliament.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Colin_Brock_p_99_151-1"><a href="#cite_note-Colin_Brock_p_99-151">[149]</a></sup> Historically, early <a href="/wiki/Iranian_religions" title="Iranian religions">Iranian religions</a> such as the Proto-Iranic religion and the subsequent <a href="/wiki/Zoroastrianism" title="Zoroastrianism">Zoroastrianism</a> and <a href="/wiki/Manichaeism" title="Manichaeism">Manichaeism</a> were the dominant religions in Iran, particularly during the Median, Achaemenid, Parthian, and Sasanian eras. This changed after the fall of the Sasanian Empire by the centuries-long <a href="/wiki/Islamization_of_Iran" title="Islamization of Iran">Islamization</a> that followed the <a href="/wiki/Muslim_conquest_of_Persia" title="Muslim conquest of Persia">Muslim Conquest of Iran</a>. Iran was predominantly Sunni until the conversion of the country (as well as the people of what is today the neighboring Republic of Azerbaijan) to <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Shia" title="Shia">Shia</a> Islam by order of the <a href="/wiki/Safavid_dynasty" title="Safavid dynasty">Safavid dynasty</a> in the 16th century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Abdullah2014_132-1"><a href="#cite_note-Abdullah2014-132">[130]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/History_of_the_Jews_in_Iran" title="History of the Jews in Iran">Judaism has a long history in Iran</a>, dating back to the <a href="/wiki/Fall_of_Babylon" title="Fall of Babylon">Achaemenid conquest of Babylonia</a>. Although many left in the wake of the establishment of the State of Israel and the 1979 Revolution, about 8,756<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-IranCensusMurder_425-0"><a href="#cite_note-IranCensusMurder-425">[423]</a></sup> to 25,000<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-426"><a href="#cite_note-426">[424]</a></sup> Jewish people live in Iran. Iran has the largest Jewish population in the Middle East outside of Israel.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-427"><a href="#cite_note-427">[425]</a></sup>
</p><p>Around 250,000 to 370,000 <a href="/wiki/Christianity_in_Iran" title="Christianity in Iran">Christians reside in Iran</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Worldpopulationreview.com_November_29_2015c_428-0"><a href="#cite_note-Worldpopulationreview.com_November_29_2015c-428">[426]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-429"><a href="#cite_note-429">[427]</a></sup> and Christianity is the country's largest recognized minority religion.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-430"><a href="#cite_note-430">[428]</a></sup> Most are of Armenian background, as well as a sizable minority of Assyrians.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-IRFR2009-Iran_431-0"><a href="#cite_note-IRFR2009-Iran-431">[429]</a></sup> A large number of Iranians have converted to Christianity from the predominant <a href="/wiki/Shia_Islam" title="Shia Islam">Shia Islam</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Sanasarian200044_432-0"><a href="#cite_note-Sanasarian200044-432">[430]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-433"><a href="#cite_note-433">[431]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-434"><a href="#cite_note-434">[432]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-435"><a href="#cite_note-435">[433]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Bah%C3%A1%CA%BC%C3%AD_Faith" title="BahÃ¡Ê¼Ã­ Faith">BahÃ¡Ê¼Ã­ Faith</a> is not officially recognized and has been subject to official persecution.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-fdih2_436-0"><a href="#cite_note-fdih2-436">[434]</a></sup> According to the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Special_Rapporteur_on_Human_Rights_in_Iran" title="United Nations Special Rapporteur on Human Rights in Iran">United Nations Special Rapporteur on Human Rights in Iran</a>, BahÃ¡Ê¼Ã­s are the largest non-Muslim religious minority in Iran, with an estimated 350,000 adherents.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-UNSRHRI_437-0"><a href="#cite_note-UNSRHRI-437">[435]</a></sup> Since the 1979 Revolution, the <a href="/wiki/Persecution_of_Bah%C3%A1%CA%BC%C3%ADs" title="Persecution of BahÃ¡Ê¼Ã­s">persecution of BahÃ¡Ê¼Ã­s</a> has increased with executions and denial of civil rights, especially the denial of access to higher education and employment.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-fdih2_436-1"><a href="#cite_note-fdih2-436">[434]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ihrdc_438-0"><a href="#cite_note-ihrdc-438">[436]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-439"><a href="#cite_note-439">[437]</a></sup>
</p><p>Iranian officials have continued to support the rebuilding and renovation of Armenian churches in the Islamic Republic. The <a href="/wiki/Armenian_Monastic_Ensembles_of_Iran" title="Armenian Monastic Ensembles of Iran">Armenian Monastic Ensembles of Iran</a> has also received continued support. In 2019, the Iranian government registered the Holy Savior Cathedral, commonly referred to as <a href="/wiki/Vank_Cathedral" title="Vank Cathedral">Vank Cathedral</a>, in the <a href="/wiki/New_Julfa" title="New Julfa">New Julfa</a> district of <a href="/wiki/Isfahan" title="Isfahan">Isfahan</a>, as a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/UNESCO_World_Heritage_Site" title="UNESCO World Heritage Site">UNESCO World Heritage Site</a>, with significant expenditures for its congregation. Currently three Armenian churches in Iran have been included in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/UNESCO_World_Heritage_List" title="UNESCO World Heritage List">UNESCO World Heritage List</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-440"><a href="#cite_note-440">[438]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-441"><a href="#cite_note-441">[439]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Culture">Culture</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_Iran" title="Culture of Iran">Culture of Iran</a></div>
<p>The earliest attested cultures in Iran date back to the Lower Paleolithic. Owing to its geopolitical position, Iran has influenced cultures as far as Greece and Italy to the west, Russia to the north, the <a href="/wiki/Arabian_Peninsula" title="Arabian Peninsula">Arabian Peninsula</a> to the south, and <a href="/wiki/South_Asia" title="South Asia">south</a> and <a href="/wiki/East_Asia" title="East Asia">east Asia</a> to the east.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Art">Art</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Persian_art" title="Persian art">Iranian art</a> and <a href="/wiki/Arts_of_Iran" title="Arts of Iran">Arts of Iran</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Achaemenid_architecture" title="Achaemenid architecture">Achaemenid architecture</a>, <a href="/wiki/Parthian_art" title="Parthian art">Parthian art</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sasanian_art" title="Sasanian art">Sasanian art</a>, <a href="/wiki/Safavid_art" title="Safavid art">Safavid art</a>, <a href="/wiki/Qajar_art" title="Qajar art">Qajar art</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Iranian_modern_and_contemporary_art" title="Iranian modern and contemporary art">Iranian modern and contemporary art</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Cup_with_a_frieze_of_gazelles_MET_an62.84.R.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1651" data-file-width="2000" decoding="async" height="182" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1f/Cup_with_a_frieze_of_gazelles_MET_an62.84.R.jpg/220px-Cup_with_a_frieze_of_gazelles_MET_an62.84.R.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1f/Cup_with_a_frieze_of_gazelles_MET_an62.84.R.jpg/330px-Cup_with_a_frieze_of_gazelles_MET_an62.84.R.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1f/Cup_with_a_frieze_of_gazelles_MET_an62.84.R.jpg/440px-Cup_with_a_frieze_of_gazelles_MET_an62.84.R.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Cup_with_a_frieze_of_gazelles_MET_an62.84.R.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Iron_Age" title="Iron Age">Iron Age</a> gold cup from <a href="/wiki/Marlik" title="Marlik">Marlik</a>, kept at <a href="/wiki/New_York_City" title="New York City">New York City</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Metropolitan_Museum_of_Art" title="Metropolitan Museum of Art">Metropolitan Museum of Art</a></div></div></div>
<p>The art of Iran encompasses many disciplines, including <a href="/wiki/Iranian_architecture" title="Iranian architecture">architecture</a>, <a href="/wiki/Stonemasonry" title="Stonemasonry">stonemasonry</a>, <a href="/wiki/Metalworking" title="Metalworking">metalworking</a>, <a href="/wiki/Persian_carpet" title="Persian carpet">weaving</a>, <a href="/wiki/Persian_pottery" title="Persian pottery">pottery</a>, <a href="/wiki/Persian_miniature" title="Persian miniature">painting</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Persian_calligraphy" title="Persian calligraphy">calligraphy</a>. Iranian works of art show a great variety in style, in different regions and periods.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-442"><a href="#cite_note-442">[440]</a></sup> The art of the Medes remains obscure, but has been theoretically attributed to the <a href="/wiki/Scythian_art" title="Scythian art">Scythian style</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-443"><a href="#cite_note-443">[441]</a></sup> The Achaemenids borrowed heavily from the art of their neighboring civilizations,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-444"><a href="#cite_note-444">[442]</a></sup> but produced a synthesis of a unique style,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-445"><a href="#cite_note-445">[443]</a></sup> with <a href="/wiki/Achaemenid_architecture" title="Achaemenid architecture">an eclectic architecture</a> remaining at sites such as <a href="/wiki/Persepolis" title="Persepolis">Persepolis</a> and <a href="/wiki/Pasargadae" title="Pasargadae">Pasargadae</a>. Greek iconography was imported by the <a href="/wiki/Seleucid_Empire" title="Seleucid Empire">Seleucids</a>, followed by the recombination of <a href="/wiki/Hellenistic_art" title="Hellenistic art">Hellenistic</a> and earlier Near Eastern elements in the <a href="/wiki/Parthian_art" title="Parthian art">art of the Parthians</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-446"><a href="#cite_note-446">[444]</a></sup> with remains such as the <a href="/wiki/Temple_of_Anahita,_Kangavar" title="Temple of Anahita, Kangavar">Temple of Anahita</a> and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Statue,_National_Museum_of_Iran_2401" title="Statue, National Museum of Iran 2401">Statue of the Parthian Nobleman</a>. By the time of the Sasanians, Iranian art came across a general renaissance.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-447"><a href="#cite_note-447">[445]</a></sup> Although of unclear development,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-448"><a href="#cite_note-448">[446]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Sasanian_art" title="Sasanian art">Sasanian art</a> was highly influential, and spread into far regions. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Taq_Bostan" title="Taq Bostan">Taq-e-Bostan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Taq_Kasra" title="Taq Kasra">Taq-e-Kasra</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Naqsh-e_Rustam" title="Naqsh-e Rustam">Naqsh-e-Rostam</a>, and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Falak-ol-Aflak_Castle" title="Falak-ol-Aflak Castle">Shapur-Khwast Castle</a> are among the surviving monuments from the Sasanian period.
</p><p>During the Middle Ages, Sasanian art played a prominent role in the formation of both European and Asian medieval art,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Iransaga:_The_art_of_Sassanians_96-1"><a href="#cite_note-Iransaga:_The_art_of_Sassanians-96">[94]</a></sup> which carried forward to the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Islamic_world" title="Islamic world">Islamic world</a>, and much of what later became known as Islamic learningâincluding <a href="/wiki/Medicine_in_the_medieval_Islamic_world" title="Medicine in the medieval Islamic world">medicine</a>, <a href="/wiki/Islamic_architecture" title="Islamic architecture">architecture</a>, <a href="/wiki/Early_Islamic_philosophy" title="Early Islamic philosophy">philosophy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Philology" title="Philology">philology</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Islamic_literature" title="Islamic literature">literature</a>âwere of Sasanian basis.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-449"><a href="#cite_note-449">[447]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-450"><a href="#cite_note-450">[448]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Iran_in_Britannica_451-0"><a href="#cite_note-Iran_in_Britannica-451">[449]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-452"><a href="#cite_note-452">[450]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Safavid era is known as the <i>Golden Age</i> of Iranian art,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-453"><a href="#cite_note-453">[451]</a></sup> and Safavid works of art show a far more unitary development than in any other period,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Safavable_454-0"><a href="#cite_note-Safavable-454">[452]</a></sup> as part of a political evolution that reunified Iran as a cultural entity.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Safavable_454-1"><a href="#cite_note-Safavable-454">[452]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Safavid_art" title="Safavid art">Safavid art</a> exerted noticeable influences upon the neighboring <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">Ottomans</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Mughal_Empire" title="Mughal Empire">Mughals</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Deccan_sultanates" title="Deccan sultanates">Deccans</a>, and was also influential through its fashion and garden architecture on 11thâ17th-century Europe.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Safavable_454-2"><a href="#cite_note-Safavable-454">[452]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Mirror_Hall.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1220" data-file-width="1640" decoding="async" height="164" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4f/Mirror_Hall.jpg/220px-Mirror_Hall.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4f/Mirror_Hall.jpg/330px-Mirror_Hall.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4f/Mirror_Hall.jpg/440px-Mirror_Hall.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Mirror_Hall.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Kamal-ol-molk" title="Kamal-ol-molk">Kamal-ol-Molk</a>'s <i><a href="/wiki/Mirror_Hall" title="Mirror Hall">Mirror Hall</a></i>, often considered a starting point in <a href="/wiki/Iranian_modern_and_contemporary_art" title="Iranian modern and contemporary art">Iranian modern art</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-455"><a href="#cite_note-455">[453]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>Iran's <a href="/wiki/Iranian_modern_and_contemporary_art" title="Iranian modern and contemporary art">contemporary art</a> traces its origins back to the time of <a href="/wiki/Kamal-ol-molk" title="Kamal-ol-molk">Kamal-ol-Molk</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-IrMo_456-0"><a href="#cite_note-IrMo-456">[454]</a></sup> a prominent <a href="/wiki/Realism_(arts)" title="Realism (arts)">realist</a> painter at the court of the <a href="/wiki/Qajar_dynasty" title="Qajar dynasty">Qajar dynasty</a> who affected the norms of painting and adopted a naturalistic style that would compete with photographic works. A new Iranian school of fine art was established by Kamal-ol-Molk in 1928,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-IrMo_456-1"><a href="#cite_note-IrMo-456">[454]</a></sup> and was followed by the so-called "coffeehouse" style of painting.
</p><p>Iran's <a href="/wiki/Avant-garde" title="Avant-garde">avant-garde</a> modernists emerged by the arrival of new western influences during World War II.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-IrMo_456-2"><a href="#cite_note-IrMo-456">[454]</a></sup> The vibrant contemporary art scene originates in the late 1940s, and Tehran's first modern art gallery, Apadana, was opened in September 1949 by painters Mahmud Javadipur, Hosein Kazemi, and Hushang Ajudani.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-457"><a href="#cite_note-457">[455]</a></sup> The new movements received official encouragement by the mid-1950s,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-IrMo_456-3"><a href="#cite_note-IrMo-456">[454]</a></sup> which led to the emergence of artists such as <a href="/wiki/Marcos_Grigorian" title="Marcos Grigorian">Marcos Grigorian</a>, signaling a commitment to the creation of a form of modern art grounded in Iran.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-458"><a href="#cite_note-458">[456]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Architecture">Architecture</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Iranian_architecture" title="Iranian architecture">Iranian architecture</a> and <a href="/wiki/Persian_gardens" title="Persian gardens">Persian gardens</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:224px;max-width:224px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:222px;max-width:222px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Persepolis_06.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="1200" data-file-width="1600" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c9/Persepolis_06.jpg/220px-Persepolis_06.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c9/Persepolis_06.jpg/330px-Persepolis_06.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c9/Persepolis_06.jpg/440px-Persepolis_06.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption">Ruins of the <a href="/wiki/Tachara" title="Tachara">Tachara</a>, part of the <a href="/wiki/World_Heritage_Site" title="World Heritage Site">World Heritage Site</a> of <a href="/wiki/Persepolis" title="Persepolis">Persepolis</a></div></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:222px;max-width:222px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Naghshe_Jahan_Square_Isfahan_modified.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="1470" data-file-width="2096" decoding="async" height="154" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d6/Naghshe_Jahan_Square_Isfahan_modified.jpg/220px-Naghshe_Jahan_Square_Isfahan_modified.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d6/Naghshe_Jahan_Square_Isfahan_modified.jpg/330px-Naghshe_Jahan_Square_Isfahan_modified.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d6/Naghshe_Jahan_Square_Isfahan_modified.jpg/440px-Naghshe_Jahan_Square_Isfahan_modified.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Isfahan" title="Isfahan">Isfahan</a>'s <a href="/wiki/World_Heritage_Site" title="World Heritage Site">World Heritage Site</a> of <a href="/wiki/Naqsh-e_Jahan_Square" title="Naqsh-e Jahan Square">Naqsh-e Jahan Square</a></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>The history of architecture in Iran goes back to the seventh millennium BC.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-459"><a href="#cite_note-459">[457]</a></sup> Iranians were among the first to use <a href="/wiki/Mathematics" title="Mathematics">mathematics</a>, <a href="/wiki/Geometry" title="Geometry">geometry</a> and <a href="/wiki/Astronomy" title="Astronomy">astronomy</a> in architecture. Iranian architecture displays great variety, both structural and aesthetic, developing gradually and coherently out of earlier traditions and experience.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-460"><a href="#cite_note-460">[458]</a></sup> The guiding <a href="/wiki/Motif_(visual_arts)" title="Motif (visual arts)">motif</a> of Iranian architecture is its cosmic symbolism, "by which man is brought into communication and participation with the powers of heaven".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-461"><a href="#cite_note-461">[459]</a></sup>
</p><p>Iran ranks seventh among <a href="/wiki/UNESCO" title="UNESCO">UNESCO</a>'s list of countries with the most archaeological ruins and attractions from antiquity.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-462"><a href="#cite_note-462">[460]</a></sup>
</p><p>Traditionally, the guiding formative motif of Iranian architecture has been its cosmic <a href="/wiki/Symbol" title="Symbol">symbolism</a> "by which man is brought into communication and participation with the powers of heaven".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-463"><a href="#cite_note-463">[461]</a></sup> This theme has not only given unity and continuity to the architecture of Persia but has been a primary source of its emotional character as well.
</p><p>According to Persian historian and archaeologist <a href="/wiki/Arthur_Upham_Pope" title="Arthur Upham Pope">Arthur Pope</a>, the supreme Iranian art, in the proper meaning of the word, has always been its architecture. The supremacy of architecture applies to both pre- and post-Islamic periods.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-464"><a href="#cite_note-464">[462]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Weaving">Weaving</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Persian_carpet" title="Persian carpet">Persian carpet</a></div>
<p>Iran's carpet-weaving has its origins in the Bronze Age and is one of the most distinguished manifestations of Iranian art. Iran is the world's largest producer and exporter of handmade carpets, producing three-quarters of the world's total output and having a share of 30% of world's export markets.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Goswami2009_465-0"><a href="#cite_note-Goswami2009-465">[463]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-466"><a href="#cite_note-466">[464]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Literature">Literature</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Literature_in_Iran" title="Literature in Iran">Literature in Iran</a>, <a href="/wiki/Iranian_literature" title="Iranian literature">Iranian literature</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Persian_literature" title="Persian literature">Persian literature</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ferdowsi_tomb4.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1536" data-file-width="2048" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3c/Ferdowsi_tomb4.jpg/220px-Ferdowsi_tomb4.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3c/Ferdowsi_tomb4.jpg/330px-Ferdowsi_tomb4.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3c/Ferdowsi_tomb4.jpg/440px-Ferdowsi_tomb4.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Ferdowsi_tomb4.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Tomb of the tenth-century Persian poet <a href="/wiki/Ferdowsi" title="Ferdowsi">Ferdowsi</a>, author of <i><a href="/wiki/Shahnameh" title="Shahnameh">Å ÄhnÄme</a></i>, the classical Persian composition of the Iranian <a href="/wiki/National_epic" title="National epic">national epics</a>, in <a href="/wiki/Tus,_Iran" title="Tus, Iran">Tus</a></div></div></div>
<p>Iran's oldest <a href="/wiki/Literature" title="Literature">literary tradition</a> is that of <a href="/wiki/Avestan" title="Avestan">Avestan</a>, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Old_Iranian" title="Old Iranian">Old Iranian</a> <a href="/wiki/Sacred_language" title="Sacred language">sacred language</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Avesta" title="Avesta">Avesta</a>, which consists of the legendary and religious texts of <a href="/wiki/Zoroastrianism" title="Zoroastrianism">Zoroastrianism</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Iranian_religion" title="Ancient Iranian religion">ancient Iranian religion</a>, with its earliest records dating back to the pre-Achaemenid times.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-467"><a href="#cite_note-467">[465]</a></sup>
</p><p>Of the various modern languages used in Iran, <a href="/wiki/Persian_language" title="Persian language">Persian</a>, various dialects of which are spoken throughout the Iranian Plateau,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-468"><a href="#cite_note-468">[466]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-469"><a href="#cite_note-469">[467]</a></sup> has the most influential literature. Persian has been dubbed as a worthy language to serve as a conduit for poetry, and is considered one of the four main bodies of world literature.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-470"><a href="#cite_note-470">[468]</a></sup> Despite originating from the region of <a href="/wiki/Persis" title="Persis">Persis</a> (better known as <i>Persia</i>) in southwestern Iran, the Persian language was used and developed further through <a href="/wiki/Persianate_society" title="Persianate society">Persianate societies</a> in <a href="/wiki/Anatolia" title="Anatolia">Asia Minor</a>, <a href="/wiki/Central_Asia" title="Central Asia">Central Asia</a>, and <a href="/wiki/South_Asia" title="South Asia">South Asia</a>, leaving massive influences on <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_poetry" title="Ottoman poetry">Ottoman</a> and <a href="/wiki/Persian_language_in_the_Indian_subcontinent" title="Persian language in the Indian subcontinent">Mughal literatures</a>, among others.
</p><p>Iran has a number of famous medieval poets, most notably <a href="/wiki/Rumi" title="Rumi">Rumi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ferdowsi" title="Ferdowsi">Ferdowsi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hafez" title="Hafez">Hafez</a>, <a href="/wiki/Saadi_Shirazi" title="Saadi Shirazi">Sa'adi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Omar_Khayyam" title="Omar Khayyam">Omar Khayyam</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Nizami_Ganjavi" title="Nizami Ganjavi">Nezami Ganjavi</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-471"><a href="#cite_note-471">[469]</a></sup> Iranian literature also inspired writers such as <a href="/wiki/Johann_Wolfgang_von_Goethe" title="Johann Wolfgang von Goethe">Johann Wolfgang von Goethe</a>, <a href="/wiki/Henry_David_Thoreau" title="Henry David Thoreau">Henry David Thoreau</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Ralph_Waldo_Emerson" title="Ralph Waldo Emerson">Ralph Waldo Emerson</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Paul_Kane_114-1"><a href="#cite_note-Paul_Kane-114">[112]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Shafiq_Shamel_115-1"><a href="#cite_note-Shafiq_Shamel-115">[113]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Adineh_Khojasteh_Pour_and_Behnam_Mirza_Baba_Zadeh_116-1"><a href="#cite_note-Adineh_Khojasteh_Pour_and_Behnam_Mirza_Baba_Zadeh-116">[114]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Philosophy">Philosophy</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Ancient_philosophy#Ancient_Iranian_philosophy" title="Ancient philosophy">Ancient philosophy Â§Â Ancient Iranian philosophy</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Iranian_philosophy" title="Iranian philosophy">Iranian philosophy</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Raffael_071.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1205" data-file-width="2048" decoding="async" height="129" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/be/Raffael_071.jpg/220px-Raffael_071.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/be/Raffael_071.jpg/330px-Raffael_071.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/be/Raffael_071.jpg/440px-Raffael_071.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Raffael_071.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Zoroaster" title="Zoroaster">Zoroaster</a>, the founder of <a href="/wiki/Zoroastrianism" title="Zoroastrianism">Zoroastrianism</a>, depicted on <a href="/wiki/Raphael" title="Raphael">Raphael</a>'s <i><a href="/wiki/The_School_of_Athens" title="The School of Athens">The School of Athens</a></i></div></div></div>
<p>Iranian philosophy originates from <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Proto-Indo-European_religion" title="Proto-Indo-European religion">Indo-European</a> roots, with <a href="/wiki/Zoroaster" title="Zoroaster">Zoroaster</a>'s reforms having major influences.
</p><p>According to <i><a href="/wiki/The_Oxford_Dictionary_of_Philosophy" title="The Oxford Dictionary of Philosophy">The Oxford Dictionary of Philosophy</a></i>, the chronology of the subject and science of philosophy starts with the Indo-Iranians, dating this event to 1500 BC. The Oxford dictionary also states, "Zarathushtra's philosophy entered to influence Western tradition through Judaism, and therefore on <a href="/wiki/Middle_Platonism" title="Middle Platonism">Middle Platonism</a>."
</p><p>While there are <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Proto-Indo-Iranian_religion" title="Proto-Indo-Iranian religion">ancient relations</a> between the Indian <a href="/wiki/Vedas" title="Vedas">Vedas</a> and the Iranian <a href="/wiki/Avesta" title="Avesta">Avesta</a>, the two main families of the Indo-Iranian philosophical traditions were characterized by fundamental differences, especially in their implications for the human being's position in society and their view of man's role in the universe.
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Cyrus_Cylinder" title="Cyrus Cylinder">Cyrus Cylinder</a>, which is known as "the first charter of <a href="/wiki/Human_rights" title="Human rights">human rights</a>", is often seen as a reflection of the questions and thoughts expressed by Zoroaster, and developed in Zoroastrian schools of the Achaemenid era.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-472"><a href="#cite_note-472">[470]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-473"><a href="#cite_note-473">[471]</a></sup> The earliest tenets of Zoroastrian schools are part of the extant scriptures of the Zoroastrian religion in <a href="/wiki/Avestan" title="Avestan">Avestan</a>. Among them are treatises such as the Zatspram, <a href="/wiki/Shikand-gumanig_Vizar" title="Shikand-gumanig Vizar">Shkand-gumanik Vizar</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Denkard" title="Denkard">Denkard</a>, as well as older passages of the Avesta and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gathas" title="Gathas">Gathas</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-474"><a href="#cite_note-474">[472]</a></sup>
</p><p>The current trends in Iranian philosophy have grown limited in scope because of Islamic frames of thought <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-475"><a href="#cite_note-475">[473]</a></sup> although the liberal ways of thought remain open to be generated in Iranian publications by Iranian intellectuals, especially outside Iran, where the Iranian regime has less power to restrict Iranian thought and philosophy.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Mythology">Mythology</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Persian_mythology" title="Persian mythology">Persian mythology</a> and <a href="/wiki/Iranian_folklore" title="Iranian folklore">Iranian folklore</a></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Persian_mythology" title="Persian mythology">Iranian mythology</a> consists of ancient <a href="/wiki/Iranian_folklore" title="Iranian folklore">Iranian folklore</a> and stories, all involving extraordinary beings, reflecting attitudes towards the confrontation of <a href="/wiki/Good_and_evil" title="Good and evil">good and evil</a>, actions of the gods, and the exploits of heroes and fabulous creatures.
</p><p>Myths play a crucial part in Iranian culture, and understanding of them is increased when they are considered within the context of actual events in Iranian history. The geography of Greater Iran, a vast area covering present-day Iran, the Caucasus, Anatolia, Mesopotamia and Central Asia, with its high mountain ranges, plays the main role in much of Iranian mythology.
</p><p>Tenth-century Persian poet <a href="/wiki/Ferdowsi" title="Ferdowsi">Ferdowsi</a>'s long <a href="/wiki/Epic_poetry" title="Epic poetry">epic poem</a> <i><a href="/wiki/Shahnameh" title="Shahnameh">Å ÄhnÄme</a></i> ("Book of Kings"), which is for the most part based on <i>XwadÄynÄmag</i>, a <a href="/wiki/Middle_Persian" title="Middle Persian">Middle Persian</a> compilation of the history of Iranian kings and heroes from mythical times down to the reign of <a href="/wiki/Khosrow_II" title="Khosrow II">Chosroes II</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-476"><a href="#cite_note-476">[474]</a></sup> is considered the <a href="/wiki/National_epic" title="National epic">national epic</a> of Iran. It draws heavily on the stories and characters of the Zoroastrian tradition, from the texts of the <a href="/wiki/Avesta" title="Avesta">Avesta</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Denkard" title="Denkard">Denkard</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Bundahishn" title="Bundahishn">Bundahishn</a>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Music">Music</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Music_of_Iran" title="Music of Iran">Music of Iran</a></div>
<p>Iran is the apparent birthplace of the earliest complex instruments, dating back to the third millennium BC.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-477"><a href="#cite_note-477">[475]</a></sup> The use of both vertical and horizontal angular <a href="/wiki/Harp" title="Harp">harps</a> have been documented at the sites Madaktu and <a href="/wiki/Kul-e_Farah" title="Kul-e Farah">Kul-e Farah</a>, with the largest collection of <a href="/wiki/Elam" title="Elam">Elamite</a> instruments documented at Kul-e Farah. Multiple depictions of horizontal harps were also sculpted in Assyrian palaces, dating back between 865 and 650 BC.
</p>
