<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Karna-Persian-Instrument-Persepolis-Museum.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="800" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Karna-Persian-Instrument-Persepolis-Museum.JPG/220px-Karna-Persian-Instrument-Persepolis-Museum.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Karna-Persian-Instrument-Persepolis-Museum.JPG/330px-Karna-Persian-Instrument-Persepolis-Museum.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Karna-Persian-Instrument-Persepolis-Museum.JPG/440px-Karna-Persian-Instrument-Persepolis-Museum.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Karna-Persian-Instrument-Persepolis-Museum.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Zurna" title="Zurna">Karna</a>, an ancient Iranian musical instrument from the sixth century BC, kept at the Persepolis Museum</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Xenophon" title="Xenophon">Xenophon</a>'s <i><a href="/wiki/Cyropaedia" title="Cyropaedia">Cyropaedia</a></i> mentions a great number of singing women at the court of the <a href="/wiki/Achaemenid_Empire" title="Achaemenid Empire">Achaemenid Empire</a>. <a href="/wiki/Athenaeus" title="Athenaeus">Athenaeus</a> of <a href="/wiki/Naucratis" title="Naucratis">Naucratis</a>, in his <i><a href="/wiki/Deipnosophistae" title="Deipnosophistae">Deipnosophistae</a></i>, points out to the capture of Achaemenid singing girls at the court of the last Achaemenid king <a href="/wiki/Darius_III" title="Darius III">Darius III</a> (336â330 BC) by <a href="/wiki/Macedonia_(ancient_kingdom)" title="Macedonia (ancient kingdom)">Macedonian</a> general <a href="/wiki/Parmenion" title="Parmenion">Parmenion</a>. Under the <a href="/wiki/Parthian_Empire" title="Parthian Empire">Parthian Empire</a>, the <i><a href="/wiki/Gusans" title="Gusans">gÅsÄn</a></i> (<a href="/wiki/Parthian_language" title="Parthian language">Parthian</a> for "minstrel") had a prominent role in the society.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-478"><a href="#cite_note-478">[476]</a></sup> According to <a href="/wiki/Plutarch" title="Plutarch">Plutarch</a>'s <i>Life of Crassus</i> (32.3), they praised their national heroes and ridiculed their Roman rivals. Likewise, <a href="/wiki/Strabo" title="Strabo">Strabo</a>'s <i><a href="/wiki/Geographica" title="Geographica">Geographica</a></i> reports that the Parthian youth were taught songs about "the deeds both of the gods and of the noblest men".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-479"><a href="#cite_note-479">[477]</a></sup>
</p><p>The history of <a href="/wiki/Sasanian_music" title="Sasanian music">Sasanian music</a> is better documented than the earlier periods and is especially more evident in Avestan texts.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EI-mhphi_480-0"><a href="#cite_note-EI-mhphi-480">[478]</a></sup> By the time of <a href="/wiki/Khosrow_II" title="Khosrow II">Chosroes II</a>, the Sasanian royal court hosted a number of prominent musicians, namely Azad, <a href="/wiki/Bamshad" title="Bamshad">Bamshad</a>, <a href="/wiki/Barbad" title="Barbad">Barbad</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nagisa_(harpist)" title="Nagisa (harpist)">Nagisa</a>, Ramtin, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sarkash" title="Sarkash">Sarkash</a>.
</p><p>Iranian traditional musical instruments include string instruments such as <a href="/wiki/Chang_(instrument)" title="Chang (instrument)">chang</a> (<a href="/wiki/Harp" title="Harp">harp</a>), <a href="/wiki/Qanun_(instrument)" title="Qanun (instrument)">qanun</a>, <a href="/wiki/Santur" title="Santur">santur</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rud" title="Rud">rud</a> (<a href="/wiki/Oud" title="Oud">oud</a>, <a href="/wiki/Barbat_(lute)" title="Barbat (lute)">barbat</a>), <a href="/wiki/Tar_(string_instrument)" title="Tar (string instrument)">tar</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dutar" title="Dutar">dotar</a>, <a href="/wiki/Setar" title="Setar">setar</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tanbur" title="Tanbur">tanbur</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Kamancheh" title="Kamancheh">kamanche</a>, wind instruments such as <a href="/wiki/Sorna" title="Sorna">sorna</a> (<a href="/wiki/Zurna" title="Zurna">zurna</a>, <a href="/wiki/Karnay" title="Karnay">karna</a>) and <a href="/wiki/Ney" title="Ney">ney</a>, and percussion instruments such as <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tonbak" title="Tonbak">tompak</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kus" title="Kus">kus</a>, <a href="/wiki/Daf" title="Daf">daf</a> (<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Dayereh" title="Dayereh">dayere</a>), and <a href="/wiki/Naqareh" title="Naqareh">naqare</a>.
</p><p>Iran's first symphony orchestra, the <a href="/wiki/Tehran_Symphony_Orchestra" title="Tehran Symphony Orchestra">Tehran Symphony Orchestra</a>, was founded by Qolam-Hoseyn Minbashian in 1933. It was reformed by <a href="/wiki/Parviz_Mahmoud" title="Parviz Mahmoud">Parviz Mahmoud</a> in 1946, and is currently Iran's oldest and largest symphony orchestra. Later, by the late 1940s, <a href="/wiki/Ruhollah_Khaleqi" title="Ruhollah Khaleqi">Ruhollah Khaleqi</a> founded the country's first national music society, and established the School of National Music in 1949.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-481"><a href="#cite_note-481">[479]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Iranian_pop_music" title="Iranian pop music">Iranian pop music</a> has its origins in the Qajar era.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-482"><a href="#cite_note-482">[480]</a></sup> It was significantly developed since the 1950s, using indigenous instruments and forms accompanied by <a href="/wiki/Electric_guitar" title="Electric guitar">electric guitar</a> and other imported characteristics. The emergence of genres such as <a href="/wiki/Iranian_rock" title="Iranian rock">rock</a> in the 1960s and <a href="/wiki/Iranian_hip_hop" title="Iranian hip hop">hip hop</a> in the 2000s also resulted in major movements and influences in Iranian music.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-483"><a href="#cite_note-483">[481]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-484"><a href="#cite_note-484">[482]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-485"><a href="#cite_note-485">[483]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-486"><a href="#cite_note-486">[484]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Theater">Theater</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Persian_theater" title="Persian theater">Persian theater</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Persian_dance" title="Persian dance">Persian dance</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:RudakiHall.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="400" data-file-width="639" decoding="async" height="138" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cd/RudakiHall.jpg/220px-RudakiHall.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cd/RudakiHall.jpg/330px-RudakiHall.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cd/RudakiHall.jpg/440px-RudakiHall.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:RudakiHall.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Roudaki_Hall" title="Roudaki Hall">Roudaki Hall</a>, constructed between 1957 and 1967 in <a href="/wiki/Tehran" title="Tehran">Tehran</a></div></div></div>
<p>The earliest recorded representations of dancing figures within Iran were found in prehistoric sites such as Tepe Sialk and Tepe MÅ«sÄ«Än.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-487"><a href="#cite_note-487">[485]</a></sup> The oldest Iranian initiation of theater and the phenomena of acting can be traced in the ancient epic ceremonial theaters such as <i>Sug-e SiÄvuÅ¡</i> ("mourning of <a href="/wiki/Siy%C3%A2vash" title="SiyÃ¢vash">SiÄvaÅ¡</a>"), as well as dances and theater narrations of Iranian mythological tales reported by <a href="/wiki/Herodotus" title="Herodotus">Herodotus</a> and <a href="/wiki/Xenophon" title="Xenophon">Xenophon</a>.
</p><p>Iran's traditional theatrical genres include BaqqÄl-bÄzi ("grocer play", a form of slapstick comedy), Ruhowzi (or <i>Taxt-howzi</i>, comedy performed over a courtyard pool covered with boards), SiÄh-bÄzi (in which the central comedian appears in blackface), SÄye-bÄzi (<a href="/wiki/Shadow_play" title="Shadow play">shadow play</a>), Xeyme-Å¡ab-bÄzi (<a href="/wiki/Marionette" title="Marionette">marionette</a>), and Arusak-bÄzi (<a href="/wiki/Puppetry" title="Puppetry">puppetry</a>), and <a href="/wiki/Ta%27zieh" title="Ta'zieh">Ta'zie</a> (religious tragedy plays).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-488"><a href="#cite_note-488">[486]</a></sup>
</p><p>Before the 1979 Revolution, the Iranian national stage had become a famous performing scene for known international artists and troupes,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-489"><a href="#cite_note-489">[487]</a></sup> with the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Roudaki_Hall" title="Roudaki Hall">Roudaki Hall</a> of Tehran constructed to function as the national stage for <a href="/wiki/Opera" title="Opera">opera</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ballet" title="Ballet">ballet</a>. Opened on 26 October 1967, the hall is home to the <a href="/wiki/Tehran_Symphony_Orchestra" title="Tehran Symphony Orchestra">Tehran Symphony Orchestra</a>, the Tehran Opera Orchestra, and the <a href="/wiki/Iranian_National_Ballet_Company" title="Iranian National Ballet Company">Iranian National Ballet Company</a>, and was officially renamed <i>Vahdat Hall</i> after the 1979 Revolution.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Loris_Tjeknavorian" title="Loris Tjeknavorian">Loris Tjeknavorian</a>'s <i><a href="/wiki/Rostam_and_Sohrab_(opera)" title="Rostam and Sohrab (opera)">Rostam and Sohrab</a></i>, based on the tragedy of <i><a href="/wiki/Rostam_and_Sohrab" title="Rostam and Sohrab">Rostam and Sohrab</a></i> from <a href="/wiki/Ferdowsi" title="Ferdowsi">Ferdowsi</a>'s epic poem <i><a href="/wiki/Shahnameh" title="Shahnameh">Å ÄhnÄme</a></i>, is an example of opera with Persian <a href="/wiki/Libretto" title="Libretto">libretto</a>. Tjeknavorian, a celebrated <a href="/wiki/Iranian_Armenians" title="Iranian Armenians">Iranian Armenian</a> composer and conductor, composed it in 25 years, and it was finally performed for the first time at Tehran's Roudaki Hall, with <a href="/wiki/Darya_Dadvar" title="Darya Dadvar">Darya Dadvar</a> in the role of <a href="/wiki/Tahmina" title="Tahmina">Tahmina</a>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cinema_and_animation">Cinema and animation</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Cinema_of_Iran" title="Cinema of Iran">Cinema of Iran</a> and <a href="/wiki/History_of_Iranian_animation" title="History of Iranian animation">History of Iranian animation</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:252px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Vase_animation.svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="426" data-file-width="2384" decoding="async" height="45" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1f/Vase_animation.svg/250px-Vase_animation.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1f/Vase_animation.svg/375px-Vase_animation.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1f/Vase_animation.svg/500px-Vase_animation.svg.png 2x" width="250"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Vase_animation.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Reproduction of the third-millennium BC goblet from southeastern Iran, possibly the world's oldest example of animation<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-490"><a href="#cite_note-490">[488]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>A third-millennium BC earthen goblet discovered at the <a href="/wiki/Shahr-e_Sukhteh" title="Shahr-e Sukhteh">Burnt City</a>, a Bronze Age urban settlement in southeastern Iran, depicts what could possibly be the world's oldest example of animation. The artifact, associated with <a href="/wiki/Jiroft_culture" title="Jiroft culture">Jiroft</a>, bears five sequential images depicting a wild goat jumping up to eat the leaves of a tree.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-491"><a href="#cite_note-491">[489]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-492"><a href="#cite_note-492">[490]</a></sup> The earliest attested Iranian examples of visual representations, however, are traced back to the bas-reliefs of Persepolis, the ritual center of the <a href="/wiki/Achaemenid_Empire" title="Achaemenid Empire">Achaemenid Empire</a>. The figures at Persepolis remain bound by the rules of grammar and syntax of visual language.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-493"><a href="#cite_note-493">[491]</a></sup> The Iranian visual arts reached a pinnacle by the <a href="/wiki/Sasanian_Empire" title="Sasanian Empire">Sasanian era</a>, and several works from this period have been found to articulate movements and actions in a highly sophisticated manner. It is even possible to see a progenitor of the cinematic close-up shot in one of these works of art, which shows a wounded wild pig escaping from the hunting ground.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-horschamp1_494-0"><a href="#cite_note-horschamp1-494">[492]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Kiarostami-1940.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="310" data-file-width="300" decoding="async" height="176" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b6/Kiarostami-1940.jpg/170px-Kiarostami-1940.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b6/Kiarostami-1940.jpg/255px-Kiarostami-1940.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/b/b6/Kiarostami-1940.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Kiarostami-1940.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Abbas_Kiarostami" title="Abbas Kiarostami">Abbas Kiarostami</a> (1940â2016), an acclaimed Iranian film director</div></div></div>
<p>By the early 20th century, the five-year-old industry of cinema came to Iran. The first Iranian filmmaker was probably <a href="/wiki/Mirza_Ebrahim_Khan_Akkas_Bashi" title="Mirza Ebrahim Khan Akkas Bashi">Mirza Ebrahim (Akkas Bashi)</a>, the court photographer of <a href="/wiki/Mozaffar_ad-Din_Shah_Qajar" title="Mozaffar ad-Din Shah Qajar">Mozaffar-ed-Din Shah</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Qajar_dynasty" title="Qajar dynasty">Qajar dynasty</a>. Mirza Ebrahim obtained a camera and filmed the Qajar ruler's visit to Europe. Later in 1904, <a href="/wiki/Mirza_Ebrahim_Khan_Sahhafbashi" title="Mirza Ebrahim Khan Sahhafbashi">Mirza Ebrahim (Sahhaf Bashi)</a>, a businessman, opened the first public movie theater in Tehran.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-massoudmehrabi1_495-0"><a href="#cite_note-massoudmehrabi1-495">[493]</a></sup> After him, several others like Russi Khan, Ardeshir Khan, and Ali Vakili tried to establish new movie theaters in Tehran. Until the early 1930s, there were around 15 cinema theaters in Tehran and 11 in other provinces.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-horschamp1_494-1"><a href="#cite_note-horschamp1-494">[492]</a></sup> The first Iranian feature film, <i><a href="/wiki/Abi_and_Rabi" title="Abi and Rabi">Abi and Rabi</a></i>, was a silent comedy directed by <a href="/wiki/Ovanes_Ohanian" title="Ovanes Ohanian">Ovanes Ohanian</a> in 1930. The first sounded one, <i><a href="/wiki/Lor_Girl" title="Lor Girl">Lor Girl</a></i>, was produced by <a href="/wiki/Ardeshir_Irani" title="Ardeshir Irani">Ardeshir Irani</a> and <a href="/wiki/Abdolhossein_Sepanta" title="Abdolhossein Sepanta">Abd-ol-Hosein Sepanta</a> in 1932.
</p><p>Iran's animation industry began by the 1950s, and was followed by the establishment of the influential <a href="/wiki/Institute_for_the_Intellectual_Development_of_Children_and_Young_Adults" title="Institute for the Intellectual Development of Children and Young Adults">Institute for the Intellectual Development of Children and Young Adults</a> in January 1965.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-496"><a href="#cite_note-496">[494]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-497"><a href="#cite_note-497">[495]</a></sup> The 1960s was a significant decade for Iranian cinema, with 25 commercial films produced annually on average throughout the early 60s, increasing to 65 by the end of the decade. The majority of the production focused on melodrama and thrillers. With the screening of the films <i><a href="/wiki/Qeysar_(film)" title="Qeysar (film)">Qeysar</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/The_Cow_(1969_film)" title="The Cow (1969 film)">The Cow</a></i>, directed by <a href="/wiki/Masoud_Kimiai" title="Masoud Kimiai">Masoud Kimiai</a> and <a href="/wiki/Dariush_Mehrjui" title="Dariush Mehrjui">Dariush Mehrjui</a> respectively in 1969, alternative films set out to establish their status in the film industry and <a href="/wiki/Bahram_Beyzai" title="Bahram Beyzai">Bahram Beyzai</a>'s <i><a href="/wiki/Downpour_(film)" title="Downpour (film)">Downpour</a></i> and <a href="/wiki/Nasser_Taghvai" title="Nasser Taghvai">Nasser Taghvai</a>'s <i>Tranquility in the Presence of Others</i> followed soon. Attempts to organize a film festival, which had begun in 1954 within the framework of the Golrizan Festival, resulted in the festival of Sepas in 1969. The endeavors also resulted in the formation of Tehran's World Film Festival in 1973.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Esfandiary2012_498-0"><a href="#cite_note-Esfandiary2012-498">[496]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Behrouz_Vossoughi.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="579" data-file-width="435" decoding="async" height="226" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6e/Behrouz_Vossoughi.jpg/170px-Behrouz_Vossoughi.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6e/Behrouz_Vossoughi.jpg/255px-Behrouz_Vossoughi.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6e/Behrouz_Vossoughi.jpg/340px-Behrouz_Vossoughi.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Behrouz_Vossoughi.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Behrouz_Vossoughi" title="Behrouz Vossoughi">Behrouz Vossoughi</a>, a well-known Iranian actor who has appeared in more than 90 films</div></div></div>
<p>After the Revolution of 1979, and following the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Iranian_Cultural_Revolution" title="Iranian Cultural Revolution">Cultural Revolution</a>, a new age emerged in Iranian cinema, starting with <i>Long Live!</i> by <a href="/wiki/Khosrow_Sinai" title="Khosrow Sinai">Khosrow Sinai</a> and followed by many other directors, such as <a href="/wiki/Abbas_Kiarostami" title="Abbas Kiarostami">Abbas Kiarostami</a> and <a href="/wiki/Jafar_Panahi" title="Jafar Panahi">Jafar Panahi</a>. Kiarostami, an acclaimed Iranian director, planted Iran firmly on the map of world cinema when he won the <a href="/wiki/Palme_d%27Or" title="Palme d'Or">Palme d'Or</a> for <i><a href="/wiki/Taste_of_Cherry" title="Taste of Cherry">Taste of Cherry</a></i> in 1997.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Dabashi2007_499-0"><a href="#cite_note-Dabashi2007-499">[497]</a></sup> The continuous presence of Iranian films in prestigious international festivals, such as the <a href="/wiki/Cannes_Film_Festival" title="Cannes Film Festival">Cannes Film Festival</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Venice_Film_Festival" title="Venice Film Festival">Venice Film Festival</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Berlin_International_Film_Festival" title="Berlin International Film Festival">Berlin International Film Festival</a>, attracted world attention to Iranian masterpieces.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-DecherneyAtwood2014_500-0"><a href="#cite_note-DecherneyAtwood2014-500">[498]</a></sup> In 2006, six Iranian films, of six different styles, represented Iranian cinema at the Berlin International Film Festival. Critics considered this a remarkable event in the history of Iranian cinema.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-501"><a href="#cite_note-501">[499]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-502"><a href="#cite_note-502">[500]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Asghar_Farhadi" title="Asghar Farhadi">Asghar Farhadi</a>, a well-known Iranian director, has received a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Golden_Globe_Award" title="Golden Globe Award">Golden Globe Award</a> and two <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Academy_Award" title="Academy Award">Academy Awards</a>, representing Iran for Best Foreign Language Film in 2012 and 2017. In 2012, he was named as one of the 100 Most Influential People in the world by the American news magazine <i><a href="/wiki/Time_(magazine)" title="Time (magazine)">Time</a></i>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Observances">Observances</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/List_of_festivals_in_Iran" title="List of festivals in Iran">List of festivals in Iran</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:7SEEN_89.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1077" data-file-width="1199" decoding="async" height="198" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/78/7SEEN_89.jpg/220px-7SEEN_89.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/78/7SEEN_89.jpg/330px-7SEEN_89.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/78/7SEEN_89.jpg/440px-7SEEN_89.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:7SEEN_89.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Haft-Seen" title="Haft-Seen">Haft-Seen</a>, a custom of <a href="/wiki/Nowruz" title="Nowruz">Nowruz</a>, the Iranian New Year</div></div></div>
<p>Iran's official <a href="/wiki/New_Year" title="New Year">New Year</a> begins with <a href="/wiki/Nowruz" title="Nowruz">Nowruz</a>, an ancient Iranian tradition celebrated annually on the <a href="/wiki/Equinox" title="Equinox">vernal equinox</a>. It is enjoyed by people adhering to different religions, but is considered a holiday for the Zoroastrians. It was registered on the <a href="/wiki/UNESCO" title="UNESCO">UNESCO</a>'s list of <a href="/wiki/Masterpieces_of_the_Oral_and_Intangible_Heritage_of_Humanity" title="Masterpieces of the Oral and Intangible Heritage of Humanity">Masterpieces of the Oral and Intangible Heritage of Humanity</a> in 2009,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Unesco.org_November_29_2015c_503-0"><a href="#cite_note-Unesco.org_November_29_2015c-503">[501]</a></sup> described as the <i>Persian New Year</i>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-504"><a href="#cite_note-504">[502]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-505"><a href="#cite_note-505">[503]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-506"><a href="#cite_note-506">[504]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-507"><a href="#cite_note-507">[505]</a></sup> shared with a number of other countries in which it has historically been celebrated.
</p><p>On the eve of the last Wednesday of the preceding year, as a prelude to Nowruz, the ancient festival of <a href="/wiki/Chaharshanbe_Suri" title="Chaharshanbe Suri">ÄÄrÅ¡anbe Suri</a> celebrates <a href="/wiki/Atar" title="Atar">Ätar</a> ("fire") by performing rituals such as jumping over <a href="/wiki/Bonfire" title="Bonfire">bonfires</a> and lighting off <a href="/wiki/Firecracker" title="Firecracker">firecrackers</a> and <a href="/wiki/Fireworks" title="Fireworks">fireworks</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-508"><a href="#cite_note-508">[506]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-509"><a href="#cite_note-509">[507]</a></sup> The Nowruz celebrations last by the end of the 13th day of the Iranian year (<a href="/wiki/Farvardin" title="Farvardin">Farvardin</a> 13, usually coincided with 1<span class="nowrap">Â </span>or 2<span class="nowrap">Â </span>April), celebrating the festival of <a href="/wiki/Sizdah_Be-dar" title="Sizdah Be-dar">Sizdebedar</a>, during which the people traditionally go outdoors to <a href="/wiki/Picnic" title="Picnic">picnic</a>.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (November 2020)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Yald%C4%81_Night" title="YaldÄ Night">YaldÄ</a>, another nationally celebrated ancient tradition,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-510"><a href="#cite_note-510">[508]</a></sup> commemorates the ancient goddess <a href="/wiki/Mithra" title="Mithra">Mithra</a> and marks the longest night of the year on the eve of the <a href="/wiki/Winter_solstice" title="Winter solstice">winter solstice</a> (<span title="Persian-language romanization"><i lang="fa-Latn">Äelle ye zemestÄn</i></span>; usually falling on 20 or 21 December),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-511"><a href="#cite_note-511">[509]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-512"><a href="#cite_note-512">[510]</a></sup> during which families gather together to recite poetry and eat fruitsâparticularly the red fruits watermelon and <a href="/wiki/Pomegranate" title="Pomegranate">pomegranate</a>, as well as <a href="/wiki/Mixed_nuts" title="Mixed nuts">mixed nuts</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-513"><a href="#cite_note-513">[511]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-514"><a href="#cite_note-514">[512]</a></sup> In some regions of the provinces of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mazandaran_Province" title="Mazandaran Province">Mazanderan</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Markazi_Province" title="Markazi Province">Markazi</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-515"><a href="#cite_note-515">[513]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-516"><a href="#cite_note-516">[514]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-517"><a href="#cite_note-517">[515]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-518"><a href="#cite_note-518">[516]</a></sup> there is also the <a href="/wiki/Summer_solstice" title="Summer solstice">midsummer</a> festival of <a href="/wiki/Tirgan" title="Tirgan">TirgÄn</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-519"><a href="#cite_note-519">[517]</a></sup> which is observed on <a href="/wiki/Tir_(month)" title="Tir (month)">Tir</a> 13 (2 or 3<span class="nowrap">Â </span>July) as a celebration of water.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-520"><a href="#cite_note-520">[518]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-521"><a href="#cite_note-521">[519]</a></sup>
</p><p>Alongside the ancient Iranian celebrations, Islamic annual events such as <a href="/wiki/Ramadan" title="Ramadan">RamezÄn</a>, <a href="/wiki/Eid_al-Fitr" title="Eid al-Fitr">Eid e Fetr</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Ashura" title="Ashura">Ruz e ÄÅ¡urÄ</a> are marked by the country's large Muslim population, Christian traditions such as <a href="/wiki/Christmas" title="Christmas">Noel</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-522"><a href="#cite_note-522">[520]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Lent" title="Lent">Äelle ye Ruze</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Easter" title="Easter">Eid e PÄk</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-523"><a href="#cite_note-523">[521]</a></sup> are observed by the Christian communities, Jewish traditions such as <a href="/wiki/Purim" title="Purim">Purim</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-524"><a href="#cite_note-524">[522]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Hanukkah" title="Hanukkah">HanukÄ</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-525"><a href="#cite_note-525">[523]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Passover" title="Passover">Eid e Fatir</a> (Pesah)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-526"><a href="#cite_note-526">[524]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-527"><a href="#cite_note-527">[525]</a></sup> are observed by the Jewish communities, and Zoroastrian traditions such as <a href="/wiki/Sadeh" title="Sadeh">Sade</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-528"><a href="#cite_note-528">[526]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Mehregan" title="Mehregan">MehrgÄn</a> are observed by the Zoroastrians.
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Public_holidays">Public holidays</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Public_holidays_in_Iran" title="Public holidays in Iran">Public holidays in Iran</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Iranian_calendars" title="Iranian calendars">Iranian calendars</a></div>
<p>Iran's <a href="/wiki/Civil_calendar" title="Civil calendar">official calendar</a> is the <a href="/wiki/Solar_Hijri_calendar" title="Solar Hijri calendar">Solar Hejri calendar</a>, beginning at the <a href="/wiki/March_equinox" title="March equinox">vernal equinox</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Northern_Hemisphere" title="Northern Hemisphere">Northern Hemisphere</a>, which was first enacted by the Iranian Parliament on 31 March 1925.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Calenica_529-0"><a href="#cite_note-Calenica-529">[527]</a></sup> Each of the 12 months of the Solar Hejri calendar correspond with a <a href="/wiki/Astrological_sign" title="Astrological sign">zodiac sign</a>, and the length of each year is absolutely solar.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Calenica_529-1"><a href="#cite_note-Calenica-529">[527]</a></sup> The months are named after the ancient Iranian months,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Calenica_529-2"><a href="#cite_note-Calenica-529">[527]</a></sup> namely <a href="/wiki/Farvardin" title="Farvardin">Farvardin</a> (<a href="/wiki/Fravashi" title="Fravashi"><span title="Avestan-language romanization"><i lang="ae-Latn">FravaÅ¡i</i></span></a>), <a href="/wiki/Ordibehesht" title="Ordibehesht">OrdibeheÅ¡t</a> (<a href="/wiki/Asha" title="Asha"><span title="Avestan-language romanization"><i lang="ae-Latn">AÅ¡a VahiÅ¡ta</i></span></a>), <a href="/wiki/Khordad" title="Khordad">XordÄd</a> (<a href="/wiki/Haurvatat" title="Haurvatat"><span title="Avestan-language romanization"><i lang="ae-Latn">HaurvatÄt</i></span></a>), <a href="/wiki/Tir_(month)" title="Tir (month)">Tir</a> (<a href="/wiki/Tishtrya" title="Tishtrya"><span title="Avestan-language romanization"><i lang="ae-Latn">TiÅ¡trya</i></span></a>), <a href="/wiki/Mordad" title="Mordad">AmordÄd</a> (<a href="/wiki/Ameretat" title="Ameretat"><span title="Avestan-language romanization"><i lang="ae-Latn">AmÉrÉtÄt</i></span></a>), <a href="/wiki/Shahrivar" title="Shahrivar">Å ahrivar</a> (<a href="/wiki/Kshatra_Vairya" title="Kshatra Vairya"><span title="Avestan-language romanization"><i lang="ae-Latn">XÅ¡aÎ¸ra Vairya</i></span></a>), <a href="/wiki/Mehr_(month)" title="Mehr (month)">Mehr</a> (<a href="/wiki/Mithra" title="Mithra"><span title="Avestan-language romanization"><i lang="ae-Latn">MiÎ¸ra</i></span></a>), <a href="/wiki/Aban_(month)" title="Aban (month)">ÄbÄn</a> (<a href="/wiki/Aban" title="Aban"><span title="Avestan-language romanization"><i lang="ae-Latn">ÄpÅ</i></span></a>), <a href="/wiki/Azar" title="Azar">Äzar</a> (<a href="/wiki/Atar" title="Atar"><span title="Avestan-language romanization"><i lang="ae-Latn">Ätar</i></span></a>), <a href="/wiki/Dey_(month)" title="Dey (month)">Dey</a> (<a href="/wiki/Ahura_Mazda" title="Ahura Mazda"><span title="Avestan-language romanization"><i lang="ae-Latn">DaÎ¸uÅ¡</i></span></a>), <a href="/wiki/Bahman" title="Bahman">Bahman</a> (<a href="/wiki/Vohu_Manah" title="Vohu Manah"><span title="Avestan-language romanization"><i lang="ae-Latn">Vohu Manah</i></span></a>), and <a href="/wiki/Esfand" title="Esfand">Esfand</a> (<a href="/wiki/Spenta_Armaiti" title="Spenta Armaiti"><span title="Avestan-language romanization"><i lang="ae-Latn">SpÉntÄ Ärmaiti</i></span></a>).
</p><p>Alternatively, the <a href="/wiki/Islamic_calendar" title="Islamic calendar">Lunar Hejri calendar</a> is used to indicate Islamic events, and the <a href="/wiki/Gregorian_calendar" title="Gregorian calendar">Gregorian calendar</a> remarks the international events.
</p><p>Legal public holidays based on the Iranian solar calendar include the cultural celebrations of Nowruz (<a href="/wiki/Farvardin" title="Farvardin">Farvardin</a> 1â4; 21â24 March) and Sizdebedar (<a href="/wiki/Farvardin" title="Farvardin">Farvardin</a> 13; 2<span class="nowrap">Â </span>April), and the political events of <a href="/wiki/Iranian_Islamic_Republic_Day" title="Iranian Islamic Republic Day">Islamic Republic Day</a> (<a href="/wiki/Farvardin" title="Farvardin">Farvardin</a> 12; 1<span class="nowrap">Â </span>April), the death of <a href="/wiki/Ruhollah_Khomeini" title="Ruhollah Khomeini">Ruhollah Khomeini</a> (<a href="/wiki/Khordad" title="Khordad">Khordad</a> 14; 4<span class="nowrap">Â </span>June), the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/5_June_1963,_demonstrations_in_Iran" title="5 June 1963, demonstrations in Iran">Khordad 15 event</a> (<a href="/wiki/Khordad" title="Khordad">Khordad</a> 15; 5<span class="nowrap">Â </span>June), the anniversary of the <a href="/wiki/Iranian_Revolution" title="Iranian Revolution">1979 Revolution</a> (<a href="/wiki/Bahman" title="Bahman">Bahman</a> 22; 10 February), and <a href="/wiki/Nationalization_of_the_Iranian_oil_industry" title="Nationalization of the Iranian oil industry">Oil Nationalization Day</a> (<a href="/wiki/Esfand" title="Esfand">Esfand</a> 29; 19 March).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-irmys_530-0"><a href="#cite_note-irmys-530">[528]</a></sup>
</p><p>Lunar Islamic public holidays include Tasua (<a href="/wiki/Islamic_calendar" title="Islamic calendar">Muharram</a> 9), Ashura (<a href="/wiki/Islamic_calendar" title="Islamic calendar">Muharram</a> 10), Arba'een (<a href="/wiki/Islamic_calendar" title="Islamic calendar">Safar</a> 20), the death of Muhammad (<a href="/wiki/Islamic_calendar" title="Islamic calendar">Safar</a> 28), the death of Ali al-Ridha (<a href="/wiki/Islamic_calendar" title="Islamic calendar">Safar</a> 29 or 30), the birthday of Muhammad (<a href="/wiki/Islamic_calendar" title="Islamic calendar">Rabi-al-Awwal</a> 17), the death of Fatimah (<a href="/wiki/Islamic_calendar" title="Islamic calendar">Jumada-al-Thani</a> 3), the birthday of Ali (<a href="/wiki/Islamic_calendar" title="Islamic calendar">Rajab</a> 13), Muhammad's first revelation (<a href="/wiki/Islamic_calendar" title="Islamic calendar">Rajab</a> 27), the birthday of Muhammad al-Mahdi (<a href="/wiki/Islamic_calendar" title="Islamic calendar">Sha'ban</a> 15), the death of Ali (<a href="/wiki/Islamic_calendar" title="Islamic calendar">Ramadan</a> 21), Eid al-Fitr (<a href="/wiki/Islamic_calendar" title="Islamic calendar">Shawwal</a> 1â2), the death of Ja'far al-Sadiq (<a href="/wiki/Islamic_calendar" title="Islamic calendar">Shawwal</a> 25), Eid al-Qurban (<a href="/wiki/Islamic_calendar" title="Islamic calendar">Zulhijja</a> 10), and Eid al-Qadir (<a href="/wiki/Islamic_calendar" title="Islamic calendar">Zulhijja</a> 18).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-irmys_530-1"><a href="#cite_note-irmys-530">[528]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cuisine">Cuisine</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Iranian_cuisine" title="Iranian cuisine">Iranian cuisine</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Kebab_Bakhtyari.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1536" data-file-width="2048" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b3/Kebab_Bakhtyari.jpg/220px-Kebab_Bakhtyari.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b3/Kebab_Bakhtyari.jpg/330px-Kebab_Bakhtyari.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b3/Kebab_Bakhtyari.jpg/440px-Kebab_Bakhtyari.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Kebab_Bakhtyari.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Chelow_kabab" title="Chelow kabab">Chelow kabab</a> (rice and <a href="/wiki/Kebab" title="Kebab">kebab</a>), one of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Iran%27s_national_dishes" title="Iran's national dishes">Iran's national dishes</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-531"><a href="#cite_note-531">[529]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-532"><a href="#cite_note-532">[530]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-533"><a href="#cite_note-533">[531]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>Due to its variety of ethnic groups and the influences from the neighboring cultures, the cuisine of Iran is diverse. Herbs, along with fruits such as plums, pomegranate, quince, prunes, apricots, and raisins, are frequently used. To achieve a balanced taste, characteristic flavorings such as <a href="/wiki/Saffron" title="Saffron">saffron</a>, dried lime, cinnamon, and parsley are mixed delicately and used in some special dishes. Onion and garlic are commonly used in the preparation of the accompanying course, but are also served separately during meals, either in raw or pickled form.
</p><p>Iranian cuisine includes a wide range of main dishes, including various types of <a href="/wiki/Kebab" title="Kebab">kebab</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pilaf" title="Pilaf">pilaf</a>, <a href="/wiki/Stew" title="Stew">stew</a> (<a href="/wiki/Khoresh" title="Khoresh">khoresh</a>), <a href="/wiki/Soup" title="Soup">soup</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/%C4%80sh" title="Äsh">Äsh</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Omelette" title="Omelette">omelette</a>. Lunch and dinner meals are commonly accompanied by side dishes such as plain <a href="/wiki/Yogurt" title="Yogurt">yogurt</a> or <a href="/wiki/Tzatziki" title="Tzatziki">mast-o-khiar</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sabzi_khordan" title="Sabzi khordan">sabzi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Shirazi_salad" title="Shirazi salad">salad Shirazi</a>, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tursu" title="Tursu">torshi</a>, and might follow dishes such as <a href="/wiki/Borani" title="Borani">borani</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mirza_Ghassemi" title="Mirza Ghassemi">Mirza Qasemi</a>, or <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kashk_e_bademjan" title="Kashk e bademjan">kashk e bademjan</a> as the appetizer.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Tea_and_Tray_-_Bazaar_of_Omar_Khayyam_-_Night_-_Nishapur_2.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3072" data-file-width="2304" decoding="async" height="227" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/Tea_and_Tray_-_Bazaar_of_Omar_Khayyam_-_Night_-_Nishapur_2.JPG/170px-Tea_and_Tray_-_Bazaar_of_Omar_Khayyam_-_Night_-_Nishapur_2.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/Tea_and_Tray_-_Bazaar_of_Omar_Khayyam_-_Night_-_Nishapur_2.JPG/255px-Tea_and_Tray_-_Bazaar_of_Omar_Khayyam_-_Night_-_Nishapur_2.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/Tea_and_Tray_-_Bazaar_of_Omar_Khayyam_-_Night_-_Nishapur_2.JPG/340px-Tea_and_Tray_-_Bazaar_of_Omar_Khayyam_-_Night_-_Nishapur_2.JPG 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Tea_and_Tray_-_Bazaar_of_Omar_Khayyam_-_Night_-_Nishapur_2.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div>An Iranian tea (<span title="Persian-language romanization"><i lang="fa-Latn">ÄÄy</i></span>) tray served near Garden of <a href="/wiki/Mausoleum_of_Omar_Khayy%C3%A1m" title="Mausoleum of Omar KhayyÃ¡m">Mausoleum</a> of <a href="/wiki/Omar_Khayyam" title="Omar Khayyam">Omar Khayyam</a> in <a href="/wiki/Nishapur" title="Nishapur">Nishapur</a></div></div></div>
<p>In Iranian culture, tea (<span title="Persian-language romanization"><i lang="fa-Latn">ÄÄy</i></span>) is widely consumed.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-534"><a href="#cite_note-534">[532]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-535"><a href="#cite_note-535">[533]</a></sup> Iran is the world's seventh major tea producer,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FAOSTAT_536-0"><a href="#cite_note-FAOSTAT-536">[534]</a></sup> and a cup of tea is typically the first thing offered to a guest.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-537"><a href="#cite_note-537">[535]</a></sup> One of Iran's most popular desserts is the <a href="/wiki/Faloodeh" title="Faloodeh">falude</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-538"><a href="#cite_note-538">[536]</a></sup> consisting of <a href="/wiki/Vermicelli" title="Vermicelli">vermicelli</a> in a <a href="/wiki/Rose_water" title="Rose water">rose water</a> syrup, which has its roots in the fourth century BC.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-539"><a href="#cite_note-539">[537]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-540"><a href="#cite_note-540">[538]</a></sup> There is also the popular saffron ice cream, known as <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bastani_Sonnati" title="Bastani Sonnati">bastani sonnati</a></i> ("traditional ice cream"),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-541"><a href="#cite_note-541">[539]</a></sup> which is sometimes accompanied with <a href="/wiki/Carrot_juice" title="Carrot juice">carrot juice</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-542"><a href="#cite_note-542">[540]</a></sup> Iran is also famous for its <a href="/wiki/Caviar" title="Caviar">caviar</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-543"><a href="#cite_note-543">[541]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Sports">Sports</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Sport_in_Iran" title="Sport in Iran">Sport in Iran</a></div>
<p>Iran is most likely the birthplace of <a href="/wiki/Polo" title="Polo">polo</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-544"><a href="#cite_note-544">[542]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-545"><a href="#cite_note-545">[543]</a></sup> locally known as <i>ÄowgÄn</i>, with its earliest records attributed to the ancient <a href="/wiki/Medes" title="Medes">Medes</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-546"><a href="#cite_note-546">[544]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Freestyle_wrestling" title="Freestyle wrestling">Freestyle wrestling</a> is traditionally considered the <a href="/wiki/National_sport" title="National sport">national sport</a> of Iran, and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Iran_national_freestyle_wrestling_athletes" title="Iran national freestyle wrestling athletes">national wrestlers</a> have been world champions on many occasions. Iran's traditional wrestling, called <i><a href="/wiki/Pahlevani_and_zoorkhaneh_rituals" title="Pahlevani and zoorkhaneh rituals">koÅ¡ti e pahlevÄni</a></i> ("heroic wrestling"), is registered on <a href="/wiki/UNESCO" title="UNESCO">UNESCO</a>'s <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Intangible_Cultural_Heritage" title="Intangible Cultural Heritage">Intangible Cultural Heritage</a> list.
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Dizin_ski_resort.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="472" data-file-width="789" decoding="async" height="132" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b5/Dizin_ski_resort.jpg/220px-Dizin_ski_resort.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b5/Dizin_ski_resort.jpg/330px-Dizin_ski_resort.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b5/Dizin_ski_resort.jpg/440px-Dizin_ski_resort.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Dizin_ski_resort.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Skiers at the <a href="/wiki/Dizin" title="Dizin">Dizin Ski Resort</a></div></div></div>
<p>Being a mountainous country, Iran is a venue for <a href="/wiki/Skiing" title="Skiing">skiing</a>, <a href="/wiki/Snowboarding" title="Snowboarding">snowboarding</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hiking" title="Hiking">hiking</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rock_climbing" title="Rock climbing">rock climbing</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-547"><a href="#cite_note-547">[545]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Mountaineering" title="Mountaineering">mountain climbing</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-548"><a href="#cite_note-548">[546]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-549"><a href="#cite_note-549">[547]</a></sup> It is home to several ski resorts, the most famous being <a href="/wiki/Tochal_Complex" title="Tochal Complex">Tochal</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dizin" title="Dizin">Dizin</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Shemshak_(ski_resort)" title="Shemshak (ski resort)">Shemshak</a>, all within one to three hours traveling from the capital city Tehran.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Snowseasoncentral.com_November_29_2015c_550-0"><a href="#cite_note-Snowseasoncentral.com_November_29_2015c-550">[548]</a></sup> The resort of Tochal, located in the <a href="/wiki/Alborz" title="Alborz">Alborz</a> mountain rage, is the world's fifth-highest ski resort (3,730Â m or 12,238Â ft at its highest station).
</p><p>Iran's <a href="/wiki/National_Olympic_Committee_of_the_Islamic_Republic_of_Iran" title="National Olympic Committee of the Islamic Republic of Iran">National Olympic Committee</a> was founded in 1947. Wrestlers and <a href="/wiki/Olympic_weightlifting" title="Olympic weightlifting">weightlifters</a> have achieved the country's highest <a href="/wiki/Iran_at_the_Olympics" title="Iran at the Olympics">records at the Olympics</a>. In September 1974, Iran became the first country in West Asia to host the <a href="/wiki/Asian_Games" title="Asian Games">Asian Games</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Azadi_Sport_Complex" title="Azadi Sport Complex">Azadi Sport Complex</a>, the largest sports complex in Iran, was originally built for this occasion.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:AzadivsNaftMIS2022.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="720" data-file-width="1195" decoding="async" height="133" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4b/AzadivsNaftMIS2022.jpg/220px-AzadivsNaftMIS2022.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4b/AzadivsNaftMIS2022.jpg/330px-AzadivsNaftMIS2022.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4b/AzadivsNaftMIS2022.jpg/440px-AzadivsNaftMIS2022.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:AzadivsNaftMIS2022.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Azadi_Stadium" title="Azadi Stadium">Azadi Stadium</a> in <a href="/wiki/Tehran" title="Tehran">Tehran</a> is <a href="/wiki/List_of_association_football_stadiums_by_capacity" title="List of association football stadiums by capacity">West Asia's largest football stadium</a>.</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Football_in_Iran" title="Football in Iran">Football</a> has been regarded as the most popular sport in Iran, with the <a href="/wiki/Iran_national_football_team" title="Iran national football team">men's national team</a> having won the <a href="/wiki/AFC_Asian_Cup" title="AFC Asian Cup">Asian Cup</a> on three occasions. The men's national team has maintained its position as Asia's best team, ranking first in Asia and 22nd in the world according to the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/FIFA_World_Rankings" title="FIFA World Rankings">FIFA World Rankings</a> (as of September 2021<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Iran&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-551"><a href="#cite_note-551">[549]</a></sup>
</p><p>Volleyball is the second most popular sport in Iran.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-552"><a href="#cite_note-552">[550]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-553"><a href="#cite_note-553">[551]</a></sup> Having won the 2011 and 2013 <a href="/wiki/Asian_Men%27s_Volleyball_Championship" title="Asian Men's Volleyball Championship">Asian Men's Volleyball Championships</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Iran_men%27s_national_volleyball_team" title="Iran men's national volleyball team">men's national team</a> is currently the strongest team in Asia, and ranks eighth in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/FIVB_World_Rankings" title="FIVB World Rankings">FIVB World Rankings</a> (as of JulyÂ 2017<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Iran&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>).
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Basketball" title="Basketball">Basketball</a> is also popular,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-554"><a href="#cite_note-554">[552]</a></sup> with the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Iran_national_basketball_team" title="Iran national basketball team">men's national team</a> having won three <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/FIBA_Asia_Championship" title="FIBA Asia Championship">Asian Championships</a> since 2007.
</p><p>In 2016, Iran made global headlines for international female champions boycotting tournaments in Iran in chess (U.S. Woman Grandmaster <a href="/wiki/Naz%C3%AD_Paikidze" title="NazÃ­ Paikidze">NazÃ­ Paikidze</a>)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-555"><a href="#cite_note-555">[553]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-556"><a href="#cite_note-556">[554]</a></sup> and in shooting (Indian world champion <a href="/wiki/Heena_Sidhu" title="Heena Sidhu">Heena Sidhu</a>),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-557"><a href="#cite_note-557">[555]</a></sup> as they refused to enter a country where they would be forced to wear a <a href="/wiki/Hijab" title="Hijab">hijab</a>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Media">Media</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Media_of_Iran" title="Media of Iran">Media of Iran</a></div>
<p>According to the <a href="/wiki/Press_Freedom_Index" title="Press Freedom Index">Press Freedom Index</a>, Iran holds one of the lowest positions, ranking 174th out of 180 countries as of 2021.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-558"><a href="#cite_note-558">[556]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-559"><a href="#cite_note-559">[557]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Culture_and_Islamic_Guidance" title="Ministry of Culture and Islamic Guidance">Ministry of Culture and Islamic Guidance</a> is Iran's main government department responsible for the <a href="/wiki/Cultural_policy" title="Cultural policy">cultural policy</a>, including activities regarding communications and information.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-560"><a href="#cite_note-560">[558]</a></sup>
</p><p>Iran's first newspapers were published during the reign of <a href="/wiki/Naser_al-Din_Shah_Qajar" title="Naser al-Din Shah Qajar">Naser al-Din Shah</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Qajar_dynasty" title="Qajar dynasty">Qajar dynasty</a> in the mid-19th century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-561"><a href="#cite_note-561">[559]</a></sup> Most of the <a href="/wiki/List_of_newspapers_in_Iran" title="List of newspapers in Iran">newspapers published in Iran</a> are in Persian, the country's official language. The country's most widely circulated periodicals are based in Tehran, among which are <i><a href="/wiki/Etemad" title="Etemad">Etemad</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Ettela%27at" title="Ettela'at">Ettela'at</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Kayhan" title="Kayhan">Kayhan</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Hamshahri" title="Hamshahri">Hamshahri</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Resalat_(newspaper)" title="Resalat (newspaper)">Resalat</a></i>, and <i><a href="/wiki/Shargh" title="Shargh">Shargh</a></i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BYI_350-1"><a href="#cite_note-BYI-350">[348]</a></sup> <i><a href="/wiki/Tehran_Times" title="Tehran Times">Tehran Times</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Iran_(newspaper)" title="Iran (newspaper)">Iran Daily</a></i>, and <i><a href="/wiki/Financial_Tribune" title="Financial Tribune">Financial Tribune</a></i> are among English-language newspapers based in Iran.
</p><p>Television was introduced in Iran in 1958.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FisherAvery1991p810_562-0"><a href="#cite_note-FisherAvery1991p810-562">[560]</a></sup> Although the <a href="/wiki/1974_Asian_Games" title="1974 Asian Games">1974 Asian Games</a> were broadcast in color, full color programming began in 1978.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FisherAvery1991p810_562-1"><a href="#cite_note-FisherAvery1991p810-562">[560]</a></sup> Since the 1979 Revolution, Iran's largest media corporation is the <a href="/wiki/Islamic_Republic_of_Iran_Broadcasting" title="Islamic Republic of Iran Broadcasting">Islamic Republic of Iran Broadcasting</a> (IRIB).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BYI_350-2"><a href="#cite_note-BYI-350">[348]</a></sup> Despite the restrictions on non-domestic television, about 65% of the residents of the capital city and about 30 to 40% of the residents outside the capital city access worldwide television channels through <a href="/wiki/Satellite_dish" title="Satellite dish">satellite dishes</a>, although observers state that the figures are likely to be higher.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-563"><a href="#cite_note-563">[561]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-564"><a href="#cite_note-564">[562]</a></sup>
</p><p>Iran received access to the Internet in 1993. According to Internet World Stats, as of 2017<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Iran&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, around 69.1% of the population of Iran are Internet users.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-IWStats_565-0"><a href="#cite_note-IWStats-565">[563]</a></sup> Iran ranks 17th among <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_number_of_Internet_users" title="List of countries by number of Internet users">countries by number of Internet users</a>. According to the statistics provided by the web information company of <a href="/wiki/Alexa_Internet" title="Alexa Internet">Alexa</a>, <a href="/wiki/Google_Search" title="Google Search">Google Search</a> is Iran's most widely used search engine and <a href="/wiki/Instagram" title="Instagram">Instagram</a> is the most popular online <a href="/wiki/Social_networking_service" title="Social networking service">social networking service</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Alexa_Internet_566-0"><a href="#cite_note-Alexa_Internet-566">[564]</a></sup> Direct access to many worldwide mainstream websites has been blocked in Iran, including <a href="/wiki/Facebook" title="Facebook">Facebook</a>, which has been blocked since 2009 due to the organization of anti-governmental protests on the website.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-567"><a href="#cite_note-567">[565]</a></sup> However, as of 2017<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Iran&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, Facebook has around 40 million subscribers based in Iran (48.8% of the population) who use <a href="/wiki/Virtual_private_network" title="Virtual private network">virtual private networks</a> and <a href="/wiki/Proxy_server" title="Proxy server">proxy servers</a> to access the website.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-IWStats_565-1"><a href="#cite_note-IWStats-565">[563]</a></sup> Some of the officials themselves have verified accounts on the social networking websites that are blocked by the authorities, including Facebook and <a href="/wiki/Twitter" title="Twitter">Twitter</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-568"><a href="#cite_note-568">[566]</a></sup> About 90% of Iran's <a href="/wiki/E-commerce" title="E-commerce">e-commerce</a> takes place on the Iranian online store of Digikala, which has around 750,000 visitors per day and more than 2.3 million subscribers and is the most visited online store in the Middle East.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-569"><a href="#cite_note-569">[567]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Alexa_Internet_566-1"><a href="#cite_note-Alexa_Internet-566">[564]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Fashion_and_clothing">Fashion and clothing</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Fashion_in_Iran" title="Fashion in Iran">Fashion in Iran</a></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Fashion_in_Iran" title="Fashion in Iran">Fashion in Iran</a> is divided into several historical periods. The exact date of the emergence of <a href="/wiki/Weaving" title="Weaving">weaving</a> in Iran is not yet known, but it is likely to coincide with the emergence of <a href="/wiki/Civilization" title="Civilization">civilization</a>. Clothing in Iran is mentioned in <a href="/wiki/Persian_mythology" title="Persian mythology">Persian mythology</a>. <a href="/wiki/Ferdowsi" title="Ferdowsi">Ferdowsi</a> and many historians have considered <a href="/wiki/Keyumars" title="Keyumars">Keyumars</a> to be the inventor of the use of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Animal_skin" title="Animal skin">animals' skin</a> and hair as clothing. Some historians have also mentioned <a href="/wiki/Hushang" title="Hushang">Hushang</a> as the first inventor of the use of living skins as clothing.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:02_570-0"><a href="#cite_note-:02-570">[568]</a></sup> Ferdowsi considers <a href="/wiki/Tahmuras" title="Tahmuras">Tahmuras</a> to be a kind of <a href="/wiki/Textile" title="Textile">textile</a> initiator in Iran. There are historical discoveries in northern Iran from about 6,000 BC that refer to <a href="/wiki/Wool" title="Wool">wool</a> weaving at the time. Other discoveries in central Iran dating back to 4200 BC have shown that the animals' skin has not been the only clothing worn on the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Iranian_Plateau" title="Iranian Plateau">Iranian Plateau</a> since those years. The clothing of ancient Iran took an advanced form, and the fabric and color of clothing became very important at that time. Depending on the social status, eminence, climate of the region and the season, <a href="/wiki/Persian_clothing" title="Persian clothing">Persian clothing</a> during the Achaemenian period took various forms. The philosophy used in this clothing, in addition to being functional, also had an aesthetic role.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:02_570-1"><a href="#cite_note-:02-570">[568]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Beauty_pageant" title="Beauty pageant">Beauty pageant</a> festivals inside Iran were not held after the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/1979_revolution" title="1979 revolution">1979 revolution</a>, and the last selection ceremony of the "beauty queen of Iran" was held in 1978 in this country. Since then, many Iranian girls have participated in the Beauty pageant and Miss Universe outside of Iran. <a href="/wiki/Sahar_Biniaz" title="Sahar Biniaz">Sahar Biniaz</a> (<a href="/wiki/Miss_Universe_Canada_2012" title="Miss Universe Canada 2012">Miss Universe Canada 2012</a>) and <a href="/wiki/Shermine_Shahrivar" title="Shermine Shahrivar">Shermineh Shahrivar</a> (<a href="/wiki/Miss_Germany" title="Miss Germany">Miss Germany</a> and <a href="/wiki/Miss_Europe" title="Miss Europe">Miss Europe</a>) are examples of Iranian models outside Iran.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-571"><a href="#cite_note-571">[569]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-572"><a href="#cite_note-572">[570]</a></sup> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Girls_of_Enghelab_Street" title="Girls of Enghelab Street">Girls of Enghelab Street</a> was a series of protests in 2017â2019 against a <a href="/wiki/Hijab_by_country#Iran" title="Hijab by country">compulsory hijab</a> in Iran.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-573"><a href="#cite_note-573">[571]</a></sup>
</p>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Explanatory_notes">Explanatory notes</span></h2>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1011085734">.mw-parser-output .reflist{font-size:90%;margin-bottom:0.5em;list-style-type:decimal}.mw-parser-output .reflist .references{font-size:100%;margin-bottom:0;list-style-type:inherit}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns-2{column-width:30em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns-3{column-width:25em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns{margin-top:0.3em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns ol{margin-top:0}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns li{page-break-inside:avoid;break-inside:avoid-column}.mw-parser-output .reflist-upper-alpha{list-style-type:upper-alpha}.mw-parser-output .reflist-upper-roman{list-style-type:upper-roman}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-alpha{list-style-type:lower-alpha}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-greek{list-style-type:lower-greek}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-roman{list-style-type:lower-roman}</style><div class="reflist reflist-lower-alpha">
<div class="mw-references-wrap"><ol class="references">
<li id="cite_note-13"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-13">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="/wiki/Persian_language" title="Persian language">Persian</a>: <span dir="rtl" lang="fa">Ø¬ÙÙÙØ±Û Ø§Ø³ÙØ§ÙÛ Ø§ÛØ±Ø§Ù</span> <span title="Persian-language romanization"><i lang="fa-Latn">Jomhuri-ye EslÄmi-ye IrÄn</i></span> <span style="font-size:85%;">(<span class="unicode haudio"><span class="fn"><span style="white-space:nowrap;margin-right:.25em;"><a href="/wiki/File:Fa-ir-JEI_(1).ogg" title="About this sound"><img alt="" data-file-height="20" data-file-width="20" decoding="async" height="11" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/11px-Loudspeaker.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/17px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/22px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 2x" width="11"/></a></span><a class="internal" href="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/4/4b/Fa-ir-JEI_%281%29.ogg" title="Fa-ir-JEI (1).ogg">listen</a></span></span>)</span> <small></small><span class="IPA" lang="fa-Latn-fonipa" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/Persian" title="Help:IPA/Persian">[dÊomhuËËÉ¾ije eslÉËËmije ÊiËËÉ¾Én]</a></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-44"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-44">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">In the Avesta, the <i>airiia-</i> are members of the ethnic group of the Avesta-reciters themselves, in contradistinction to the <i>anairiia-</i> (the "<a href="/wiki/Aneran" title="Aneran">non-Arya</a>"). The word also appears four times in Old Persian: One is in the <a href="/wiki/Behistun_Inscription" title="Behistun Inscription">Behistun Inscription</a>, where <i>ariya-</i> is the name of a language (DB 4.89). The other three instances occur in <a href="/wiki/Darius_the_Great" title="Darius the Great">Darius the Great</a>'s inscription at <a href="/wiki/Naqsh-e_Rostam" title="Naqsh-e Rostam">Naqsh-e Rostam</a> (DNa 14â15), in Darius I's inscription at Susa (DSe 13â14), and in the inscription of <a href="/wiki/Xerxes_I" title="Xerxes I">Xerxes I</a> at <a href="/wiki/Persepolis" title="Persepolis">Persepolis</a> (XPh 12â13). In these, the two Achaemenid dynasties describe themselves as <i>pÄrsa pÄrsahyÄ puÃ§a ariya ariyaciÃ§a</i> "a Persian, son of a Persian, an Ariya, of Ariya origin."âThe phrase with <i>ciÃ§a</i> ("origin, descendance") assures that <i>ariya</i> is an ethnic name wider in meaning than <i>pÄrsa</i> and not a simple adjectival epithet.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bailey_Arya_43-1"><a href="#cite_note-Bailey_Arya-43">[42]</a></sup></span>
</li>
</ol></div></div>

<li id="cite_note-CIA-3"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-CIA_3-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-CIA_3-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-CIA_3-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-CIA_3-3"><sup><i><b>d</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-CIA_3-4"><sup><i><b>e</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-CIA_3-5"><sup><i><b>f</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-CIA_3-6"><sup><i><b>g</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-CIA_3-7"><sup><i><b>h</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://www.cia.gov/the-world-factbook/countries/iran/" rel="nofollow">"Iran"</a>. <i>The World Factbook</i>. <li id="cite_note-Sarkhosh-4"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Sarkhosh_4-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Sarkhosh_4-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation cs2" id="CITEREFSarkhosh_Curtis,_VestaStewart,_Sarah2005">Sarkhosh Curtis, Vesta; Stewart, Sarah (2005), <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=a0IF9IdkdYEC" rel="nofollow"><i>Birth of the Persian Empire: The Idea of Iran</i></a>, London: I.B. Tauris, p.Â 108, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>Â <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-84511-062-8" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-84511-062-8"><bdi>978-1-84511-062-8</bdi></a>, <q>Similarly the collapse of Sassanian Eranshahr in AD 650 did not end Iranians' national idea. The name 'Iran' disappeared from official records of the Saffarids, Samanids, Buyids, Saljuqs and their successor. But one unofficially used the name Iran, Eranshahr, and similar national designations, particularly Mamalek-e Iran or 'Iranian lands', which exactly translated the old Avestan term Ariyanam Daihunam. On the other hand, when the Safavids (not Reza Shah, as is popularly assumed) revived a national state officially known as Iran, bureaucratic usage in the Ottoman empire and even Iran itself could still refer to it by other descriptive and traditional appellations.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Birth+of+the+Persian+Empire%3A+The+Idea+of+Iran&amp;rft.place=London&amp;rft.pages=108&amp;rft.pub=I.B.+Tauris&amp;rft.date=2005&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-84511-062-8&amp;rft.au=Sarkhosh+Curtis%2C+Vesta&amp;rft.au=Stewart%2C+Sarah&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3Da0IF9IdkdYEC&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIran"></span></span>
</li>

<li id="cite_note-MW-12"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-MW_12-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-MW_12-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/Iran" rel="nofollow">"Definition of IRAN"</a>. <i>www.merriam-webster.com</i><span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite_note-Fishman-14"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Fishman_14-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Fishman_14-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFA._Fishman2010">A. Fishman, Joshua (2010). <i>Handbook of Language and Ethnic Identity: Disciplinary and Regional Perspectives (Volume 1)</i>. <a href="/wiki/Oxford_University_Press" title="Oxford University Press">Oxford University Press</a>. p.Â 266. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>Â <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-19-537492-6" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-19-537492-6"><bdi>978-0-19-537492-6</bdi></a>. <q>" "Iran" and "Persia" are synonymous" The former has always been used by the Iranian speaking peoples themselves, while the latter has served as the international name of the country in various languages</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Handbook+of+Language+and+Ethnic+Identity%3A+Disciplinary+and+Regional+Perspectives+%28Volume+1%29&amp;rft.pages=266&amp;rft.pub=Oxford+University+Press&amp;rft.date=2010&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-19-537492-6&amp;rft.aulast=A.+Fishman&amp;rft.aufirst=Joshua&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIran"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Lewis1984-15"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Lewis1984_15-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFLewis1984">Lewis, Geoffrey (1984). <li id="cite_note-Schmitt_Aryans1-41"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Schmitt_Aryans1_41-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Schmitt_Aryans1_41-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation cs2" id="CITEREFSchmitt1987">Schmitt, RÃ¼diger (1987), <a class="external text" href="http://www.iranicaonline.org/articles/aryans" rel="nofollow">"Aryans"</a>, <i>Encyclopedia Iranica</i>, vol. 2, New York: Routledge &amp; Kegan Paul, pp.Â 684â687</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=bookitem&amp;rft.atitle=Aryans&amp;rft.btitle=Encyclopedia+Iranica&amp;rft.place=New+York&amp;rft.series=vol.+2&amp;rft.pages=684-687&amp;rft.pub=Routledge+%26+Kegan+Paul&amp;rft.date=1987&amp;rft.aulast=Schmitt&amp;rft.aufirst=R%C3%BCdiger&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.iranicaonline.org%2Farticles%2Faryans&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIran"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-42"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-42">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Laroche. 1957. Proto-Iranian <i>*arya-</i> descends from Proto-Indo-European (PIE) <i><span class="Unicode" style="white-space:nowrap;" title="Proto-Indo-European language"><span lang="ine">*ar-yo-</span></span></i>, a <i>yo-</i>adjective to a root <span class="Unicode" style="white-space:nowrap;" title="Proto-Indo-European language"><span lang="ine">*ar</span></span> "to assemble skillfully", present in Greek <i>harma</i> "chariot", Greek <i>aristos</i>, (as in "<a href="/wiki/Aristocracy" title="Aristocracy">aristocracy</a>"), Latin <i>ars</i> "art", etc.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Bailey_Arya-43"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Bailey_Arya_43-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Bailey_Arya_43-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation encyclopaedia cs1" id="CITEREFBailey1987"><a href="/wiki/Harold_Walter_Bailey" title="Harold Walter Bailey">Bailey, Harold Walter</a> (1987). <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20160303194904/http://www.iranicaonline.org/articles/arya-an-ethnic-epithet" rel="nofollow">"Arya"</a>. <i>Encyclopedia Iranica</i>. Vol.Â 2. New York: Routledge &amp; Kegan Paul. pp.Â 681â683. Archived from <a class="external text" href="http://www.iranicaonline.org/articles/arya-an-ethnic-epithet" rel="nofollow">the original</a> on 3 March 2016.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=bookitem&amp;rft.atitle=Arya&amp;rft.btitle=Encyclopedia+Iranica&amp;rft.place=New+York&amp;rft.pages=681-683&amp;rft.pub=Routledge+%26+Kegan+Paul&amp;rft.date=1987&amp;rft.aulast=Bailey&amp;rft.aufirst=Harold+Walter&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.iranicaonline.org%2Farticles%2Farya-an-ethnic-epithet&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIran"></span></span>

<li id="cite_note-49"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-49">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation news cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://www.nytimes.com/1935/01/01/archives/persia-changes-its-name-to-be-iran-from-mar-22.html" rel="nofollow">"Persia Changes Its Name; To Be 'Iran' From Mar. 22"</a>. <i><a href="/wiki/The_New_York_Times" title="The New York Times">The New York Times</a></i>. 1 January 1935<span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite_note-52"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-52">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation audio-visual cs1"><a href="/wiki/Richard_N._Frye" title="Richard N. <li id="cite_note-53"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-53">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFChristoph_Marcinkowski2010">Christoph Marcinkowski (2010). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=F9khRsDDuX8C&amp;pg=PA83" rel="nofollow"><i>Shi'ite Identities: Community and Culture in Changing Social Contexts</i></a>. <li id="cite_note-54"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-54">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFFrye1962">Frye, Richard Nelson (October 1962). "Reitzenstein and QumrÃ¢n Revisited by an Iranian". <i>The Harvard Theological Review</i>. <b>55</b> (4): 261â268. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" title="Doi (identifier)">doi</a>:<a class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.1017%2FS0017816000007926" rel="nofollow">10.1017/S0017816000007926</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/JSTOR_(identifier)" title="JSTOR (identifier)">JSTOR</a>Â <a class="external text" href="//www.jstor.org/stable/1508723" rel="nofollow">1508723</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/S2CID_(identifier)" title="S2CID (identifier)">S2CID</a>Â <a class="external text" href="https://api.semanticscholar.org/CorpusID:162213219" rel="nofollow">162213219</a>. <q>I use the term Iran in an historical context [...] Persia would be used for the modern state, more or less equivalent to "western Iran". I use the term "Greater Iran" to mean what I suspect most Classicists and ancient historians really mean by their use of Persia â that which was within the political boundaries of States ruled by Iranians.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=The+Harvard+Theological+Review&amp;rft.atitle=Reitzenstein+and+Qumr%C3%A2n+Revisited+by+an+Iranian&amp;rft.volume=55&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.pages=261-268&amp;rft.date=1962-10&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fapi.semanticscholar.org%2FCorpusID%3A162213219%23id-name%3DS2CID&amp;rft_id=%2F%2Fwww.jstor.org%2Fstable%2F1508723%23id-name%3DJSTOR&amp;rft_id=info%3Adoi%2F10.1017%2FS0017816000007926&amp;rft.aulast=Frye&amp;rft.aufirst=Richard+Nelson&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AIran"></span></span>
